40967964.review:
Um dos melhores jogos que eu já joguei vale muito a pena comprar. 
Pontos positivos.
- Trilha sonora absurda, auxilia de forma perfeita na imersäo do game.
- Visual do jogo, eles däo um foco legal nisso inclusive `` forçando `` o personagem a admirar a vista (Para ganho de conquista) e de fato o cenário é muito lindo
- Jogo é inteiramente puzzle com traços de RPG (Tendo que melhorar arma, aprimorar habilidades, achar cristais de vida/mana etc..) oq deixa a play muito mais fluída e menos cansativa
- O mapa é enorme e sempre em constante mudança oq provavelmente deixará vc perdido em alguns momentos, por um lado é ruim, por outro te força a explorar mais o continente dando a oportunidade do jogador descobrir rotas e passagens secretas antes deixadas para trás
- A lore do jogo é bem subjetiva, näo há dialogo e isso pra mim foi um dos pontos alto no game. Oq deveria ser de entendimento geral passa ser um conteúdo enigmático, forçando o player a elaborar diversas teorias sobre oq de fato aconteceu no mundo mecanizado
- O Jogo trás diversas ameças e inimigos bem diferentes, além disso o mapa é bastante traiçoero. É um ponto positivo, pois n deixa o game monótomo e clichë

Pontos negativos.
- Achei o sistema de lutas um ponto fraco no jogo, é bastante confuso e fácilmente burlado caso vocë fique spamando rolamento. No ínicio é um pouco complicado, principalmente pra quem joga pelo teclado, mas posteriormente fica bem fácil e pouco desafiador. 
- Outro ponto falho no jogo é a posiçäo da cämera, muitas vezes dificultando na gameplay. Vocë n tem controle nenhum sobre ela. Em alguns momentos, principalmente nas partes de explorar o mapa faz uma falta tremenda.

Recomendaçöes
- Se vocë possuir um controle recomendo vc usar, o jogo pelo teclado é complicado. Em certos momentos o jogador precisa tirar a mäo do mouse para realizar comandos pelo teclado (Nada que prejudique a gameplay, mas é uma dica válida)
- Explore o mapa com calma, näo se afobe em terminar logo o jogo, pois muito provavelmente vocë deixará passar locais que possuem cristais, fragmentos e habilidades que iräo te ajudar no decorrer do game, principalmente no final dele.

40927778.review:
My first hour of this game consisted of the following:

1. Following a robot, who seems to be my guide, then running around aimlessly trying to figure out where to go.

2. Eventually working out you can jump on certain ledges, yay. More following the robot, with a bit more figuring out where to go thrown in.

3. Finding an upgrade vending machine in a cave, but I have no money and no weapon to upgrade.

4. Finding a sword in the same cave. Yay again. Stll no money with which to upgrade it though.

5. Nothing else in cave, so exiting cave. No indication of where to go or what to do. Robot just stood by entrance of cave, but there's nothing else to do in there.

6. Game freezing, looks like it wanted to play a cutscene and took away controls, didn't do anything and didn't give them back. Alt-F4 to quit, then continue from checkpoint.
 
7. Getting stuck in scenery after jumping into what subsequently turned out to be a character switching pod thing that didn't trigger it's screen for some reason. Unable to get out. Restart from checkpoint.

8. Running around aimlessly, backtracking, trying everything I can think of working out what to do.

9. Eventually working out that there was some destructable scenery. Going down a few grass ladders. Progress at last!

10. Again having no idea what to do. Character can sit on edge of mountain and admire scenery, so have obviously got somewhere important, but it seems to be a dead end. 

11. More running aimlessly and backtracking working out where to go next.

12. Jumping off a ledge and exploding because the fall was too high.

My second hour didn't happen as at this point I chose to refund the game.

The game seems to have a lot of positive reviews, but without any actual evidence of it getting any better than what I described above, I'd recommend steering far clear and spending your money on something else!

40909278.review:
Beautiful game, would have been awesome if there were fewer bugs.

Beginning with the cons: 

1. The game crashes quite often.

2. You might get stuck inside a bush or something if you jump from a wrong place.

3. It's highly possible that you might need a guide during the gaming process. I ran through the whole map for two or three times in the beginning just to find where I should go for the next step. 

Still do I recommend it since

1. I really love the landscape and music in the game (took more than 100 screenshots, the pictures are amazing).

2. The crashes and bugs are acceptable for me since the game reopens pretty fast and there are enough savepoints on the map so you won't lose too much process. 

However, if you are looking for seamless gaming experience, think twice before you buy it.

40891611.review:
我从前是火炬之光的玩家，这部新作让我看到了他们奋力拜托暗黑系列的影响的决心，也许这种并不是适合大多数人的，集解谜、开放世界、ARPG、朋克于一身的游戏，才是他们真正想做的游戏。
    虽然这样更加难以商业推广，虽然这样并不能为他们带来销量。
    但是这样做出的游戏，是能让玩家看到制作组的影子的游戏，这类游戏多见于独立游戏，有“胆量”这么做的制作组太少太少了。
    当然他们也解散了，既《Hob》这一绝唱之后。

    诚如其他评测所说，也许很多玩家不适应，不习惯，甚至完全地讨厌此类“不明所以，观光大于内涵”的游戏，所以只有当你满足如下条件时才推荐入手：

    1.对火炬之光，暗黑一类游戏的叙事模式没有抗拒感。

    2.不会对跑图过程感到厌烦，喜欢欣赏游戏中的风景。

    3.一定程度上热爱朋克风，但不是死忠重朋克的玩家（这款游戏可能无法满足这类人）

    4.并不是为了打打杀杀而来。

    5.有一定的玩其他解谜游戏的经验。（方便上手）

    6.对没有引导步骤的游戏有耐心，并且能以平常心审视游戏过程的人。

    以上也大概说明了这款游戏的缺点：深度不高，剧情晦涩，没有新手引导（其实谜题并不是很难，主要时间都在跑图和找路上）

结论：信仰入手，慎重入手。

40881809.review: Le meilleur jeu du monde ! Arrivée à la fin je voulais rejouer encore !

40845877.review:
[h1]HobNob: A Tale With No Biscuits[/h1]

Hob is an interesting premise done well, just not faultless but it is still a very fun, engaging, colourful and fairly unique experience, despite at times feeling like it is lacking for enemy variation and it occasionaly suffering from annoying camera angle changes. The story is not told through dialogue but through exploration and discovery. 

The performance was decent enough for me, although I have heard people saying that it crashes a lot, I did not have that experience but did have an occassional crash but nothing for me to get upset about.

[h1]Story:[/h1] I do not have a lot to say about the story, as it is best experienced as intended, you following metaphorical breadcrumbs from area to area, changing the landscape as you go, unlocking new powers and upgrades. Everything in this aspect is best done through your own exploration and discovery of the environment you find yourself in, so I shall say no more.

[h1]Issues:[/h1] The biggest drawback of Hob for me, is that if you spend your time with the game in small parts, of maybe only an hour or so at a time, then can not play again for about a week, you forget where you were, what you were doing and where you have been.
In fact, that last point is my most negative issue of my experience with the game, I played for an hour or so once or if I have the time, twice per week and then when I make some time for it again, I have forgotten what I was doing when I went back in, then had to try to retrace my steps and try my best to recall what I was about to do.
[i]However, I do realise that is mostly down to me, not the game itself. I just say this to suggest that when you play, you play for longer perioods of time than I did, if that is possible.[/i]

[h1]Additional:[/h1] The more of the map you unlock, will eventually have you feeling like you are going the wrong way at times regardless of how long you have played. I think this is inevitable due to the nature of the game.

[h1]Summary:[/h1] Hob is a really good game, it has so much going for it, cutesy characters, it is colourful, family friendly, interesting premise, endearing, charming and most importantly, it is [b]extremely satisfying,[/b] as you approach a newly discovered mechanism to then manipulate the world around you, changing the landscape by mostly unseen mechanisms underground, which leads to unlocking new areas, for you to continue to explore.

[b]Gameplay: 7/10[/b]
[b]Performance: 7/10[/b]
[b]Engagement: 8/10[/b]
[h1]Overall Score: 7/10, Buy It.[/h1]

40827984.review:
Gorgeous grahics, beautiful soundtrack and a nice mixture of light combat and puzzle platformer gameplay. Possibly the closest thing to Zelda available on PC. Unfortunately, the tedious backtracking choked out all the fun for me in the end. I played it for about 14 hours, out of which I spent the last 3 hours zig-zagging across the map, backtracking and trying to find out what to do next.

In some cases, the level design even makes this problem worse. More than one time, I found myself swimming through some lake or river which had exactly two spots at which you could enter the shore, even though the rest of the shoreline was just as low. This can make for some serious frustration comined with the autosave function. You spend two minutes paddling through the lake, one more minute running around the rest of the lake, entering battle , being killed - and repeat the whole thing again to get back to where you were killed. Had some similar jump & run sections as well. Sou you better prepare yourself for a LOT of backtracking in this game.

The fact that there's no speech at all in the game really adds to the overall mysterious atmosphere. Unfortunately, combined with the open-world gameplay, it leaves you clueless what to do next a lot of the time. I definitely would NOT recommend playing this without keeping a walkthrough at hand, unless you're ready to be seriously frustrated. You may well find yourself cluelessly running around the (huge) map for hours simply because you overlooked a crack in a wall.

Also, the lack of speech in combination with a gameplay relying heavily on backtracking may make the world seem a tad lifeless after a while, even though there's quite a number of adorable creatures in it and the fauna is simply gorgeous to look at. Still, due to all the tracing your own steps back all the time, it feels quite a bit like a walking simulator after a while.

So, even though I fell in love with it's stunning looks and mysterious, fairy-tale atmosphere at first, it really grew stale after a while and I just couldn't bring myself to finish it, because I learned that that would mean hours and hours of more backtracking and revisiting places I had been to a dozen times before again. 

It's a shame. Given a more balanced gameplay and mission-tracking or hint system and some kind of discernable back story, Hob could have been a cult classic on PC, because there's not too much like it in terms of atmosphere. But given it is the way it is now, it simply feels unfinished and dull.

40722956.review:
Hob is an open world metroidvania experience, in a form of an isometric platformer focused on puzzles and exploration. The game also features combat, but as long as you figure out how to tackle each creature type then it's not complicated, and for the most part it can be avoided if someone chooses to rush past enemies.

Visuals are simply gorgeous. The atmosphere is great. The world is excellently crafted. It's a sort of bio-mechanic creation, where entire areas can rise up from underground. Figuring stuff out is satisfying. And even though there is not a single word spoken, it gave me a lot to think about. :)

I explored everything thoroughly, found all the lore & secret passages, collected every power-up & upgrade, and visited each imaginatively framed vista. Essentially, I enjoyed this game quite substantially and wanted to savor the experience. :)

[i]Written after beating the game with 18.5 hours played & 33 of 37 (89%) achievements earned.[/i]

I finished it in 14 hours, but there are a lot items/upgrades to find.

Unfortunately, there will be no Hob 2, since the studio closed. Also, read the comic in the developer site before start the game.

40599683.review:
Gran juego. El sistema de descubrimiento del mundo es excelente y muy llevadero. Solo en breves ocasiones uno desconoce hacia donde ir o que hacer, pero con un poco de dedicación en la exploración, el problema se subsana rápidamente. Las graficas son muy simpáticas y agradables a la vista; no obstante, cuenta con algunos bugs menores en los que el personaje se traba. 
La historia si bien es desentrañable y muy intuitiva a pesar de que el juego no tiene voces ni textos, se podría decir que uno no puede comprenderla a fondo sin leer una guía o investigar en internet. 
La música es muy agradable y acompaña a las texturas del juego en su entorno pacífico y relajado. 
Los combates son divertidos pero ligeramente monótonos; se entiende rápidamente que no forma parte central del juego el entablar batalla, pero aún así falta un poco más de dedicación en su acabado. 
En resumen, un gran juego para divertirse y jugar con fluidez y relajación. Una aventura para aquellos que gusten de la exploración y los puzles.

40598931.review:
Hob is a Zelda-like game built in a beautiful world combining a natural world full of greenery, flowing rivers, and deserts with a bit of a steampunk theme as the entire game world is built on a giant machine, with the disease of some horrible purple plague marring much of the landscape. The big kicker is that there is no talking in the game whatsoever; aside from a few button prompts to teach you how to use certain abilities, you must learn everything about the world through expressions, with a few characters talking unintelligibly to you. This is actually done really well, as much of the story is shown well enough to interpret who everybody is relative to each other, where they came from, and how they matter in the present, while leaving enough open to question if you're doing the right thing.

Gameplay revolves around exploring the environment through platforming, as well as smacking around some baddies with your proto sword thingee, along with a bag of tricks to give you an edge in both. Movement is very fluid and skill based, so if you screw something up, its 100% your fault. I did have a few issues with the platforming, as the Hob faced the wrong way when angling a jump, but if you pay attention and don't just rush your jumps, you'll be fine. As for fighting, the big problem is that the enemies don't seem to scale up to being terribly powerful. On a regular run trying to find everything including health pick ups, combat was rarely difficult and there are very few boss type battles to change it up, which is a bit of a shame, although doing a run of no health upgrades will definitely be a challenge as enemy damage seems to be scaled around the idea that you will use them to increase your health quickly.

Overall, Hob is a good game that is beautiful to visit, with emphasis on exploring the beauties of nature and horrors of the plague-y menace corrupting the land, with both the story and combat taking a back seat (the former of which is a bit of a shame as the mechanics are solid, there just isn't enough big baddies to use them on).

40595414.review:
I saw Hob on sale while looking for some VR games on sale and bought it at the same time as some of those VR games. I watched a single video on it and thought it would be up my alley.

I think the art style is awesome and has a very nice aesthetic. One of my favourite things about the game was the art style and how the world all fit together like a big 3D jigsaw puzzle.

The story is pretty basic, but I think the protagonist and his mechanical friend have character and make you want to find out what's going on in the game world. Combat mechanics are responsive and don't feel cheap or flawed or anything like that I died a decent amount on hard difficulty but it was always completely my fault, not due to slow or clunky combat or anything like that.

It took me 10 hours to play through. I didn't get every little thing to upgrade everything possible but I think I was pretty close to doing so. So if you're one of those 100% kind of people then maybe it would be around 12-15 hours?

I picked it up for I think just over $11 CAD and I think it is worth that price. It was fun to play and explore the, imo, wonderfully crafted and charming environment.

[h1] O que dizer sobre [b] Hob [/b] [/h1]

40456448.review:
Good game with great visuals and simple combat, I recieved it as a gift from some friends. If you're a fan of puzzle platformers and generally can find your own way around (which is partially what this game makes you do, with some small direction) then you'll love this.

Keyboard and Mouse is definitely not a good direction to go, controller as is suggested will get you everywhere. The graphics are nice, some odd texture glitches happen in places from time to time but nothing major. The game takes as many chances as possible to show you the nicely crafted elements and how pretty the world is (if you care about that sort of thing). Everything pretty much explains itself and does it well, for those who can catch on quickly. The game has a launcher on startup that lets you tweak settings before starting everything up instead of having to wait for the game to fully launch and then having to close it just to apply the updated settings, which is a nice change. 

Found out recently that the Devs- Runic games, went out of business a few months back (hey I don't pay attention to that so whatever) so the game won't recieve any further support unless they sell it to another company (would be nice, it is definitely a fun game). In the hours I've played I've experienced a fair few bugs and glitches since they were only able to pump the game out and then a month or so later PW kicked them to the curb because...???...P2P profit. However the game is completeable and none of the glitches or bugs I've seen have been game breaking. At most I've seen enemy character models with no collision in T-pose (once) and had the game crash 2 times, once 13 minutes in the first time I tried to play, and numerous odd gravity hitches when you jump to a spot you shouldn't be able to stand. Those kind of things could easily be fixed and hell, they even have (on crash) a bug report thing that pops up however, since they're dead in the water what good that'll do... yeah.

So I would recommend this game, though as it sits now and because as far as I know no one has yet to even mention picking this game up- wait on a sale pick it up and enjoy....unless you need direct guidance to every aspect in a game to complete it at which point I'll just say look elsewhere cause this is just distilled frustration for you.

Hoping this turns into one of those little hidden gems of a game that people sorely want a sequel to...as long as the sequel isn't some kickstarted crapchute that is.

40378254.review:
Challenging, very satisfying, and quite addicting.

If you are a fan of Zelda, Hyper Light Drifter, or Darksiders, do yourself a favor and try this game. While you don't get the character customization of Darksiders, the music score of Hyper Light Drifter, or the deep story of Zelda, you get a game that clearly cares about exploring and freeing a world. Hob has a unique way of expanding it's world, constructing itself as you progress. Each progression brings new challenges and tools, which are very fun to use! Combat isn't super important or deep, but gives you satisfaction when progressing across the map. 

I had Hob in my wishlist for quite some time before I snagged it on sale. After playing it (not all the way through yet) I would say it is worth it at full price! I found myself at work in the morning saying, "I can't wait to get home and play Hob." It was suprising how fun it was to explore and change the world of Hob. If you fancy exploration or puzzle solving, this is the game for you!

40298967.review:
Runic Games在解散前夕发售了最后的绝唱HOB，并将其与火炬之光1+2打包。我将其买在了预售时间，而打开这份礼物我放在了2018的春节。

购买游戏请参考下述未分类关键词：）
童心未泯、探索冒险、自由向往、蒸汽朋克、爱与和平

------

人类是一种好奇心旺盛的动物，孜孜不倦的去探索是人类的本能。正如诺兰操刀的《西部世界》，通过每集一部分一部分的展示，让观众去猜测乐园的架构；沃卓斯基兄弟的《黑客帝国》，则是通过各个维度的展示，让观众去挖掘机器文明的升级历史。HOB则直接通过无字幕的设置条件，让玩家仅能通过探索、解谜、思考，将游戏中的当前剧情、“史前文明”、巨大场景、惨烈战争一一从尘封中逐一重现天日。

游戏制作人应当是或多或少的受到了宫崎骏《天空之城》的影响。在这里不谈制作人的游戏诉求，HOB中主角所在的星球陆地有着漂浮感，而这正是一款核心玩法中包含这动作的游戏。当你在陆地顶端、悬崖峭壁、史前遗迹之间跳跃攀爬，似乎寄托了每个人灵魂中向往着自由和飞翔的愿望。

人、机器、绿色植物的和平共处。游戏中与主角一同推进游戏进程的机器人一定是有着智慧的，在HOB的漫画中机器人原本已在战争中失去能源核心，但是在代表植物的小精灵歌唱下其能源核心位置开出了一朵花而获得新生；而在主角开场就失去左臂后，机器人毅然断下自己的左臂为主角接上。这里应比《天空之城》中机械的机器人有着更高的升华，人与人造的智慧物种应当如何共处？在看见机器人结局时你的内心一定会有着不一样的想法。

游戏中充斥了蒸汽朋克的美学，不同于一般的蒸汽朋克中的巨大机械、暴力运作、锈迹斑斑，游戏中的机械无论大小都透着金属的质感与精致，加上主角种族的对能源的运用，我称之为蒸汽朋克未来版。

游戏中的场景可以称之为美轮美奂。正如前文所述，无论是悬架峭壁还是史前遗迹、无论是机械工厂还是水管大坝、无论是深邃地底还是迷雾深林，每一个重要场景都不突兀而与游戏背景、风格完美融合。HOB的美术风格卡通，画风清新、明快，与其本身小体量的轻松解谜的游戏玩法也是贴合的。

------

火炬之光应当说也是成功之作。但是Runic Games通过HOB让笔者看见其破茧成蝶的决心和绝响，这是我的处女测评，献给 Runic Games。

40079261.review:
[h1]Nota 10/10 [/h1]

[b]Hob[/b] é um jogo de terceira pessoa onde você controla seu personagem em meio a um mundo infectado por uma espécie de fungo, e dispositivos tecnológicos anciões, sua tarefa principal tarefa é limpar o mundo dessa praga, fazendo uso das ferramentas antigas e muitas vezes tendo ajuda de seus pequenos amigos da natureza, possui ótimos puzzles e uma boa jogabilidade. 

Esse é um belo jogo onde não temos narração nem diálogos, o que faz o jogo não contar nada, mas ao mesmo tempo mostrar muito, gráficos excelentes trilha sonora agradável e inimigos únicos, onde até mesmo o mapa pode lhe ameaçar. 

Recomendo muito esse jogo a parte final dele onde você decide qual destino que o mundo deve tomar foi algo que mexeu comigo, nenhuma das opções estavam totalmente certas ou erradas todas tinham seus motivos e razões, mas isso é algo que terão que descobrir jogando, talvez pesquisando um pouco sobre as conspirações na internet depois de zerar... 

Existe uma pequena [b]HQ[/b] no site oficial da Runic Games, lá você encontra um pequeno prólogo que te ajuda a entender um pouco da história do jogo, mostrando que [b]Hob[/b] foi desenvolvido com muito amor pelos seus desenvolvedores

[b]Hob[/b] é um ótimo jogo pelo preço oferecido, se estiver em promoção pense nele com carinho.

40055193.review:
As of February 2018, I would say I cannot recommend this game at least on PC.  Overall this game has too much wrong going on from a developer that's produced better games in the past.  I finished the game feeling like it was rushed to completion and not properly playtested and I will be hesitant before buying more games from the developer in the future.

Pros:
Beautiful atmosphere
No dialogue story done well enough
Fun combat

Cons:
Puzzles were too easy - this is only a con if you're looking for something harder, but all the puzzles were very straightfoward in my opinion

Horrible camera changes - I get that the devs wanted a cinematic feel I guess, but the camera changes were often disorienting and not in the greatest places.

Holes in the world - I can't count the number of times I fell through the world because there was a hole that shouldn't have been there.  This is not falling off the world map, which is fine but I actually fell through the wall/ground in numerous areas where I shouldn't have.  This is the one thing in the cons section that I could see them easily fixing and yet it still persists nearly six months after the product was released.

   With great non linear level design and puzzles neither too challenging nor too easy, Hob is definitely deserves to be sit on the shelves among great old platform games as a classic. Art style is unique and gorgeous and will stun you the beauty of the landscape and character designs. 

   Controls can be a little clunky sometimes, and camera surely is a frustration, but these can easily be overlooked because the game overall is really good and worth every coin.

39985233.review:
I have one word for this game - beautiful!

This is such a creative game with such beautiful scenery. I couldn't get close enough to my monitor to admire how well the graphics are done :-D The gameplay pretty much involves running around in this beautiful world and solving puzzles and fighting the odd enemy here and there. The puzzles aren't super challenging, but I found this to be a good thing as I personally don't like puzzles that are too hard that I end up googling a walkthrough for anyway. The world is cleverly designed. Pulling a lever here might open up a whole new area you would've never guessed existed. I was quite amazed at how well this was done. Fighting enemies is fun. They can be dumb sometimes and they hit each other, but I'm pretty sure the game was designed to be this way. There are also friendly littles "allies" which are cute to look at and make the game that much more engaging. 

Overall I feel this was money well spent.

39847154.review: I would definitely recommend, it got mixed reviews and I would say that's about right. Some love it and others hate it, but as long as you go in knowing that there are bugs and issues you should be fine. This game has its problems, bugs and parts that felt unfinished or rushed, but I enjoyed the game despite these issues. The shape language is really strong and awesome, it really made me want to explore the world. 39841810.review:
I really liked Hob with it minimalistic art style. It does a fantastic job in steering where the player has to go and what comes next, just based on visual clues. Which is necessary as there is no real dialogue or text. The characters communicate more with gestures and sounds. If you played a Dark Souls, there will be some familiarity in terms of discovering and advancing in new areas and unlocking shortcuts that allow you to navigate the world faster. Exploring the world is awarded by unlocking new skills and weapon upgrades, which one can buy with orbs collected for example from defeating enemies. You also find new tools that allow you to access new areas and give you more options during combat, like in a metroid or a zelda, but not as deeply integrated. 

Cons:
Unfortunately  the game is not without fault. The fixed camera angles can become frustrating at times, especially during jumping passages or some enemy enconters. Also during some camera expositions when unlocking a new area the fps can drop signifcantly, but as far as I noticed it stays stable during normal gameplay.

39836854.review:
[h1] 推薦: ★★★★☆[/h1]
首先，這遊戲的綜合評價我最多只給三顆星，
但是身為遊戲愛好者，衝著對於Runic Games製作小組解散的遺憾，
我在多給一顆星!! 

這遊戲需要細細品味，前期雖然有點沉悶，
但是隨著中後期獲得更多特殊的手臂能力之後，才會漸漸地感受到這款遊戲的魅力。

因為遊戲中都是以默劇的方式進行，
所以在劇情的引導上特別薄弱，會讓人有種"我到底在玩啥??"的感覺....

玩起來的感覺，機關解謎的成份會比較重，
喜觀機關解謎的朋友可以考慮入手，但是對於喜歡打怪冒險的朋友可能就不這麼推薦了。

[h1] 畫面: ★★★★☆ [/h1]
這遊戲的美術風格我很喜歡，
在造型跟跟色上，簡單又不失精緻 ，想要表達的感覺很清楚。
整個遊戲場景是一個很大的機關島，所以當解鎖某個重要機關之後，會看到很壯觀的地形轉換!!
製作小組還很用心的挑選了幾個"休息點"，讓玩家可以記錄並且放鬆的欣賞一下遊戲中的美景!!

[h1] 系統: ★★☆☆☆[/h1]
遊戲的整個核心玩法在於主角重生後的的機械手臂，

主要功能:
1.基本能力 ( 主要是推拉一些重物用 )
2.聚力一擊 ( 利用機械手臂的力量，聚氣並且擊碎牆壁或機關 )
3.電子脈衝 ( 利用電流的概念，瞬間移動到指定的位置 )
4.光束繩索 ( 發射光束，用來連結特殊機關上進行飛耀 )

[h1] 操作: ★★☆☆☆[/h1]
這遊戲的操作沒什麼特別好提的，就是大眾型的ARPG的操作方式。
比較讓我覺得困擾的就是...這是一款3D遊戲，但是卻不讓你轉視角....
有些視野比較不好的地方，常常都會因為遮蔽物擋住視線而跳歪Orz|||

[h1] 劇情: ★★★☆☆[/h1]
由於是默劇的關係，沒有任何的文字說明，所以整個故事背景，在網路上眾說紛紜，
也因為沒有明確的交代，加上又是屬於原創劇情沒有參考的資料，
讓很多人在前期的沉悶就放棄這款遊戲，這點是滿可惜的....

在遊戲發行的時候，製作小組有放出了幾張圖片，
配合遊戲裡的成就彩蛋，加上網路上其他人的解讀，
最後我整理一下個人對於這個世界觀的看法。

這是一個充滿機械高科技的星球，如何被外來的種族給入侵的故事。
整個故事的主軸環繞在一開始喚醒主角的機器人身上，這邊我們姑且稱呼它為"守護者"。

根據成就的彩蛋，可以揣測，主角一族也是從外地的星球移民到這個星球來，
隨著時間的過去，主角一族在這個星球建立起龐大的機械王國。

某天，天空降下了一位不速之客，也為這顆星球帶來了紫色瘟疫，並且汙染了大地，異變生物。
主角一族對於這個瘟疫完全沒有抵抗的能力，只好派出"守護者大軍"與其對抗。
所有的族人則躲起來進入深眠，靜靜的等待"守護者"淨化整個星球的那一天。

面對紫色瘟疫的頑強，守護者的淨化也頂多只是降低蔓延的速度，
日子一天又一天的過去，守護者的自主生產，加上瘟疫淨化後的重生，
形成了一個永無止境的惡夢.....

一如往常，某台守護者正在執行淨化任務，但卻不慎被紫色瘟疫所突變的利爪命中要害，
面對機能即將停擺運，最後選擇悄悄地離開現場，並頹廢的坐在角落等待命運的到來。

此時，一群疑似星球原生種族的遠古精靈，對其守護者的要害進行了修復，並且喚醒了它。
甦醒後的守護者，開始對於這種無限循環的淨化產生了另外一種想法，
它意識到，光是這樣的抵抗是無法阻止紫色瘟疫的蔓延。
於是開始踏上尋找主角一族，尋求如何終止這永無止境的戰爭。.

遊戲開始，守護者開啟了石門，喚醒了主角...

官方漫畫:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1291160709

39826199.review:
Hob is an easy-going, colorful, stylish, 3D action-adventure platformer with mechanically strong roots from games released the mid 1990's to early 2000's. 

Immediately, the bright flat colors of the organic-mechanical design captures the eye. Trees look to be made of manufactured tubes, the ground rises high in sharp angular plateaus, and even the grass is squared off at the top. While the world has many artificial signs, it is this planet's nature nonetheless and brims with organic life that feeds, vocalizes, and populate the world. However it becomes clear that this artificial garden is under threat from a purple ooze-like substance that has colonized large swaths of the world. As the protagonist,  you are tasked early on in the game to rid it and aid in the world's completion, where much of it stowed underground. The game is also pleasantly seamless- there are no gates that lock you in a gauntlet or bosses that you must fight. You are fairly free to travel the place once you get the three pieces of equipment required to traverse the land. You also get to hug and pet animals. But remember; you can only pet certain animals. Otherwise you may find yourself slicing them down. (I learn this the hard way...)

The game's audio is clear and crisp, complete with ringing sword swings, grass rustling, animal bugling, and that satisfying “clop” sound when the protagonist falls and lands from a high cliff. It all fits together nicely. The music is atmospheric- playing in and out appropriately, but always sticks to the background.

While the game is advertised as a “wordless narrative” this is false. While we can't understand the alien languages of the inhabitants, they do speak and gesture intelligently and the protagonist comprehends them. Its also clear that while you the player are in the dark concerning the particulars in the world, the protagonist is not and shows at least some awareness of what the world is about.

The game does have a bit of backstory not presented in the game or steam page and I found this to be a detriment to the presentation. There is a five page comic that can be found on the product's web page. This clears up a bit of the nature concerning the creature that finds the protagonist in the beginning. I wish this comic was either placed in the game or adapted to the game itself, as I didn't know of it until writing this review...after playing the game. You can find the comic here: https://www.runicgames.com/hob/comic/. There are narrative elements the development team thought were important to convey when advertising the product, but not in the product itself. Personally I only watched some footage on Youtube before purchasing- one with no text, so idea of  “make it home” or how the robotic creature you first meet saw “others try and fail”. As a marketer and developer, you shouldn't stash certain elements in adverts you hope the player watches before playing, as they can be swayed to buy via a friend's recommendation, an online video not produced by the team, or reading about it.

Mechanically Hob is solid with a few hiccups. First and foremost exploring can be a bit rough namely because of the locked camera. And I mention it first because exploration it is the number one thing you do in this game- more so than combat. Personally, there were a few times I just had to force myself to look up a walkthrough only to find I was in the area but passed the sticking path ten times because of how the camera was centered. But I could have easily seen it if I could rotate the viewing. Uhg. I'm all for discovering secrets, but players shouldn't have to scan the screen just to progress.

There is also the matter of upgrades, a lot are padded out in order to obtain them. First, you have to find an upgrade like more damage to your fist attacks or a better dodge. Then you have to have enough money to purchase (or craft as its referred to in game), and you can only purchase the upgrade at one spot at the south central area of the map. Much of the “secrets” you find are just money caches and many of the upgrades bounce between play style defining to faint improvements with nothing in between. The shield is great and game changing, but the “better dodge”, “more health packs” and “more powerful fist” didn't feel any different from the default. Sure you can use tubes scattered about to warp  to the shop, but I feel buying could have been done from the pause screen and saved in the numbing back tracking. But the whole “find than buy” system also feels...odd. Like they had a crafting system with different materials, but it had to be scrapped late in development. The cloaks, the secretest of the secrets, are all underwhelming. The intent seems like they were made to be play style choices at the expense of other resources (health/energy) but the impact is minimal. I didn't feel much faster in the green one,  and I had enough health and energy by the time I found the others. They are also expensive to buy, and require a special currency tucked away in secret areas to purchase. Due to the laid back feeling of the game, they could have easily been a straight upgrade you choose without the “give and take” mentality. Default for life.

However the areas are fun to explore and the whole idea of land masses rising from the abyss is fantastic. Many of the puzzles are simple block pushing, “lock and key” styled obstacles as well as lever pushing/button pressing to get the next area. Nothing too strenuous or brain wracking, which gives the game an auto pilot feel.

Combat is second stage to exploring, but it is fluid and fun. Though there are few enemy types, but they come in several forms sporting various defenses in which you have to use your tools to defeat them. This helps keep combat fresh. You are also free to retreat as you please and never caged to fight a gauntlet of baddies. The major enemies do not respawn, making back tracking less painful. Combat is on the easy side and I recommend anyone who has played other 3D platformers to dial up the challenge to at least hard early in the game. The creatures don't get more health/damage (to my knowledge) but become more aggressive and their attacks have less lag in them. This is my favorite type of challenge setting as it requires a player to think on their toes rather than just hit the enemies more.

If you've been hankering to play another action-adventure like Brave Fencer Mushashi, Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver, or the Legend of Zelda series, Hob reaches for such goals, but never quite grasps it. It just doesn't have anything that makes it own and stand out. Behind the sleek coat of paint is a fairly bog standard game. If you're new to the whole 3D action adventure genre, Hob is an decent first game- its got the core of what makes an action-adventure game and it's easy to pick up and play. If you're looking for challenge, either in the puzzle department or in combat Hob won't sate your hunger for something difficult or brain teasing. It also has little replay value, lest you want to discover 100% of the caches and items. Not a terrible game, just nothing to get a player invested in it.

39803429.review:
Alright, short as the name of the game: Hob is awesome. We're not talking about a Triple A game for sure, but Hob does its job. What stood out for me was its simplicity: Hob doesn't have a complicated story, doesn't have super graphics, but kept me playin for several consecutive hours. It has a perfect balance between of hack-n-slash parts (not too many tbh) and platform parts, both mixed up with wonderful sounds and melodies. For what concerns the gameplay, Hob seemed quite fluent to me: i didn't encounter too many bugs or glitches (probably 2 or 3, one of which made me basically die inside a wall), and most of the time i was able to escape everytime i was about to somehow get stuck. It's not a challenging game at all: i played the whole game at the highest difficulty and foes didn't cause too much trouble, mostly because of Hob's dodging and especially for his "stunning teleport" skill (seemed quite OP to me), and also because they all have the same range of attack moves, so that they become quite predictable once u get used to them.
Even if there are no dialogues at all between the characters, it's pretty easy to understand what to do, and even the map it's very accurate. Because of the complete absence of dialogues, i didn't understand at all what was the spider-lady saying, so that when it came to decide if join her or fight her i ended up choosing both things (first fight, then join) without any clue but just to get both achievements. I'll go for a 7/10.

PROS
- Addictive
- Platform & Hack-n-Slash balanced
- Background music & sounds


CONS
- Not challenging (even at high difficulty)
- No dialogues


If you've got some extra money go get Hob, for its price i think it's worth.

39801241.review:
這個遊戲公司總是能讓玩家回想起初次接觸該類遊戲的感動。

在這個作品中，沒有滿畫面的資訊，沒有滿畫面的提示，甚至連遊戲教學都沒有，僅僅是簡單的動作，沒人聽得懂的簡單對話，還有一個相較於主角，不算小的世界，但你很難說他不好玩！這就是一個簡單的作品，開放世界 + 動作 + 解謎；輔以優秀的音樂、音效、運鏡手法，將一份心意，呈到玩家眼前。

2018 年的現在，這間公司很可惜地消逝於市場，希望未來還有機會看到這樣用心的作品

優點：
    ．不複雜的操作；不像許多作品在 n 種狀況下，各功能鍵對應的功能都有變化
    ．優秀的遊戲節奏，明顯是經過設計的景點與音樂，可以有效讓玩家放鬆一會；取得新能力的節奏也相當不錯
    ．適中的難度，輕中重型玩家都能有所滿足，各式線索也不至於過度刁難
    ．場景設計極為出色

缺點：
    ．操作，在部分地點，跳躍的方向不直覺
    ．個人真的很好奇角色在說什麼XD

游戏的本质是休闲时间里给受众带来轻松愉悦，我对HOB的体验可以分作几个部分：

9/10 for a brilliant game!!

39737791.review:
Понаписал в что-то многовато. В кратце: красивая с отличной музыкой игра, но очень не логичная, что для меня критично. 

Для начала о хорошем. Игра сделана в стиле Torchlight и она приятная на глаз, приятная музыка. Сам мир в котором происходит игра разнообразен и наполнен и разными локациями и разными живностями, что интересно. Разнообразие врагов и головоломок в игре радует.

Мне в играх не нравится, когда сама игра усложняет игру и я говорю не про монстров или сложные головоломки. К примеру: иногда камера встает в очень неудобные позы, иногда персонаж на бегу не берется за край обрыва, а иногда да, непослушное управление шагоходом, малоинформативная карта. Игра нарушает свои же правила: вначале игры вы открываете двери рукой, а потом не можете, хотя они визуально не отличаются.  Почему-то все враги в игре могут отменить вашу атаку, а вы их не можете. 
Эта игра из тех, которые вас заставляют проходить старые локации, потому что у вас сейчас нет необходимых навыком, а вот когда появятся, тогда и приходите.

Так же в этой игре мало понятных и логичных действий. Тебе не объясняют правил этого мира, почему и как это работает. В итоге я проходил наугад, вроде там и есть указания что надо сделать, но они абсолютно не ясные.  И это не такие как были в Морровинде, найди хижину к северу западу от города рядом у реки у которой дверь появляется только утром в неопределенное время. Тут же тебе голем просто показывает нам надо туда(опустим почему нам надо туда) типо это надо включить обелиск иди по специальному проводу. И это работает только в одном месте, хотя по миру таких обелисков много и они одинаковые, и почему и как они включается не объясняется, в некоторых локациях можно догадатся, а в некоторых нет и они почему то потом загараются, хотя об этом ни как не рассказывается. Есть моменты когда голем ждет от тебя действий(к примеру включить тот же обелиск) ты проделываешь сложный путь(телепортируешься, лезешь по лестнице, прыгаешь) ты добираешься до точки, а этот голем оказывается рядом с тобой О_О WTF?! На кой черт я ему, если он и сам это так лихо проделал и как? И таких нелогичных моментов в игре много.

Есть такая прекрасная игра называется RiME. Она построена по тому же принципу, рассказа истории, одно большое отличие от Hog, это локации, а не открытый мир. Там так же ты не понимаешь, кто ты, как ты там оказался, для чего ты все это делаешь, тебе диалогами тоже ничего не объясняют. Но там тебя постепенно знакомят с правилами игры и эти правила сохраняются на протяжении всей игры. В течении игры тебе раскрывают сюжет, ты все равно не понимаешь, кто ты, но начинаешь догадываться и после того как ты прошел игру ты осознаешь все. А тут спустя 5 часов я все еще не понимаю кто я, почему я тут, почему голем который со мной не может выполнить эту работу которую делаю я. И вообще для чего все это.

39733099.review: The game does not strain its plot, the puzzles are pretty simple and that's why it's gorgeous.

39732613.review:
Before I write this I want to say I have never written a review on steam and likely won't do so again after this, but I simply feel that I have to turn others away from this game because it is a huge disappointment. And I really wanted to like this game too--going in I was sure I would. I love these types of zelda/metroidvania-type action games, the the beautiful looking (at the time) art direction was just icing on the cake. Honestly I feel this game could have been brilliant if not for: 

1. Some really, really stupid design desisions: the most annoying of which being that falling from any slight elevation instantly kills you with a out-of-place-in-this-game explosion of blood (I was at the point where I was often very unsure if it was actually safe to just drop down from any distance at all).  The game itself is also ludicrously linear, even though it had no real reason to be--you are forced to explore each area in a set order, I really don't know why they chose to make it that way as the sections of the map seem like they could have easily been more open to give a little bit of choice to the player, but what do I know.

AND 2. The game is insanely pretentious and full of itself when it really has right to be. It says 'wordless narrative' in its description but honestly its just 'wordless' without the narrative. It's fine to have no text, dialogue, etc. (hyper light drifter did it great), but if you do that you have SHOW the story instead, which this game just doesn't do. It often feels like the character your controlling is just doing things, flipping switches, turning stuff on, putting stuff together, etc. with no real reason behind why or what doing those things even accomplish, even the direct consequences of some of the things you do in the game aren't very clear or apparent, which makes 'puzzle-solving' a real nightmare (and by 'puzzle-solving' I mean do this, go there, turn this knob, push this button, etc., etc. with no actual brainwork involved). 

How far up its own ass is this game? It loves to give you contant wide angles to show off its environments for some reason, even though they aren't all that beautiful or impressive and all look extremely similar (so much so its very easy to get lost because everything looks the same). These wide shots happen so often, and camera sweeps over them so slowly you often can't see what the character is actually doing before they're already dead. The final pretentious straw though was that I thought I found an awesome secrete item, or treasure room or something based on this huge epic lead up it gave me. Turns out it was a 'Lore Room.' What's a 'Lore Room.' A room with a wall that has glowing shapes on it that is apparently supposed to tell some kind of story. Nothing else in that room either, no item, no currency, nothing. The game decided its 'lore' was such a great reward for the player's exploration all by itself they didn't need to anything else to be there. Yeah... all I have I'm a storyboard artist for a living, I know how to tell a story visually and what works and what doesn't. This game doesn't. It doesn't work on a gameplay level, and it doesn't work on narrative level. I feel it could have worked, but was held back by the designers feeling what they had was already so perfect and incredible they didn't need to change anything. They were wrong.

39718846.review:
Hob is a good platformer puzzle game. It's not without it's problems but I found the overall experience a pretty fun and engaging one. My first session with the game I ended up losing about 5hrs just exploring different parts of the world. The creatures and characters throughout the game are interesting enough. The fighting is pretty good enemies telegraph attacks mostly. You have different ways you can fight an enemy. You can also play the game by avoiding nearly all fights. 

Hob rewards exploration as you find alternative paths that lead to bonuses. Most puzzles in the game are relatively easy to get through/understand. I enjoyed just being able to run around and explore some areas which defintely lengthened the game for me. It's relatively short however if you take your time to explore you find extra puzzles and see more of the world the developers have built.


Problems with the game:

- Sometimes your character doesn't land quite right. This might mean death or you fall into an unescapable spot. This is when you need to use the respawn feature. Platforming in general is alright it's just a few times it doesn't feelt quite right. This leads to more deaths than expected.
- Camera angles can sometimes switch awkwardly. As they switch from one fixed angle to another as you run between them. Suddenly your characters moves differently to where you expect as the camera angle affects your movement. This caused me to run off to my death in a puzzle dungeon. This also suddenly had me respawn near the end of that dungeon.
- Fighting can be finicky. The lock on feature seems to disable your ability to do a dash attack. Some enemies can be a slog to fight as there is no way to tell how close you are to defeating an enemy. Locking on is awful against group attacks most of the time. 
- Sound bugs sometimes appear with certain enemies. Killed in a certain way the bombers death sound is stuck on that spot on repeat. you'll even hear it trail off as you run away. You can reset that by transitioning to a new area. The flying bug swarm sound sometimes just hovers in a place. There's also a flying bug nest where the sound just bugs out and stays there even after you destroy it.
- Check points don't always register your arrival. Some are stuck being up all the time. This affected me only a few times throughout the game. I would just die and then have to back track a little more than expected. Check points aren't exactly hard saves either. So sometimes you might need to back track to get anything that didn't register in the save.

I would definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good platformer to play on your PC. Some of these problems go away if you just take your time more with the game. Such as the camera angle transition. You won't get caught out by it.

39693726.review:
I really really loved this game. 

First what I liked. There was so much more to this game than I was expecting. Beautiful character design, an open expanding world to explore, numerous enemies to defeat and different strategies for different play styles. The overal design and thought put into this world was phenomenal. The music is incredible and drastically improves the experience. I love all the different noises that the different creatures make. This game was really well though out down to the tiniest little details.This game has a plot that is up to you to interpret, with no text, no language, just some body positioning to show emotion and music. Its an original story that you get to explore through a breath of different enviroments. There really was no shortage of imagination in this game. 

What I did not like:
- The fixed camera. Not being able to reposition this camera meant that some pathways with gaps you have to jump were unneccessarily difficult. Instead of enjoying the natural flow of the game you become stuck and endlessly frustrated. Being able to slighly turn the camera angle, even just slighly, wouldve drastically improved this experience. 
-The warp pads. I do like the warp pads. They have great design and add to quite a number of the puzzles. They are buggy though. Often id endup landing right off the landing pad over the edge and have to climb the path back to where ever it was. Holding down the warp button to long often ended up in double warping right back to where i started. This was a minor thing that I can easily overlook but it just made my play though experience that much more frustrating.

Even with this two pretty minor things frustrating me at times I still loved this game. I will definelty be giving it a replay at some point in the future. I leave this game completley satisfied. It was fun to play and has an original story. I cannot highly reccomend this enough. If you are questioning it, i'd say get it, and let this phenomenal game speak for itself. 10/10 for me, warts and all.

39684251.review:
For starters> Great game. I really like the visuals and the progressive difficulty. Also most things have one or more uses, meaning that nothing is "just a collectable."


What the game does well:
- The visuals
The game is very pretty, and the artstyle is amazing. Every area have a certain distinct feature to it and every enemy can be identified with ease.
- Great puzzles
This should be a MUST for puzzle games, but sadly a lot seem to miss the point of a good puzzle. Hob doesn't do this. Every puzzle opens a number of new things to do. Get more currency, new gear or just progress in the story.
- The story.
While the story is made to be without words, making you interprit the story as you play through the game, it is quite taunting. Something happened and along the main questline it's your job to figure it out with your golem friend.

What the game fails with:
-The camera
This is my main concern with the game. The camera is locked in a certain angle, that changes depending on where your currently at. This means that you sometimes need to calculate which angle to jump at, or have faith that you are actually going toi make that jump that is kinda blending into the background. It's not impossible to play around, but very annoying.
- The fighting.
It's a puzzle game, but a great deal of the time you're running around killing enemies. Whilst it isn't a bad combat system, it becomes annoying to have to fight more enemies right after the last group. Or having to handle 4-5 enemies before finishing the puzzle.
- Perfect jumps amd stupid platforms.
Some jumps needs you to stay at the absolute max of the edge or platform. This would be good, just not when the jump is diagonal to the camera, and you can't see how close to actually are the falling to your death. Some platforms also requires impossible to guess at first way of reaching.
-Ggrapple
You can jump whilst grappling, but be very careful as up isn't always the way you expect. Throwing yourself into the abyss ir more common than fucking up a ledge in Assassins creed.


Still amazing game, and definetly one I would recommend. Worth the price.

39680678.review:
Hob is an absolutely phenomenal game that offers an interesting take on traditional puzzle platformer/adventure games. People will probably site Zelda as the game's biggest inspiration, and this is probably. The puzzles, combat and general experience of the game all feel very much like a classic Zelda game. 

However, Hob isn't just an homage to a bygone era of gaming. It manages to establish it's own character, entirely separate from any inspirations the developers may have had. This is primarily achieved through top-notch level design that consistently astounds you as you progress through a world with familiar themes, (e.g. good vs. evil, life vs. corruption) but outstanding character that you're certain to be less accustomed to.

At first, it seems that Hob will be a game that relies almost entirely on its puzzles and environment to maintain its players' attention till the end. But as you progress, you uncover an intriguing and deliberately ambiguous story that spurs you on, as if both you and the protagonist are itching to know the next part of the plot. The game also has a surprisingly fleshed out and well developed combat system that offers players multiple styles of attacks to take down the various enemies they encounter. Monster variety is decent and hits on most of the typical archetypes you'd expect in a game like this whilst tying combat in neatly with some of the mechanics you progressively learn organically.

Overall, Hob is a game I'd highly recommend to anyone who enjoyed games like Zelda in the past and has felt like contemporary gaming has left this genre behind. It's a fantastic showcase of the genres potential to provide enthralling experiences through traditional game design. And for the low price tag, it's definitely worth it for approximately 10-15hrs of quality gameplay.

This isn't a bad game, but I can't really recommend it.  There are better games in the same genre.

The Bad:
The game is buggy and crashed on me a few times.  I also got bad geometry artifacts at times where I needed to restart to get rid of them.  And the mechanics on the grappling beam you get later are a bit wonky and killed me several times.

It is not an open world and is pretty linear.  It is about average for a metrovania.  Some revisiting to get new items or find new paths, but nothing amazing.

The story is pretty light and I don't think I got much out of it that way.

The Good:
It is pretty.  It is a lot of fun watching the world rebuild around you.  The puzzling mechanics are fine and I did actually play through to the end.  The crashing wasn't enough to make to stop playing.  They do a reasonable job of conveying some store without any words.

On balance, the game is just ok and there are many other recent games I'd recommend instead (e.g. hyperlight drifter).

[b] Análise [/b]
Jogo fenomenal. Não possui narração e também não possui legendas, o qual lhe transforma em um game inteiramente misterioso, Você se mantêm preso na história do começo ao fim, tentando desvender todos os puzzles que ele oferece. O jogo possui um mapa grande e com bastante lutas que ficam mais dificil ao decorrer da história.

Existem também aprimoramentos para sua luva e espada, fortalecendo e ganhando habilidades que lhe dão beneficios nas lutas e no próprio desenvolver da história solucionando os puzzle!!

Vale muito a pena o investimento. Super recomendo!!


[b] Game [/b]
"Hob" é um jogo de plataforma 3D com mapa aberto para voce poder explorá-lo, desvendar os puzzles e conseguir aprimoramentos ao seu personagem. Houve uma intoxicação na cidade por uma planta extremamente venenosa e você, o salvador da pátria, precisa destruir toda manifestação da planta na cidade, afim de restaurar toda a paz que existia antes,

Você está pronto para salvar o mundo da ameça venenosa desta planta?


[b] Jogabilidade [/b]
Altamente recomendado o uso de um controle. as açoes do game são muito mais fáceis de ser executada com um controle, devido todas as ações estarem sobre sua mão. Jogabilidade simples, intuitiva e com muita ação. Fácil controle do personagem, somente pecando na câmera, onde não temos nenhum controle e não podemos movê-la, o que seria muito importante em determinadas cenas e situações do jogo.

[b] Conclusão [/b]
Em geral, o jogo realmente é muito bom e vale a pena o investimento. É divertido, possui gráficos, trilha sonora muito fortes e válidas para a experiência que ele entrega. Super recomendo o jogo, O único ponto fraco que deixaria aqui é a falta de controle da câmera do personagem, dificultando o jogo em algumas situações.

Vlws, flw!

39588149.review:
Acheté pendant une réduction (15€) sur un coup de tête après avoir vu la vidéo de présentation, absolument pas déçu !  Par où commencer ?

La direction artistique :
Le style du jeu un peu cartoon peu plaire ou non, pour moi ça m'a clairement tapé dans l'oeil, le jeu est beau et les environnements sont vivants, le chara design est vraiment sympa et on prend plaisir à simplement profiter de la beauté de tel ou tel lieu.

Histoire : 
Pas un mot (compréhensible) n'est prononcé durant le jeu hormis les conversations (à sens unique) avec votre compagnon robotique qui vous indiquera où aller. Le jeu vous laisse plus interpreter qu'autre chose, ne vous donnant des portions d'histoire que par le gameplay ou en récompense de vos explorations. Par contre le fait est que si ce genre de narration ne vous plaît/interesse pas, le jeu se réduit à "sauver le monde POINT

Gameplay :
Outre une poingnée de morts dûes  au personnage qui  refuse de s'accrocher à une plateforme, je n'ai rien à redire. J'ai fait le jeu avec une manette et c'est très instinctif  et particulièrement fluide, le personnage semble léger, agile et rapide. De plus les actions sont instantanées, c'est vraiment plaisant à  jouer.
Les énigmes sont bien réfléchies, et bien que le jeu soit relativement court si on ne cherche pas tous les collectibles, sont très nombreuses. Cependant elles sont assez simples lorsqu'on est habitué au genre, pas TROP faciles, mais plus corsées n'aurait pas fait de mal (il en va de même pour les combats, si vous aimez la difficulté à ce niveau, reglez le jeu en difficile dès le début du jeu)

Musique :
Les musiques sont assez discrètes et aucune (pour moi) ne  m'aura marqué au point de pouvoir la chantonner à l'instar d'une musique d'un Zelda, mais elles collent toujours à l'ambiance et sont vraiment jolies. 

Pour conclure, Hob est  une bouffée d'air frais, un jeu vraiment plaisant, poétique et qui paradoxalement pour un jeu de puzzle m'a vidé la tête (dans le bon sens du terme, genre détendu), on apprécie jouer pour explorer, résoudre les énigmes et dévérouiller de nouvelles portions du monde ou tout simplement admirer le paysage.

39586164.review:
This is, easily, one of the most beautiful games I have ever seen. Gorgeous graphics (if cartoon-like) greet you every turn.

Even better is the gameplay. Sure, there's a bevy of puzzle platformers out there that have combat and RP elements. But I doubt there are any out there like Hob that gives you the extra challenge of having no dialogue.

This is a FEATURE. And, in my opinion, a good one. The challenge in Hob comes not from your enemies but from understanding how the world and its elements work. There is... an underlying logic to the game. It makes you practice abstract thinking and logic while developing hand-eye coordination. It's about knowing how to make the TERRAIN get you to where you need to be.

Even combat with boss-type creatures requires your understanding the method in their madness. You can just keep hitting them, sure - the game seems to have infinite respawns - but where's the challenge in that? Observe your opponent, find a pattern or a weakness, so you can efficiently deal with them.

I'm just around an hour and 30 minutes into the game as a I write this and I'm thoroughly enjoying every minute of it. Easily one of the best purchases I've ever done.

This is a marvelous game albeit quite short (I reached the ending and gathered about 98% collectibles in less than 11 hours without any outside help).

It doesn't explain much, but all puzzles give you enough visual context to solve them by yourself.
The story of its world is hidden in what you are able to discover.

It has a bit of combat but all enemies have their weaknesses. If you can't beat them you might either gather more upgrades or try another approach. Don't worry about getting them later, I haven't seen any which couldn't be reached even after getting to the last checkpoint.

It suffers from some minor bugs. I had the game crash multiple times at startup. Sometimes one might fall behind or through objects. But all in all its more solid than many other AAA titles I played.

I hope to see more of the developers in the future as playing it was quite enjoyable.

39539768.review:
Great game!

Non-Subjective:

Lots of puzzles. Basic combat. Solid, yet shallow RPG elements. Plot is unfolded through non-verbal dialogue. The game is sentimental at times and and the environment "appears" complex. Solid 7/10.

Subjective:

Graphics and sounds are 10/10. Fluid and complex animations help tell the story and give the characters personality. The puzzles range from simplistic to annoying. At one point I spent 45 minutes looking for a place I hadn't been or a lever I hadn't pulled, only to remember that I could bash through the floor which opened and area that provided the solution to a puzzle- and then I never used that ability again for the rest of the game. This is an example of how obscure a couple of the solutions were. You can easily spend over an hour looking for a ladder that you missed. I was surprised and a little disappointed at how linear the game felt. You're presented with this incredible "open world". However, you're placed upon a path. Wonder off that path and you'll spend several minutes aimlessly flubbing about until you get back on the path and resolve the task at hand.

The Controls are solid and responsive. Combine this with the complex animations and your character feels "alive", much like Ori did in "Ori and the Blind Forest". One gripe that's synonymous with 3d platformers is the directional jumping and physics. The game will shift from manipulating your character from the player's perspective to the character's perspective totally on the fly. Run around on flat ground and the controls are intuitive. Grip a wall while viewing your character from a side perspective and you have to hold the controller left or right to get them to jump up to a ledge - hold up and jump and your character leaps to their side and falls to their death. It sucks and I died mostly from this. Also, Leaping from a spinning platform will send your character several degrees to the left or right causing you to miss your jump and fall to your death.

Gripes aside, the game is well worth the money. It's fun, intriguing, beautiful, creative and a little emotional at times. I love the world and all it's inhabitants. If they had fine-tuned the controls, added more RPG elements, and created more dynamic combat and abilities, the game would've been 9/10 easily.  7/10

39526798.review:
The best game I've played in a long time. I was surprised how good it was based on the early reviews, which made me put it off. Picked it up in a sale and could not be happier.

It reminds me a lot of Ico in places, in terms of there being a large, interconnected world where you often see other paths you've travelled, or yet to travel, in the background. The level design is superb, with how everything interconnects, and how the world connects and eventually opens up as you unlock abilities or modify the environment. Much of the game is about seeing a place and solving an environmental puzzle to get there. None of it is too hard, but some parts require some thought. I found it just right.

Combat is pretty fun and gives you lots of moves to play with, more than you really need but you can try different things to keep things interesting.

The background music is great as well. I'm tempted to buy the soundtrack for once. It was great to have a nap to while the game was paused once!

Graphics are really nice, unless you dislike the somewhat flat/cell-shaded style. I liked it, and the look of the game is nicely cohesive, while still giving different areas their own flavours.

I ran it locked at 60 fps in 4k at ultra settings on a 1080ti, so if there were peformance problems, It seems they were fixed, or I got lucky. I played it quite a while after release. I think there was one area which had framerate issues for a few seconds, which wasn't a problem as you just walk through that spot. I had ONE crash, right at the start of the game after a cut-scene, and no problems otherwise, other than managing to jump through the world a couple of times while I was trying to find secrets. Not an issue as dying is not much of a setback in the game (unless going for the 5-deaths achievement).

Very highly recommended!

39523317.review:
Hob reminds me of why we should never let the cruelty of the world prevent us from appreciating its beauty. It illustrates this lesson forcefully just moments in, when the androgynous hero suffers an infection that quickly leads to an amputation, all for the crime of being distracted by a graceful giraffe-like creature and the stunning landscape surrounding them. A robotic golem comes to the rescue, gifting the hero its own arm, which includes a fist even Hellboy could appreciate.

And does our hero sit around moping, having learned the world sometimes punishes the gentle-hearted? Not at all. They jump back into action almost immediately, using the new arm to punch, grapple, and warp the problems of the world into submission. That's kind of the story of my experience with Hob as a whole, as it kept drawing me back even though it occasionally treated me unfairly and left me confused.

Interactions between characters are depicted with gestures rather than words.

Hob readily evokes the spirit of The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, as its 10 or so hours involve solving a host of puzzles, whacking monsters with upgradeable swords, and finding health and energy upgrades stashed in the nooks and crannies of its beautiful world. But there's also a hint of Journey here, most obviously in the red hood with Batman ears worn by the protagonist. More importantly, though, Hob is a similarly voiceless adventure, depicting interactions between the few characters with emotion-laden gestures instead of words. Even the menus come off as puzzles in their own right, as they explain what items you've collected with symbols you must decipher on your own. The approach generally works so well that it's kind of jarring when text descriptions are used for the optional upgrades of the hero's rocky hand.

To be sure, the wordless approach allows for touching moments, as when your golem buddy releases a butterfly while our hero looks on in admiration. But it certainly doesn't work as well as it does in Journey, which is laser-focused on the clear goal of ascending a distant mountain. In Hob, it's never clear what you're doing or why. There's a vague sense that the purple, bulbous plague infecting the world must be stopped, but even that only seems to be the point of what you’re doing some of the time. The lack of written objectives in this semi-open world also makes figuring where to go next a chore, especially in the early hours when your goals are merely pointed out with vague gestures from the charitable automaton.

Hob is more concerned with painting a picture than telling a story, and there's little doubt that it paints a lovely picture. Much of the joy of playing it comes from just admiring the brightly colored landscapes where nature and machinery intertwine so naturally that it's tough to tell where one ends and the other begins. Not content to merely give us pretty scenery, Hob serves up a land where the world itself is a puzzle so that, with the press of a button, the landscape alters itself in a way that rugged cliffs and plateaus leap up where there was only sky before. You'll find some of the most impressive sights above ground, but others hide under the surface in dungeons housing engines so massive they could probably serve as spare parts for the Death Star.


Puzzles are never exactly complicated or even original.

The puzzles themselves are never exactly complicated or even original, being chiefly concerned with dragging and shuffling blocks or rotating gears. Even so, they're satisfying to complete, particularly when that final "click" triggers yet another reshuffling of the world, activating glowy turquoise lights and often creating new puzzles in the process. I found myself more fascinated by their elegant intricacy than their difficulty, admiring the ways I'd need to delve deep into the earth, rotate skyscraper-sized structures, and teleport like lightning over seemingly endless gaps all just to open a door.

Respawn points are plentiful and loading screens are short.

Sometimes Hob tosses light platforming into the mix, too, but these are among its weakest moments. The artsy fixed-perspective camera often doesn't make it clear if the next jump is going to make you land safely or go hurtling off a ledge. Sometimes the camera will even get you killed, as it's a little overfond of not showing you what else is behind the ledge obscuring your character. Sometimes it's a thorny plant that slaps you to death; sometimes it's a big ogre with a club who paints the landscape red with your blood. It doesn't help that Hob suffers from substantial frame rate drops at times, which can cause trouble at the precise moment when you need clarity above all else. It's a good thing respawn points are plentiful and loading screens are short, as these moments threaten to ruin the whole experience.

And yes, you'll do a little hacking and slashing. It's not a major part of Hob, though, and it's fun enough to make up for its relative simplicity. Armed with both the punchy arm and a sword that looks like a key, our hero faces off against everything from trolls who pelt you with explosive gas balls to nasty little minions who drop health-restoring apples after each kill. Combat itself is a fun mix of dodge rolling and slashing at the appropriate time or busting through shields with a meaty punch of the rocky hand. Sometimes, though, I found I had more fun when I didn't even attack the creatures directly, but rather fooled the reckless big guys into accidentally slaughtering their buddies in their drive to get to me.

All of these elements – the voiceless story, the satisfying if moderately challenging puzzles, the just-common-enough combat – combine to create a Zen-like experience that's wonderful so long as you stay focused on the moment and not on where it's heading or what it all means. Its beauty and composer Matt Uelmen's moving (if somewhat sparse) soundtrack help create that Journey-like feel, but it never achieves the same sense of purpose or – by extension –emotional power. All the same, I won't soon forget my time with Hob. It ends with a choice that ties back to the earliest moments, at last answering some – but not all – of the mysteries that popped up throughout. With a little more focus, this could have been one of the greats.

Hob is a beautiful Zelda-like puzzler with fun combat elements that takes place on an enchanting world where nature and machinery alter the landscape as easily as a twist of a Rubik's cube. The wordless approach to the story creates some confusion and the fix camera sometimes results in unnecessary deaths, but never does the time spent with Hob feel wasted.         7.8/10

39516901.review:
9/10 Game Review
10/10 Music
10/10 Visual/Graphics
6/10 Glitches, Bugs, Map flaws

So the game is one giant puzzle, stacked into several different puzzles, and chocked full of hidden areas, special powers, and things to make your little robotic sprite even more amazing. 
The levels and sections are mind-blowingly detailed and the animations in which they occur is out-of-this-world amazing. I haven't seen a game play like this ever. When a section completes -- the entire world and landscape before you changes, like a giant robotic rubix cube.

There's not a lot of story to go on, so wielding your imagination and understanding what exactly the non-verbal cues are telling you leaves a lot to be self-discovered throughout the story with hidden Lore Vaults, and just paying attention to the details of the landscape and what has actually taken place.

Gameplay is superb. Tumbling. Charging weapons and a huge robotic fist. What's not to love?!
The puzzles and memory games will have your head spinning in a tizzy and that-last-damn-sword-piece you missed because of a weird camera angle will have you scouring the world for an additional hour until you decide to look at a map or youtube, only to realize it's the one piece of twelve that's in a dungeon, not in the world. #bitter
Collect heart pieces to increase your life counter and energy cores to increase your energy charges; think Zelda.

I absolutely loved this game and the challenge and experience it brought me. Honest to God, I haven't had this much fun and enjoyment out of a game since I was in my teens, almost two decades ago.

The ONLY reason I gave it a 9/10 instead of 10/10 is development purposes.

I feel like the game is 99% polished and completed, but the 1% is something someone like me would find and break. Lol. I'm accused of doing this from time to time, but I found at least a dozen broken map spots that lead me into nothingness and resulted in a death, most often -- squarely in the middle of the map, on land, but cutting a corner in search of an entrance to something and find that surprise-surprise, there's a section of unfinished map and you just fell to your death.

Or where you find the sword piece inside the Tesla Dungeon and if you jump to the right of the end-door, into the nook, it'll teleport you out, as if you went into the door... lol. Weird things. Unfinished things.

Absolutely loved this game. Love love love.<3

39514533.review:
This game is absolutely brilliant.  gorgeous graphics and scenery.  an intersting mix of organic life and technology enhancing it.  Our world could learn alot from this world in terms of the relationship of technology and the earth.

The main mechanic - some folks will find this frustratng but I found it fascinating: no clear guidance. no tutorial, learn how to play by trial and error and occasional button press guides.  The game unfolds itself without any real direction, narrative, or story, other than the events that transpire between the chracters and in the environment on screen.

This seems like it would be lacking but trust me, it works, especially if you are an intuitive person who can read and feel characters based solely on action and appearance without the need for words.  It's almost like the brilliance of the movies in the days before sound, however the sound in this game is top notch, the music is amazing as are the graphics and mechanics.  

Controls are mostly sharp and responsive, and so far it's mostly perfect, but there are ocassional unpolished or areas where controls become akward due to camera angles or obstructions. 

Eventually you will get some clear objectives blinking on a world map you can access, but even then your also free to explore at your own pace.  

The combat is fast and fun and involve intersting mechanics with various abilities as you progress.

The puzzles and strategy require intelligence, wisdom, strategy, timing, dexterity and a number of other cognitive abilities.   

As with most metroid vania platformer rpg style games, you start off with few abilities and gear, and as you progress through the puzzles and tasks and explore hidden areas [spoiler]( i.e. bonus health in this game is a giant flower with heart-shaped-health-block inside) [/spoiler]

I try to go for $1 an hour for cost to gameplay time, and this was on sale for $15 while only $20 originally, and I am thinking there will we at least 15-20+ enjoyable hours, so worth the investment in the end.

Even if it didn't fir the $1 per hour gameplay model, this is a title that everyone should at least give a go.  if they had a demo it would be amazing because people know within 30 minutes if they will love or hate it.

Loved it so far, 4.5/5 stars
*** *hint* [spoiler] try to be nice to nature & listen - make friends with the animals instead of killing them & most esecially FOLLOW THE BIRDS & THEIR SONGS [/spoiler] ***

游戏扩展地图的方式很有创意，不过并不像当初所宣传那么自由。虽然能自由的去任何一个已经解锁的地点探索，但是除了少量未能一次收集完的收集品，并没有太多值得探索的东西。游戏整体上还是传统的解密过关模式，解开机关或者打败BOSS，从而扩展新的地块，继续新的解密。谜题的难度都不大，不过对操作有一点要求，[b]强烈推荐用手柄玩[/b]。此外游戏的美术风格和配乐个人都很喜欢。
游戏最大的问题是优化很差，时不时会有剧烈的帧数波动。能玩下去，但是肯定会感觉不舒服。不过我是很早以前通关的，不知道是否有人后续接手了优化工作。
总体来说这是块璞玉，虽然工作室的关闭导致没能做好后续的打磨，仍然值得一玩。

39450042.review:
TLDR: Great game, with a few minor technical or QoL issues.

Story folds out nicely, and revelations as to the gameplay loop's mechanics are very satisfying especially when you're spending the first hour or two of the game not knowing what's going on. Being a "Metroidvania", each upgrade you acquire has a certain satisfaction to it, although some changes could be made to make it a bit more impactful.

Energy is upgraded once for every six generic energy upgrade pickups, which are uncommon, found hidden around the map. This is fine.

Health is upgraded once for every two generic health upgrade pickups, which are semi-rare, found hidden around the map. This is also fine. 

Every time you fill a tank by picking a set of these, the only indication of upgrade is a sound cue and HUD change. I'd like to see some celebratory animations or cosmetic change on my guy's fist. Power fantasy stuff.

Your sword is upgraded once for every three generic sword piece pickups which are found rarely around the map. Rather than occuring as you pick it up, the upgrade needs to be instigated by returning to the Workshop. Personally, I believe this happens rarely enough that:

- each sword forging could have it's own unique forging crucible and animation (for maximum "shit yeah!" and power fantasy)
- each sword piece pickup could be more flavourful - perhaps a bit of lore as to how the old warrior fought and passed, and a hint of information as to the properties of the next sword upgrade... The pickups themselves could be generic, and the lore and sword piece decided upon pickup dependent on the player's current progression to the next sword, so that the player doesn't have to go back searching the entire map for "Sword 2, Hilt".
- each upgraded sword (and even energy/health tanks?) could be another avenue for upgrade-gated progression. The archives are cool to revisit and open once you nab that new sword, but i'd like to see more. Perhaps temples where you could visit and learn a cool charge move from a scroll or... something. If anyone has played the older game "Prince Of Persia: Warrior Within", something akin to the Scorpion Sword and how it lets you break through walls, or the Serpent Sword, and it's function as a key. 

Unfortunately this list would require no small change and almost entirely rework the progression system - I'm simply musing from a "what if" perspective. Runic is dissolved, and thus hopes for a sequel are low... I digress.

The QoL(Kinda?) issues rest with the camera and the controls. The analog stick method of control is undoubtedly superior for this game and this is mentioned to the player at the outset. Unfortunately, I do not have a controller handy, so was stuck with keyboard controls. This is fine for most scenarios, and Runic did a decentish job at making cardinal directions adequate for movement in their level designs. However, some scenarios contain platforms where you need to move at a 60 degree angle to the horizontal lest the endless abyss below take you, and therefore cannot pass with cardinal keys. The RTS-style mouse following movement helps with this, but it's still janky given the camera angle changes a lot - often instantaneously - and therefore so must your mouse lead angle.

How you circumvent this, I have no idea. But it is a little frustrating that you reaaaaally need a controller if you want the most seamless experience. My poor little hob dude has been led to too many a death by parallax error.

Overall, I loved the game. The lack of dialogue, the music, the scene, the more-than-sum-of-parts aesthetic; it's lovely. I want more, and I regret to hear the studio has dissolved. Perhaps the rights could be picked up by another studio. The game does stand on it's own, though.
