39367438.review:
This game was a christmas gift from a friend, and it ended up being the best gift ever. I absolutely loved this game.

Pros: 
-Fun, yet simple combat, that remains challenging, even on medium difficulty and is supplemented with upgradeable moves.
-Puzzles often yield a sense of accomplishment and all feel interlocked.
-A neat collectible system that ties into the story and collectibles well. None of the collectibles are required to proceed, but all feel like accmplishments within themselves.
-Beautiful art style with charming animations. The bright colors make everything contrast well, and make the evil goop seem that much more deadly.
-An enjoyable Metroid/Castlevania/Zelda-esque explore and return formula that is made simpler by the fast travel system, without making it too easy. 
-A complete lack of intelligible dialogue, simple gestures, and pictorals lend a very mysterious, unknown charm to the game. I often had no idea why I was doing something, until I accomplished it and was rewarded with a massive change. 

Cons:
-Combat can become very rinse and repeat, and there are only 10 or so enemy types. The extra moves and skills that are gained are purely superfluous, as you can defeat any of the enemies rinse and repeat style (this is offset by different environments, upgrades to enemies, and grouping of enemy types) but combat doesnt feel like a main part of the game with a lack of boss fights. The enemies just feel thrown in to take up space and give you more of the limited currency.
-It's very easy to miss many collectibles, and a lot of the lore is locked behind finding certain ones.
-With the lack of the dialogue, someone who doesn't find the same wonder and myystery in it that I do may quickly get confused and bored with the game, or simply feel lost.
-I often found myself wishing there was a legend for the map icons.
-The fixed camera perspective never really broke the game or lost me fights, but it was often very frustrating. 
-There was only once were I died by clipping through a surface, which was truly annoying, but there were a few times I got stuck in a platform or caught in a corner. 

Overall: I freaking loved this game. It may seem as though I complianed about it a lot, but its just so everyone knows what to expect going in. I strongly recommend it to anyone who loves action/adventure/puzzle/platformers. Great game.

39241947.review:
Absolutely superb.  Well worth it, and then some.

We play games which involve a player and a back-seat driver.  Something pretty with a story, some real hook, and a need to play just one more hour!  This delivers on all of these fully.

We loved the graphics, the story, the emotion without needing text or speeches.  The gameplay is fun: casual enough that it only got really stressful runny-jumpy bits in one or two places, while the combat has styles which you learn to defeat.  Both movement and fighting are easy to adapt to, and make a well rounded offering.  Respawn is simple and not punishing, so even when I messed up, there was no sense of frustration or doom.

Navigation can get a little tiring sometimes, especially when you get the third arm ability (trying to avoid spoilers) when you can go back and search for ages to find stuff.  Some additional icons on the minimap would have been a huge plus there - where the challenge would be 'how' to get there, rather than 'where' to go.  It put a somewhat 'dull' interlude in the middle of the game, which was unecessary but which the completionist in me would not allow to avoid.

Totally kick-ass game.  I got it on sale, but honestly if I paid full I would still be a happy little camper.  Map issues aside, I cannot think of a single element of this game which I did not find both enjoyable and highly polished.

EDIT : One little problem.  Well, actually, a spooningly large one.  Before you quit and go to bed, please check that your saves are actually saving.  You see, there is some strange circumstance under which the game shows you the save symbol, but the files just don't update.  So, just in case you lose the same three hours I lost, I'd check if I were you.  This is a total bummer, and I hope the devs take note.

39210794.review:
Hob is an incredible game that to me was based heavily on curiosity, wonder, and adventure.
The world that the game is set in is relatively small. But at the same time, there is so much rich puzzles, lore, collectibles, and beauty in this world that it would still take hours to discover everything.
The main "story" part of this game takes you wondering through every part of this world. Through about the first 3rd of the adventure gaining new tools (not entirely dissimilar to Zelda Breath of the Wild) that allow you to access the rest of the world. After that, you are left to wander more or less freely, though the corruption you found around the world may regularly block your path. You can however remove the corruption, though I won't go into much detail as to how.

The game seems to take inspiration from Zelda: Breath of the Wild. There's a lot of adventuring, parkour, and exploration.

However, one of the main problems with this game is that a lot of the stuff you gain isn't really all that helpful. The combat itself is relatively easy, if you die the worst that can happen is that you'll spawn a few metres back at the last checkpoint (checkpoints are very common), most of the things you killed probably won't respawn, and there is very little increase in the difficulty of the monsters over time.

Music: 8/10,
the music itself fits the ambient feel of the game, though generally you might even struggle to notice it.

Combat: 6/10,
the combat is fluid but too easy. There are probably about 15 different creatures to fight, but you'll only ever regularly come across about 5 of them. This means that once you learn how to deal with each one, the game becomes an awful lot less difficult.

Collectibles: 7/10,
I like the collectibles, they can be hidden in varying and cunning places, and I don't think there's any way to permanently miss a collectible ingame. But, as I mentioned before, the collectibles make combat easier. Seeing as it is already easy, the collectibles lose their purpose.

Landscape: 9/10,
I love the landscape in this game, it is stunning and interesting. The graphics them selves are very similar to torchlight, except there's a lot more animation and ambient noises that can make the game seem more alive than torchlight.

Movement: 8/10,
This game has parkour systems that can be a little bit clunky for use on the computer, as if you are using your keyboard, you can struggle to get the accurate angles for jumps that aren't quite diagonal. Though it does incorporate mouse control and other things that can make this easier.

Story: 7/10,
The game doesn't really explain much inside the story, nobody in the game ever says anything, but you can discover parts of the lore of the game by exploring the world.

Overall: 8/10,
It's an excellent game worthy of playing if you enjoy exploring.

The story itself is a little short, and there isn't much to truly challenge the user. However, there are ways to make the game harder. (no death runs, avoiding picking / purchasing any upgrades, etc.)

39194500.review:
That Hob has been so roundly ignored is a tragedy, but it shows just how stiff the competition is now in the high end indie space. Even five years ago Hob would have been seriously impressive for a £15 indie title – these days the amount of stellar games at that price point means you can essentially ignore the awful AAA space altogether and still run up a sizeable backlog.

Hob is an exploration focussed action adventure game with light puzzle and combat elements, with a sizeable overworld and discreet dungeons. So yeah, we're pretty much looking at Zelda here, but it’s so well crafted and designed that it’s hard to be offended by lack of originality, especially in a genre that isn’t particularly well represented on the PC. It’s a gentle game, happy to let you move at your own pace and the puzzles are just challenging enough that you won’t feel insulted but not so taxing that you will ever get stuck for more than a few minutes.

This extends to the combat which feels a bit lightweight and seems to serve mostly to mix things up a bit. Admittedly here it does a solid job, and difficult combat would somewhat undermine the more gentle pacing and atmosphere, but I do wish the game gave you a little more variety. You're pretty much whacking the same three-four hit sword combo right until game end, interspersed with the odd punch to break enemy shields.

Hob is at it’s best when you’re just off exploring – going off the beaten path is nearly always rewarded. The world is small but well designed and dense with optional puzzles and secrets. The platforming is the only area that could use some work – the fixed camera and isometric viewpoint can make it difficult to judge jumps even with some generous auto aim, and the save points are sometimes poorly placed which can end up with a painful trek back after an untimely fall.

As well as the obvious inspiration Hob also bears more than a passing resemblance to PS3 critical darling Journey, at least visually. As well as the obvious visual similarities of the protagonists, Hob also goes for the same style of visual storytelling. Outside of the ability descriptions everything in Hob is represented by symbols, and the story is told entirely via body language and the environment. As arty as it is, I’d say this is actually the game’s biggest weakness. While Hob has excellent visual direction and sense of place, it’s rather more vague on why you’re doing the things you do – both in terms of its overall narrative and more immediate objectives. Essentially, you do things because that’s where the waypoint directs you. The actual minute to minute gameplay is excellent – a puzzle turning on a water pipe will be engaging and well crafted, but it will not be clear exactly why the water needs turning on in the first place.

Despite a few niggles the game itself is absolutely worthy of a recommendation – but the publisher, Perfect World is not. Runic, the developers of Hob were axed only a couple of months after Hob’s release. While it would be a shame if less people got to play Hob, I can’t in good faith recommend giving money to a publisher that showed their developers such contempt. While I would never endorse piracy, if you can play Hob without paying for it you could do so with a clear conscience.

39110865.review:
[h1]不错的游戏，但建议半价左右再购买[/h1]

HOb是一款探索解谜为主要内容的动作冒险游戏。风景优美，独特的生物形象世界观，以及错综复杂的地形及宏伟的机械工程场景是本作的最大的亮点；当解开谜题触发机关，继而牵一发动全身，看着眼前的整个场景发生翻天覆地的变化重组，非常震撼过瘾。

[h1]一些瑕疵[/h1]
毫无指引，完全没有文本内容，对缺乏耐心的玩家不太友好。
收集和升级系统尚可，战斗操作手感也不错，但游戏中[u]所有战斗都非常鸡肋[/u]，大部分直接跳过也没什么大影响。
方向操作和判定很迷，有点影响解谜体验；解谜设计整体不错但没有特别大的亮点，解谜和场景随着游戏时间增长重复度提高就令人[u]审美疲劳[/u]了，不过鉴于流程不长，也还可以接受。
所谓的开放地图探索其实局限很大，推进剧情还是只能按照大致固定的顺序进行。

[h1]这些缺点都不是特别严重的问题，整体还是个不错的游戏，但是也没有达到看预告片时的预期[/h1]

39101323.review:
Today I've "finished" HOB story, it was a good run, has ramping difficulty, beautiful art style and nice music & sfx to go with your adventures. There's a fair amount of items to collect and upgrades/habilities to help you overcome obstacles. An interesting level design that changes because of your actions.

At first the objective is marked on your useful map, along with the POI you'd like to visit, but later in game, say near the end of it, somehow the markers are simply gone and you must guess and wander around until you stumble with the location or do what you must do in order to procede. Yes, it feels like you will wander aimlessly in the end not sure if it's intentional or a bug or maybe it was left unfinished; again, not sure if intentional or not. Thankfully once you figure it out (or cheat and watch a YT video!) you won't need another marker because you're right there, on the finish line.

I missed some upgrade items, missed the (crypts?) secret places that you unlock -with sword upgrades- and potentially the real story behind HOB world. Maybe you can't understand the whole "truth" behind it's veil without these places. Oh well.. more reason so come back and get it all! XD

There's just 2 things that bothered my, but don't warrant a thumbs down by no means!
- Fixed camera: Often you wont see where you are and were you're going. You'll have to wing it, trust yourself!
I thought you could only screw things up with a bad 3rd person cam being too close to our character, which most times gets you killed. Well, in HOB there's BLIND SPOTS, more times than I'd admit I fell through the floor (glitches, many many times!) or straigth to the abyss, that's it, there are no bounderies, no hand-holding folks, you'd love it!

- Kind of a spoiler, so DON'T READ if you don't want to be spoiled! it's pretty minimal though.
There are some giant *dead* robots that apparently are blocking the path or at least some secrets. These have a place with 4 slots, designed to be POWERED with 4 power cores (d'oh!) but here's the kicker: once you put these in, you CANNOT get them out to try/reactivate the other giants. So this -as far as I know- forces you to start a NEW GAME each time you want to reactivate such robot. Sigh.

I've found this one way too late, in the end, and by that time I had no way of tracing back my steps or using an earlier save (not sure that I would, if I had one anyways). I think -but don't quote me on this- you CAN reuse these power cores IF they are not placed on the ONE robot that leads you to the ending. I'd need confirmation as it's just an assumption of mine which didn't check before it was too late. Perhaps someone else did.

Anyways, it's a great game and you will most likely enjoy multiple passthroughs as it's kinda short once you know what and where to do. In fact, there are achievements for speeding to the finish line in less than 5 hours. First pass took me about 15 hr so YMMV, you know this!

Do I recommend this gem from RunicGames, the creators of Torchlight I & II? YES, I wholeheartly do. I preordered this game and it's given back enjoyment more than it's asked price, so yes, worth it.

I did liked the "retirement" feature of the Torchlights games and would like it to be here too, so you could take your (his/her) items and upgrades and pick up a new passthrough way faster than before, completing it each time a bit more, having a blast and maybe doing an evil laugh when you effortlessly slaughter the corrupted creatures that dare to face your rocky wrath! (get it?) XD

BUY THIS! either on sale or normal price, not too long, not too short. it's awesome.

I spent so far a good amount of time with this game, but I now think it is fair for me to express my opinion of the time spent overall.  (Warning light spoilers). 

It takes the explore elements from Zelda, and some of the combat from Dark Souls/Breath of the Wild. The story telling is vague an wonderful, keeping it all organic as possible. Allowing you to think of "wtf is going on" and put together the puzzle of this deconstructed world you awaken in. You are assumingly Hob, a small version of maybe the large golems you notice throughout the game. I questioned a lot of "How do I build this, and how do I build that, what is this icon?" I have noticed alot of consumers complain that the game makes you explore the world yourself, rather then one narrow straight line to the finish line. I understand many enjoy not thinking for themselves, but for a game that is built to resemble a throw back to the original Zelda title. Then get over it, and just enjoy the game. 

The one thing that takes me to a negative vibe in the game itself, sadly is a bug that is still exists and plagues my brain due to being 50% done with the game, is the Sword glitch. Due to Runic Games now being owned by Perfect World International I doubt I will the issue resolved with the sword bug with the forge. If you have two pieces and press the forge, it will glitch out and permaimently not allow you to upgrade your weapon. It is a bit of a throttle to progression, because then you have to unlock a door later on with a fully upgraded sword to advance. So you have to start fresh to fix it if the game does this bug. Urggh.

39000304.review:
Hob. 

I honestly have a bit of a hard time playing games that don't deliver a Zelda-esque experience. I don't really love FPS games, and clicking adventures/RPGs don't hold my attention very well. That being said, Hob is very much the Zelda experience I've been waiting around for! 

It feels a lot like Link Between Worlds actually, if I were to pick one. The combat is simple sword and shielding around, and the eviromental puzzles are always awe inspiring as they unfold before you with every twist of a knob or pull of a lever. 

If you're looking for something that isn't particularily challenging and feels very much like a Zelda game, I highly reccommend Hob!

Pros:
Beautiful atmosphere

Endearing characters

Clever enviromental puzzles

Light combat

Cons:
No dialogue may deter some, as there's nothing in terms of explaining a real story. A lot of it is up for personal interpretation (but that honestly made it more enjoyable for me somehow)

Frame rate lag was a bit troublesome now and then.

Glitching now and then was a bit annoying as well, but I still love this game. 

Conclusion: I picked it up during the Winter sale when I had never heard of it before and had no idea I needed it. Hob gave me them post Breath of the Wild, Zelda feels when I was least expecting it :) Get it!

38917400.review:
Hob was a true masterpiece of world-building and creativity at peak amplification. The puzzles were challenging but never enough that it was unsolvable or rage-quit-y. The villains got progressively harder, and the way the tutorial introduced fighting styles forced me to use strategy and timing that I didn't expect I was going to be able to do well. There also was no point where I was frustrated with the absence of direct information given, and it only propelled, rather than stunted my interest.

My favorite part was the world itself. The beauty and colors were capturing and the creatures were perfectly crafted. The game was also the perfect balance of exploration and puzzling, and, as other reviews have said, the 'do-it-yourself' work. This will rank as one of my favorite games in history.

My issues with the game were that during the beginning hour of gameplay, the objectives felt unclear. It was only during the 'Reservoir' section that I recognized the trail. Also, a few glitches in walls and world were frustrating, but most could be fixed with a respawn.

38911787.review:
As many have said, Hob is a very pretty game.  The first few hours of it are a pure delight!  I definitely do recommend this game to anyone who loves puzzle plattformers at all.  Everything looks amazing, and the areas are so imaginative!  This definitely touches on the same sort of otherworldly blend of nature and machinery seen in Portal 2.  That does however raise some small points.  

First, this game is something of a metroidvania in that you will spend a lot of time revisiting places you've been before.  There will be a lot of running around.  The save points that were all over the place near the beginning will end up being very widely spaced apart in later sections.  The fast travel system is not as well distributed as one might like either.  This means the end game sequence is artificially extended by long, mandatory sequences of running, climbing, and jumping all over the map, and at the end of that, you have whatever it was that killed you the last time.  It was probably a fall since there are usually save points less than half a minute from difficult enemies.  I will give them credit for that.

Second, a lot of the puzzles are actually really easy IF you can find them.  That would be my biggest gripe is that even though you are given a map marker to where you need to go, you have to find the means to reach it, and since the whole environment is connected to machinery, the place you actually need to go next may not be near the place marked on your map, and it might not even be easy to spot.  I played through the entire first half of the game without a guide, but I admit to caving in and consulting a guide after wasting an hour running around trying to find a spot to use the final armament that I hadn't already visited.

My final complaint is that for all that you're changing the landscape, once you open up a new pathway, that's usually the extent of it.  There are a few puzzles that have you do A in order to do B and then undo A because B opened a way to do C, but once C or D is done, that's it.  You will probably never manipulate that part of the environment again.  Except for weak enemies, most enemies don't respawn, but annoying barriers like bushes and thorn hedges never go away (other than the few cuttable bushes), while only some walls and cliffs become passable.  You have a sword and three different tools by the end of the game, but not much to really do with them, so you will be running through mostly empty landscapes, climbing up and down because there are no stairs for this section of otherwise impassable terrain, and trying not to fall to your death in the areas where there is just no easier way through than to cross a narrow span or jump a gap.  It would have been nice if there was a little more interactability with the environment and especially a way to shorten some of the trips.

All that said, those are quibbles bred by long hours of hunting for obscure things that can be tricky to find even with a guide since nothing is labeled.  I still absolutely loved receiving this as a Christmas present, and I absolutely believe that it would have been worth it for me to buy it on sale.  Full price however?  Maybe not.  I certainly recommend the game, but if puzzle platformers are not your passion, you'll probably want to wait for a sale.

38844390.review:
What a beautiful game, and what a shame Runic was shut down so quickly after publishing this.

Hob is all about puzzling through a beautiful, occasionally dangerous environment to reactivate old technology, shift and reconfigure old places, and clear out a strange corrupting force. There's clearly been some kind of apocalypse here, but none of the game's lore is conveyed in words - it's all environmental storytelling, gestures from mute characters, and a few light-based murals you can discover along the way.

I really enjoyed the environmental puzzling and the physical ways the character interacts with the world - punching open columns of rock to create ladders, heaving against levers to turn gears into place, and so on. The fighting is simple but feels weighty enough; though I never figured out how to perform complex combos, I never felt like I needed to either. This is not a combat-driven Torchlight at all. Mostly, I just spend my time traversing the world and finding secrets and unlockables, and just wondering at the mysterious beauty of the place.

Well worth your time if you're into that sort of thing, and a very respectable and daring final effort from Runic. It's a crying shame they were shut down because games that aren't as wildly profitable as microtransaction-driven online games don't appeal to corporate shareholders.

Also, despite the scare-warning, it plays perfectly fine with a mouse and keyboard after a short adjustment period. I alternated between right-mouse-movement and WASD movement as convenient for the level design, and aside from one particular oddly-constructed pile of rocks, I never had any noticeable issues.

I would recommend the game but THERE IS NO KEYBOARD REBINDINGS. Well, you can modify some configuration file to get it to work to some extent, but not all keys can be remapped (e.g. num pad 5). But this is not an acceptable solution. And there is no way creating a screen to reconfigure the keyboard is so difficult or that it takes so much time. As such, I'm flagging the game as "do not recommend".

I like the artwork. The way the characters handles during platforming is nice (with controllers). The fights feels unfair: we get interrupted when hit by an ennemy but they don't, the shield is too slow to deploy, and the range compared is too short compared to half of the ennemies

The world design is confusing at the beginning. It's unclear where to go, and too many ways are blocked. As the game progresses, ways open up so it gets better, but even at the end, there are too many cul-de-sacs.

Clipping is quite buggy. A few times I somehow passed through the environment and fell to my death.

Again, I would recommend if it was not for the keyboard rebinding.

Often the player is left confused about what the game wants to convey. Apart from a vague picture, nothing is told. Hell, without a walkthrough I would not have been able to even find and access all the locations where the story is supposedly explained.
Spoiler: [spoiler]There are Lore Rooms spread throughout the world and they only show gibberish in the form of glowing glyphs.[/spoiler]
Instead of feeling immersed, playing the game was more like me going through the motions. As story and story telling are essential game elements to me, I cannot recommend this game.

38800377.review:
22時間程かかりましたが、クリアしました。

他の方は１０時間程度でクリアと書かれていますが、
自分はマップ上の強化アイテム探しに没頭していたため余計に時間がかかりました。
普通に進めていけば、たぶん１０～１４時間程度でクリアできると思います。
（戦闘はおまけレベル。サイドロールに無敵があるため、殴ってはサイドロールの繰り返しでなんとかなります。
　自分のように強化アイテムなど探しまわらなくてもクリア可と思います）

良い点
・マップがキレイ。ほんとラピュタ。
　環境音メインで音楽があまり主張しないので雰囲気が良い
・仕掛けを解く事で派手な地形変動を起こす。
　「おおおおお」って独り言でた。
・その仕掛けも怪しいとこ探れば解けるレベルが多い。進行の妨げにならない
　（何か所か攻略ブログをカンニングしてしまいましたが）

悪い点
・賛否両論でしょうが、登場人物が喋らない（もしくは謎の言語を使用）、テキストがないため
　ストーリーはキャラの身振り手振りや、世界を見てなんとなく想像するしかありません。
　自分はなんでここに来てるんだろうとか
　なんでこれを集めてるんだろう、、とかわからないままラストへ。
　ラストまでいくとストーリーがなんとなくわかりますが、なんとなく、、です。
　（ＥＤ二通りあり。直前セーブあるのでどっちも見る事をオススメします）
・グロい
　コミカルなキャラがバラバラになって血しぶきあげて死にます。
・転落死が多い
　これは個人のスキルのせいもあります。
　向こうの足場にジャンプ→向きが微妙にあっていない→転落死が非常に多かった。


マップ！マップ！
マップが非常に作りこまれており、探検が楽しかった。
探検が楽しい。ここが一番大事だと思います。ストーリーはおまけ

38789521.review:
复习周爆肝两天通关啦╰(*´︶`*)╯
●卡通渲染的画面非常漂亮，感觉有点像黑暗版风之杖。
配合出色的环境音和恰到好处的bgm，整个游戏流程十分赏心悦目。
●解谜难度一般，如果熟悉此类型游戏的话，几乎没有挑战性，并且到后期谜题重复率高。
解谜时间不如迷路时间长（-。-
●完成度不算太高…比如各种各样的小bug，在游戏里设置的简中在launch中居然对应的是德语…然后就是喜闻乐见的卡建模、卡贴图ψ(｀∇´)ψ有的看起来真是哭笑不得，不过开发团队很贴心的给了我们“重生”功能，随时准备人生重来吧。
●缺乏引导…绝大多数时间在迷路…不过除非卡关了，最好还是别看攻略🌚
总体来说是一部很棒的作品，除开无伤大雅的小毛病，绝对是能让你好好享受十几小时的佳作。

接触Runic Games的第一作是Torchlight,在当时刚接触单机游戏不久的我看来，毫无疑问是一部令人惊叹的作品。第一眼看Hob的主角小红帽，巨大的金属手臂其实也有点Torchlight里炼金术士的感觉。没想到玩到的第三作却成了RG的最后作品，实在是让人唏嘘。

38789226.review:
Welch liebenswürdiges, wunderschönes Spiel, mit einem einzigartigen Flow, bei dem die reine Bewegung einfach schon Spass macht, mit einem befriedigenden, im Kern simplen aber vielseitigen Kampfsystem, dessen wahrer Held die Spielwelt ist, die die eigentliche Progression darstellt.

Doch von vorne:
Das Spiel in charmant simplem aber sehr schönen cell shading Grafikstil, den es sehr gut durchzieht, erinnert an Zelda, es geht um die Erkundung einer Welt, dem Bewegen in dieser in leicht isometrischem Blickwinkel, mit Hüpfen, klettern und rennen, aber auch dem Kämpfen gegen sporadische Gegner. Action-Adventure-Jump n' run trifft die genre Mischung wohl am ehesten.
Der Star ist wie genannt die Spielwelt, die sich durch Interaktion des Spielers immer wieder verändert und neu zusammenstellt, dabei eine Mischug aus Natur und Maschine darstellt
Bild
Bild

Dadurch ergeben sich immer neue Wege durch die Welt und die Progression wird durch eben diese neuen Plattformen, aber auch endlich erreichbare Abkürzungen definiert, wobei es auch verteilt über die ganze Spielwelt Schnellreise-Rohrpoststationen gibt.
Nebst den für den Fortschritt nötigen Sachen, kann man auch viele Secrets finden, die die eigene Waffe verbessern, mehr lebens- und Ausdauerenergie geben oder einem Aufrüstungspunkte geben um mehr Fähigkeiten freizuschalten, notwendig fürs durchspielen sind die nicht, erleichtern es einem aber und der Entdeckungstrieb im Spiel ist sowieso stark.
Denn die Bewegung durch die Welt macht einfach Spass, das Rennen, das Klettern, das Springen, das Entdecken, das ausprobieren neuer Wege.
Hier kommt aber auch der einzige Kritikpunkt auf, den ich ernsthaft habe, das präzise ausrichten der Sprünge im 3D-Raum ist manchmal etwas schwierig, die Ausrichtung der Spielfigur ist nicht immer 100% ersichtlich. Da die Wege zurück von Spawn-Punkten aus aber immer kurz sind ist dies nicht sehr kritisch.

Das Kämpfen gegen sporadisch auftretende Gegner (die nach einmal besiegen der gegnergruppe aber verschwunden bleiben) sind spassig, das Kampfsystem funktioniert flüssig und bei aller Einfachheit (Es gibt nur einen Schwertschlag, dazu einen Fausschlag und eine Ausweichrolle) gibt es ordentlich Abwechslung vor allem auch weil es verschiedene Gegner gibt, die ganz verschiedene taktiken erfordern:
Bild

Ganz generell, eines der schönsten Spielerlebnisse des Jahres, weil es einfach einen einzigartigen Flow entwickelt, nicht sehr anspruchsvoll aber befriedigend, es ist eines dieser Spiele, bei dem das Spielen einfach befriedigend ist, was auch durch viele schöne Details (Animationen, Soundkulisse, etc.) unterstützt wird und das voller kleiner Liebenswürdigkeiten steckt, wie dass die Respawn-Animation immer etwas verschieden sind.

38760744.review:
I recommend this game to anyone who likes puzzle/adventure games and is willing to deal with the issues it has. The reason I'm giving it thumbs down is (read cons). The game is addictive and I could tell a lot of thought was put into this game. Its very fun and has lots of secrects to find along with replay value.      

Cons:
1: Crashed within 10 minutes of 1st starting the game but after a PC restart I played for around 10 hours with no issues. Then I changed the GAMMA due to a very dark underground area and it started crashing again. I noticed every time I turned the game off (or it crashed) the gamma would reset to default and would not respond sometimes to any atempt to change it. This was random because it would work at times then it would not. Every time I set it though it would crash within 30 minutes.
2: I had an enemy that was frozen and was sent into the air from raising the land area which resulted in a floating statue. Later in the game it happened to my character several times and was a pain to restore to normal. I have seen post of it happening to random enemies and causing issues with completing the area.
3: After 20 hours of gameplay I noticed it was not running as smooth as when I first started it up. There where no fps drops but movement became choppy and character didn't always respond to inputs from the controller. After the 1st crash within the 1st 10 minutes of the game it was flawless until I changed the gamma.
4: Since Runic is no more I doubt any of these issues will ever get solved so that means for those who do not have issues from the start it will most likely be a game that myself and others will have to completely un-install after every play through then re-install to get the smooth performance back.

Pros: Super fun and great graphics with very nice lighting effects.
       Lots of replay value and has HARD mode and a Speed run achievement.
       The entire game is just one big puzzle and there is no holding your hand to get you through it.
       Even though the game has issues it can be completed.

At the time I have 22 hours with the game completed and only have 4 achievements left to complete.

Edit: After compleing the last 4 achievements without un-installing the game I got 1 crash for Microsoft Kernal and frame rates as low as 20fps. Lots of lighting issues and missing sprites.
Rig specs: FX 8350 @4.0ghz, 32gb ram, GTX 980 Ti, and W10 Pro.

Phenomenal game. Great art direction and visual storytelling. The gameplay is fun and challenging and making the world move is so relaxing.

Very much enjoyed this game. Would recommend it to anyone who are able to immerse themselves in the excitement of discovery and exploration. Singleplayer-only with minor replayvalue outside of gathering the entirety of collectibles and upgrades.

Giving in to the excitement of discovery and exploration is the biggest tip I would give anyone picking up this game. It is satisfying in itself to simply follow the indicated goals on your map, but being able to pull yourself away from them from time to time and backtrack previously explored areas to see what new ones have opened up truly give this game it's flavor.

The game is suggested to be played with a controller, but I found it perfectly playable with mouse and keyboard. Biggest tip I can give here is to move by holding down rightclick instead of using WASD, and use lock-target (tab) often. As for the other controls, especially as they are unlocked, this isn't conveyed to the player for keyboard in any way other than going into the controlls tab in the menu. Control defaults keyboard: [spoiler]Punch: R(press and hold) , Warp: F , Grapple: Q [/spoiler]

All in all I very much so enjoyed it, and I will pick it back up for a new playthrough at some point in the future, probably multiples. If anything like Hob 2 were to ever be released, I will deffinetely buy it.

38723737.review:
Y'know, I enjoyed my time with this game.  I liked the art style, and the overall atmosphere and world design.  There isn't much story to speak of, it's aching to be one of the more "evocative" type of games but can't quite pull it off.  The sense of scale and wonder isn't quite there, but they do a good job making the attempt nonetheless.  The story is meant to be told wordlessly, but there isn't much story there regardless.  The combat, once you get used to it, is decently satisfying.  

When it comes to some of the technical issues though, I wish I could be more charitable.  My rig is pretty powerful, and yet the game has constant, noticeable hitching, even at sub-native resolution and installed on an SSD.  It crashed fairly often, and eventually (near the end of the game, of COURSE), the C++ Redistributable borked itself and could not be repaired after a reinstall, a game cache verification, and a manual reinstalling of the libraries.  I wanted to finish the game but now I can't be arsed.  Sorry, Runic.

Mal abgesehen von der Detailverliebtheit und der tollen Atmosphäre ist das Leveldesign eines [u]der Besten[/u] die ich je gesehen habe.


Einfach gesagt: [b][i]Kaufen, Spielen, Spass haben.[/i][/b]


Ich hab noch nie so viel Rasen gemäht wie in [b]Hob.[/b] Hört sich komisch an, ist aber so...

38681845.review:
First of all, Hob is cute af. That being said, let's move on.

This is a game suitable for anyone, of any age. The world is vast, colourful and a delight to explore thanks to a fantastic level design and smooth controls. There is enough collectibles to fulfill any completionist's dream, even for a rather short game (around 16 hours for me). The puzzles are pretty easy, but they are engaging and never feel out of place. They're not just trials, they are part of the architecture. Combat is easy too and I consider it a minor element of the game, but you fight just enough to remember that this world is alive. One regret though is that the unlockable combat abilities are not that useful, simply because you don't need them to win - I actually forgot that I had them. 

Another regret is that I wish the game was longer. While its short lenght is not a flaw, it leaves me wanting for more. Should it have a sequel ? I guess not. Everything has a sequel and a prequel and a sequel of the prequel these days, and one-shots are refreshing and a good reminder of the beauty of ephemerality. Well, I'm getting carried away here, and the fact that Runic shut down pretty much answers that question anyway.

I find many similarities between Hob and Hyper Light Drifter : no talking, a vague story, a ruined land where nature meets thechnology, underground facilities etc. (also both heroes wear a red cape, but that's not relevant). Hob is much lighter and brighter though, and even if its world is broken and deserted, you rebuild it with joy and never feel alone.

38578065.review:
An interesting view of 3D platform games.

Hob has very nice graphics, textures look good and bright. It's also an open-world game, so at any point, you are free to do whatever you want and revisit any place at any time (you'll have to do that as you progress anyway). Like in most new platformer games, you can upgrade your character. Upgrade system is quite deep here, you can increase health, energy and acquire new abilities. To upgrade you need to collect some collectibles scattered across a big map. Most of the enemies you kill are one time only, meaning they will not spawn again at that point ever, which means revisiting some places, especially in the beginning, could be boring, but don't worry developers added fast travel option to most parts of the map. An interesting feature that Hob has as there is no sound. There is not a single spoken dialog between characters, the game makes you think about the story yourself, so it's hard to describe how good the story is without major spoilers.

The only problem with the game is a big amount of bugs where your character gets stuck in some sort of geometry, but an overall very solid game.

Dieses Spiel hat einfach eine wunderschöne Grafik ,sowie tolles Gameplay . Es besitzt Momente der Ruhe ,aber auch der Action und des Nachdenkens. Leider gab es vorallem gegen Ende einige Buggs ,wo ich das Game nochml komplett neu starten musste ,weil man ansonsten nicht weiter kam. Auch wusste man am Ende ab einem gewissen Punkt einfach nicht was man tun sollte ,weil einem kein Ziel auf der Karte angezeigt wurde und man dann ein wenig durch die Welt irrt auf der Suche nach der Aufgabe .
Nichts desto trotz ,empfehle ich dieses Game weiter an alle die Indie Adventure Liebhaber ,die auch ohne Texte und komplett durcherzählten Story zurecht kommen .
Ich hoffe das von Runic Games auch in der Zukunft noch weiter solche Titel erscheinen werden :D.

38556359.review: If you like very imaginative level design then Hob could be the perfect game for you. It doesn't have what I would describe as any set-piece boss battles, which could be a positive or a negative depending on how you feel about boss battles. The story is presented wordlessly and is pretty abstract. I thought it was OK, but pretty standard fare. But overall the amazing level design is the real highlight. You'll be going across the whole map, which is constantly evolving, multiple times. I even spent the extra time after completing the game to go back and try and find all the collectables, which is something I rarely do. Well done Runic Games, it's a real shame Hob is your last game.

38385751.review:
Bei Hob übernimmt man die Rolle eines, für meine Begriffe, androgynen Wesens. Dieses steuert sich mit Gamepad äußerst präzise und erzeugt im Big Picture Modus richtiges Konsolenfeeling.
Man erhält nach Spielstart Zugang in eine bunte, comichaft gestaltete Welt die stimmungsvoll gestaltet wurde. Zunächst einem Golem folgend erhält man nach kurzer Zeit ein Schwert und eine Powerfaust. Damit bewaffnet kann man dann das Gras in Zelda Manier niederschnippeln, morsche Büsche beseitigen um geheime Durchgänge zu finden und Monster nieder strecken. Oder poröse Mauerstücke durchbrechen. Wobei das Kämpfen eher an zweiter Stelle steht. Es gibt im ganzen Spiel keinen einzigen richtigen Bosskampf oder übermäßig schwer zu bezwingende Gegner. Vielmehr geht es darum, die Spielwelt zu erkunden und somit auf ganz „natürliche“ Art die Story zu erspielen. 

Dabei entfaltet Hob seine ganz eigene Atmosphäre. Denn es erzählt die Geschichte Non-Verbal und intuitiv.  Es gibt kein Tutorial, keine ständig nervig düdelnde Hintergrund Musik, keine Zwischensequenzen mit Dialogen oder dergleichen. Vielmehr zwitschern Vögel, die Blätter rauschen, Bäche plätschern, es fliegen Irrlichter zwischen den Bäumen umher oder es schlagen Blitze ein in unserer Nähe. Friedliche Tiere leben in dieser Welt. Der Wald wirkt mystisch und wie aus einem Fantasy Film, die Industrieanlagen bedrohlich, die Wüste karg und hoffnungslos. An bestimmten  Punkten der Map kann man innehalten und in die Weite blicken. Auf diese Weise lässt sich manches Mal erahnen, wo sich ein Versteck befindet oder wie es im nächsten Spielabschnitt aussieht, was so den Erkundungsdrang steigert.

Überhaupt muss ich sagen, dass die Entwickler die Map richtig geil hin gekriegt haben denn sie ist unglaublich gut durchdacht. Kein einziges Mal blieb ich irgendwo stecken oder dachte es geht nicht mehr weiter. Es gibt immer einen logischen Durchgang oder eine Weiterführung  in einen anderen Bereich den man finden kann. Durch das Betätigen von Schaltern heben- und senken sich ganze Abschnitte, ordnen sich diese wie Puzzleteile zusammen und vergrößern die Hob Welt somit im weiteren Spielverlauf.  Dadurch werden z. B. Spielbereiche zugänglich, die man zuvor nur in der Ferne gesehen hatte. 

Wie eingangs erwähnt erklärt das Spiel nichts. Das macht zwar den Einstieg ins Spiel etwas schwerer aber Hob erfindet auch das Rad nicht neu. Die Spielmechanik geht spontan von der Hand und prinzipielle Dinge wie das Hochleveln des Schwertes oder der Powerfaust usw. dürften die meisten Spielerinnen und Spieler heutzutage ohnehin von der Sache her aus zig anderen Spielen schon kennen. Wenn man erst einmal drin ist kann man sich herrlich in der großen Spielwelt verlieren, Geheimgänge finden und Rätsel lösen die von der Schwierigkeit in etwa auf Zelda Niveau sind. Ständiges automatisches Speichern und massig Wiedereinstiegspunkte nach dem Tod und Möglichkeiten zur schnellen Reise sorgen dafür, dass man nicht unnötig vom Spielerlebnis abgelenkt wird. 
Zuletzt bietet Hob sogar noch ein Alternatives Ende und etwas Freiraum zur Interpretation der, zugegebenermaßen etwas simplen Story. Alles in allem würde ich sagen der erste Spieldurchlauf dürfte bei den meisten circa 15-20 Stunden dauern, je nachdem wie intensiv man die jeweiligen Bereiche erkundet. 

Mal abgesehen von ein paar Mini Bugs wie einmal ein kleiner Grafik- und ein Clipping-Error lief es bei mir absolut sauber. Es hat mir unglaublich viel Spaß gemacht die Spielwelt zu erkunden und ich werde auch noch einen weiteren Durchgang machen. Daher kann ich Hob mit allerbestem Gewissen jeder Person empfehlen die ein Action Adventure mit sehr guter Atmosphäre und eher mittlerem Schwierigkeitsgrad sucht!

38385253.review:
Hello everybody, End World Gaming here to share an excerpt from my review for Hob by Runic Games.

Hob is a fantasy action adventure game. It follows an unnamed character who loses an arm to a purple alien species. His robot friend sacrifices his arm to heal the main character. The story is presented without narration or voice acting. The story unfolds as you explore the world and it’s surprising how well it does. The game focuses more on the journey and it’s a very fun one to be sure.

The world of Hob is easily one of my favorite parts of the game. While exploring you can see wild animals wandering around and some you can pet. You have complete control over the world as well and where there wasn’t land originally… Pressing a button will shift the land to reveal new areas for you to explore. This transformation system is incredibly impressive and it must have taken a lot of work in making it work so smoothly. The level design in this game is superb.

The main character will have to combat evil creatures while exploring the world as well. The combat system feels very fluid and you can easily change which direction you’re attacking. This allows you to hit an enemy in mid-attack. Not all enemies are small though, and you’ll often need to use your abilities to combat later enemies. Abilities include grapple, block, dodge, teleport, and punch. Each ability is also utilized in exploration and early in the game you won’t be able to get to most regions.

There’s also hidden objects that you can find within the world. The major ones allow you to upgrade your health, energy and sword. Your health and energy upgrade automatically but your sword must be upgraded manually. To upgrade your sword you must gather 3 pieces and then bring it back to the forge. Doing so will have the main character drop the pieces into a smelter to melt down the pieces (And previous sword) thus creating a better one. There are 4 sword levels in all.

Other hidden objects include butterflies and schematics. The butterflies have no real impact on the story. The schematics on the other hand allow you to purchase new ability upgrades. These include faster punch charging speed, a bonus attack combo and new cloak skins. The cloak skins alter your character’s stats so you should choose carefully.

Overall, Hob has been a pretty amazing game. I absolutely love the level design this game has to offer. It’s easily some of the best that I’ve seen this year. The game is also an incredibly fun game to play as well. It’s combat system is fast and fluid and it’s platforming felt great. Hob is pretty much The Legend of Zelda game you didn’t know you needed. It’s an amazing game and I can’t recommend it highly enough.

If you're interested in checking out the full review or would like to see my final score, you can find the review here: http://www.endworldgaming.com/action-adventure/hob-review

Thanks for taking the time to read the review folks and happy gaming!

38220216.review:
Hob is a mysterious experience, one that honestly should not be missed if you're a fan of an puzzle platformer that tries to immerse the player in its bewildered tale. 

The story is told through environment alone, by your actions shifting the world, exploring and by glyphs or small details placed through the world. This will surely put a lot of people off, as its hard to keep track to whats going on if you dont pay attention or rush through the world. That being said, if you do take time to learn the world, its quite a good tale, assuming I understood it correctly. It wont blow your mind, but it is quite interesting. 

Gameplay is mainly composed of platforming and puzzle solving with a bit of combat. Neither of those things are hard or annoying which was great. Camera is fixed so you will have to rely on the game to show you the environment rather than having a free look. 

Atmosphere wise, its nice and its incredible how it all fits once you start "fixing" the world. Its like a giant puzzle with shifting lands and different environments. 

Sound design is not something you'd praise, and while there is music and sound effects, they rarely make an impression, which is a shame for such a pretty world. 

Overall while the game isnt something you'd praise, it is still quite the experience. if you're a fan of the genre, buy it and if you're not I would still recommend you at least give a try, if not for the obfuscated story but at least for the atmosphere and gameplay.  8/10

Игра хороша, однозначно. 
Атмосферный, необычный механический мир. Если что-то не получается сейчас - вернитесь позже. Мир меняется по ходу прохождения. Плюс герой обретает новые способности.
Негатиные эмоции вазвала разве что странная механика защиты от случайных падений. Иногда "красная шапочка" исправно хватается за края, не позволяя упасть, даже тогда, когда тебе и надо спрыгнуть вниз. А иногда, как слепой котёнок, кидается в пропасть в самый неподходящий момент.
Ещё неприятный момент - денег на все апгрейды после полного прохождения не хватило. Собрал все обелиски и бабочек. Но осталось два плаща из достижения Наследние предков, которые я нашёл, но не смог одеть по причине нехватки зелёной валюты. Выход тут только один - побегать по карте и пофармить реснувшихся мобов.

Really liked this game. Simple, entertaining.

Short and simple story line but with loads of shit to discover, gives you enough room to enjoy the game without actually getting fed up after 2 hours. The puzzles were really fun to work out and the graphics look really nice.

Cons:
I will say controls, specially with some of the abilities. Can't remember how many times I fell down a ledge because the camera suddenly shifts angle. Can get annoying going up the stairs in weird camera angles and you the controls don't adapt to it. Also worth mentioning some bugs where you can't take energy cubes out of their place and you have to restart the game. Also would be helpful if your map kept the collectible location of what you've already collected so you wouldn't go around looking or trying to remember.

Overall I enjoyed this game very much.

38123302.review:
tldr; A gorgeous looking game, with a lovely story.  Late campaign can be frustrating after the map help suddenly drops off.  Didn't stop me finishing it, though.  Controller Required, rather than recommended.  Thumbs up.

Had my eye on this one for a while, having bought and adored the Torchlight games.  Compared to those the elements of this are quite simplistic - run, jump, hack, slash, and occasionally upgrade.  I'm not personally a fan of jumping puzzles in third-person games, but the mechanic of this one was forgiving enough that it wasn't a bind.  Little Hob is *really* good at grabbing ledges.

An oddity of the rendering meant that playin on 'medium' quality occasionally meant that important bits of graphic weren't present - primarily the 'grapple point' on the back of some mobs that lets you remove their armour.  But if you keep half an eye on the tool tips, it's clear what's possible when.

I eventually had to resort to a couple of YT videos to find the last couple of parts of the sword, and after having technically finished the game, I discovered a whole swathe of the map that I hadn't visited.  There are little nooks and crannies all over, and if there's a fault, it's far too easy to miss the pathways that lead you on to the next section of the game - you cover most of the ground three or four times anyway.

No crashing problems for me.

All in all, I can't say enough about how amazing this game, and prior Runic games are. Give em all a play! You won't regret all the time you're going to invest in them, I promise!

O jogo é bom, os gráficos são agradáveis e a arte também é interessante. A gameplay se assemelha a jogos como The Journey e um pouco de Zelda, eu diria. O jogo é 100% mudo, e não te diz nada. Você é jogado em um mundo e você tem que aprender e solucionar os problemas por si mesmo, sem ajuda, sem diálogos. O mundo é vasto e a gameplay também leva várias horas. 

Porém, há um problema: não há algo que te deixe interessado ou te motive a continuar jogando. O fato do jogo possuir uma certa ausência de história acaba criando um certo desinteresse no jogador. Não resta muito a ele a não ser andar e andar resolvendo puzzles até se cançar. Mesmo já tendo o adquirido há um tempo, não terminei o jogo ainda e nem tenho interesse em terminar. Como já disse, é apenas andar e andar. No meio do caminho há alguns monstros, e você também pode encontrar itens que dão upgrades em suas armas e habilidades.

Enfim, recomendo caso queira preencher seu tédio, mas o jogo não é "ótimo", eu diria apenas "bom",

38058229.review: 非常魔性和好玩的一款游戏，我为了它沉迷了三天单机，感恩节促销买的一堆游戏都无暇顾及。从可玩性上来讲是大好评！，观赏性一般般吧，能感觉到贴图都是非常棒的，就是每次在观赏点截图的时候发现远处画质很模糊。画质和特效已经开到极致了的说~另外是什么支撑我来写这篇测评的呢？是因为，我遇到bug了！！在水中地城那一节，两个管道中间的电磁抓取点出现了bug，无论重生还是重新开始，角色只要通过那里，按下手柄上的LB之后只会死死的抓住抓取点不放，本来应该是按离LB之后角色就下坠的，这样能够通过调整方向键跳跃到另一条管道上。但是现在抓住不放，我只能按Y来脱离，然后角色就直直的坠下去摔死了根本无法跳跃到对面。更牛逼的是，如果我摔死或是选择重生，角色会在重生存档点（距离那个抓取点十万八千里的地方）出现抓取提示，我按下LB之后角色就跟开挂了一样，嗖的就过去了！依旧死死地贴在抓取点上不放，然后周而复始。。。。现在看来我只能卸载重装了！！玩过火炬之光2，对Runic印象一直很好，包括对这作一直充满期待。但这次bug让我感觉很无奈。。差评就算了，纯粹吐吐槽。。

37907311.review:
It's a fun game, but it has some issues.

Hob reminds me of alot of games, especially 2D Zelda. There's puzzles, combat, upgrades, platforming and exploring. All these elements are fun but not amazing. The puzzles are easy and satisfying to solve, but you're for the most part just following a path pressing buttons and flipping switches. They are never as complex as actual Zelda dungeons.

The platforming is alright, but I missed being able to control the character mid air. The static camera also hinders the platforming sometimes. I liked the upgrade system, as all upgrades needs to be discovered by the player.
The world design is neat, but it never changes to drastically and sticks to a familiar style through the game. I got a bit bored of it at the end.

The game also features bugs! And they can really screw up the game as the bugs sometimes don't trigger puzzles or key functions. There where moments I didn't know the game was bugged, instead I believed I did something wrong. Or had to come back later. This can be fatal for the game experience.

37712074.review:
Remember the good old Zelda: Link to the Past? Hob feels so much like it and much better in some places.

You are a sword-like-thingy wielding creature that explores and changes the world around you. There is some combat but if you like exploring (i.e you get all the upgrades and have enough currency to buy them) combat will not be too difficult on normal difficulty. There are 2 higher difficulty settings and one lower but to me it felt very well balanced. But combat will never be just a senseless buttonmashfest. Block, evade, stun, remove enemy armor - even combat is part of the exploration/puzzle experience.

Other than that, you will be jumping, climbing, running and swimming to get to the next button, switch or lever. While there isn't much hand-holding - usually a general direction of where to go is all you get - most puzzles aren't very complex. It is a bit sad that most puzzle games devolve into 'there is a button, therefore I must push it' without giving a thought to the consequences (it's a game, something good has to happen, right?)

There is no narrative. Only the skills and updares have a short textual decription. Everything else is body language. Rather refreshing.

There were some embarrassing bugs too - fall through the world, turn lever again after puzzle completion to sink into the wall, but nothing game breaking

This game is very simple, yet every step of the way as something different gets added it becomes just that much more fun.

37652884.review:
Hob is an action-adventure game where you play as a guy who just wants to go home. Unfortunately, home is pretty far away, and many puzzles and enemies block the path. I dove into this game blind, and I definitely enjoyed it.

Hob has a very Zelda-like vibe. You play a little guy in a tunic with a pointed hat hacking at grass with a sword. Of course, you'll find no rupees here, just health. That doesn't mean there is no shopping mechanic, however. As you defeat enemies and unlock rectangular stones with glowing symbols, you gain a currency. This currency is used to upgrade the abilities you gain along the way. There is no name for the currency.

Speaking of no name for currency, there's no names given for anything other than shop items. There is no dialog. On one hand, it's pretty great for those of us who get impatient while NPCs talk forever. On the other, it can make it a little harder to figure out where you're going. 

A good example of this is when the stone golem that's been helping you motions across a large hole in the ground. You cannot jump it. You cannot fly. You probably have no idea what the big symbol in front of the gap means because you don't have that ability yet. You just know you have to get over there. You get over there by completing a different area completely first. They also won't tell you how to use your new abilities when you get them. I personally had to check the control map a couple times to figure out what I was doing. This lack of dialog can leave some people very lost for a while.

I played Hob with a keyboard and mouse, but there were a lot of times I thought "I should really use a controller for this". It works with the keyboard and mouse, but there are a lot of diagonal jumps. These jumps get a little awkward on keyboard when you're in the middle of a time-based puzzle (or if you're being impatient). They wouldn't be too bad, but you cannot change direction in the air. I found myself dying by falling off ledges more than anything (because I'm impatient). Otherwise, it feels nice control wise.

The combat in Hob in primarily done with your sword, but the other abilities you gain in your adventure can also be used. Punching a group of scorpions in the face can be quite satisfying. It also comes with a handy stun! Rolling, slashing, and punching your way through is pretty fun. Although, once you learn how certain monsters work, it can be a little on the easy side. That being said, I have been oneshot by a monster in this game. That’ll teach me for not following map markers provided by a sentient golem that doesn’t speak my language.

The puzzles usually involve moving large sections of the area. They’re not exactly Myst hard, and you won’t need to bring a notepad or calculator with you. They do make for some pretty cool sights though. Shoving an entire section of an area down to reach the other side is neat.

Overall, Hob is a nice game for people who like platformers and puzzles. It looks nice visually, combat feels good (as it should from Runic Games), and just exploring in general is pretty fun. Aside from anything mentioned above, the only real downside I can see (if you can even call it that) is that it probably isn’t for all ages. This is due to blood, violence, and some dismemberment.

37587380.review:
Not ready for prime time.  I'm only 2.4 hrs into the game and the performance/quality are fairly disappointing.  The game has crashed twice.  Textures disappear and flicker constantly as I move around the world.  Trees will lose all foliage, details on the ground will vanish then come back as the character moves around.  I'm not exploring a solid place but one where things can vanish and appear back again at any second.  It's very immersion breaking.  My computer is old (i7-3770 and Nvidia GTX 770), but exceeds the minimum requirements.  I tried turning settings down to medium, but the game just looked ugly for it; and the disappearing textures just got worse.

Otherwise the game seems fun, if not a little obtuse.  I've gotten stuck once right at the beginning in the tutorial and had to watch a YT video to figure out where to go.  Almost got stuck a 2nd time before stumbling across a place to climb.  Gameplay seems to consist of:  explore, fight some enemies, wander around looking for a way to progress, repeat.  It's something I could get into, but I think I'll have to set this aside for a few months and hope future bug fixes improve the experience.

edit:  I took opportunity of Black Friday/Cyber Monday to purchase a better graphics card which wasn't on sale.  I bought an Nvidia 1060 6GB which improved on the flashing textures somewhat, but introduced frequent stuttering and hitching of the game.  That's at 1080p and settings set to High (and vsync helped a bit).  Still, performance was disappointing.  

I've since finished the game.  It's an interesting tale, decent combat, puzzles that aren't too hard, with some rather complicated jumping.  I'm changing my review to recommended, but with steep reservations.  If you demand performance look elsewhere. If you enjoy puzzle games and exploration, and are willing to put up with sub-par performance, Hob is worth a purchase on sale.

37481057.review:
tl;dr: I recommend Hob to anyone who enjoys exploritory games with puzzel elements and love great looking games with excellent soundtracks. 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Hob is a game I've first heard about in 2015. It was one that drew me in from the amazing art work and world setting. For two years I waited for this game to come out. I played every demo I could and when I finally got to download and kick off my own adventure in Hob I was not disappointed. 

This game has an amazing atmospheric setting, great music (recommend playing with headphones), nice little momements of to relax in. 

Exploring, going down the strange path, is part of the game and rewards for traveling off the beaten path are through out the game. 

Pros:
- Amazing art
- Immersive music
- Great controls, that adapt well to increasing enemy levels
- Large content to game that seems to be nearly endless
- Responsive dev team to fixing bugs
- View points around game that are all about taking a break and enjoying the scenery
- Gradual expanding map, with excellent cut scenes

Cons:
- Dungeons are forward only solvable. One in particular had a section that you can not progress the entire game unless you pass. It's in the vein of a platformer, but can take several tries to complete and for some might be near impossible. Shame to protential gamers who get stuck at this point with no way to get past. 
- Occasionally camera angle prevents user from seeing where they are, and where they are going. Makes it very easy to fall off things. 
- Some of the story can be hard to follow

37422146.review:
My nominee for the “No Apologies” award.

Part of me thinks, if only I had written this review sooner, could I have possibly helped save Runic Games?

This is hands down one of my favorite games of 2017. The art style is unparalleled, the world building new and unique, the gameplay and clockwork game world astonishing. I loved every second of this masterpiece, and will probably return to find all of the collectibles. 

Releasing at the same time as Cuphead might have been its downfall, as it seemed everyone ignored this gem while Cuphead (deservedly) absorbed the limelight. 

The main gripe seems to be the fixed camera, but this was a very intentional design choice that is integral to the game play. It’s a minor annoyance at first, but fine once you get your head around it.

Runic Games had more talent on display in their three little gems than most triple A studios show in a decade of fatigued franchises. Their demise means there truly is no justice in this world.    

Buy this game, marvel at its genius, and give the devs some love.

37372875.review:
通关撒花，意犹未尽。
Runic Games本可以更好，再次致敬！
游戏画风简洁清新，犹如身临童话世界。
关卡设计相当考究，游戏一开始整个地图是由迷雾笼罩。玩家跟随机器人的指示逐步探索，随着解谜的深入，这幅画卷逐渐展开，游戏气势非常震撼弘大。场景是由多个可活动板块拼接，结合场景中道具的使用和机关的触发，地壳会抬起、下降和旋转，非常生动。玩家和场景互动十足，就像是造物主，负责这个世界的每一次新生。地形交错纵横，解谜难度适宜，不至于像《传送门》系列玩起来会卡关，但是短暂的思考还是需要的。
至于战斗方面，玩过魂系列的玩家还是忽略这个游戏的战斗吧。我纯粹是来解谜看风景的，个人非常喜欢这类画风，也喜欢解谜游戏，所以游戏是一口气玩通关的，而且走遍每一寸土地。说说战斗体验，游戏中的精英怪大概是5到6种的样子，怪物的攻击模式过于单一，除了一种把自己蜷成球向你滚来的精英怪之外，其他的都是拿着长柄武器一顿子轮，毫无新意。攻击动作有较长时间的后摇，给玩家充分的时间虐他？玩过魂系列的都知道，在打boss之前尽量避免高频率的战斗，保持良好的血量撸boss。然而这个游戏是：没血了？来杀几波小怪吧！没血了？来割几波草吧！瞬间满血！
游戏整体框架非常牛逼，值得一提的还是活动的大陆板块，但是通关之后给我的感觉是，游戏内容只是展现了80%，太多地方值得丰富和改进，游戏的bug还是不少的，多次因为bug无奈点击重生。
总体来说游戏值得一玩！趁着秋季特卖，买买买啊！

37332896.review: An exploration game with Metroidvania flourishes that sees you dropped into a world with no real context and left to clear it out of bad guys and some kind of creeping corruption that's fouling the place up. The action takes place both above and below ground but each part generally leads to you pulling a lever and watching massive chunks of landscape impressively spin, rise, fall, flip and generally reassemble itself into a configuration which allows you to press forward. There are collectibles which give you a number of advantages (i.e. longer health bar, new powers for your glove thing, etc) in combat but it's not a hard game at the best of times so I didn't even use some of the new powers I ended up with. The story is close to non-existent and even when I arrived without much fanfare at the ending I was none the wiser what was going on. Frankly it doesn't matter though because opening up the map and clearing out all the corruption is the main hook and it doesn't need anything else to grab you. It doesn't have the same beautifully lonely atmosphere of RIME and it's nowhere near as pretty but in some ways it's a more engaging game because it's less linear and has more stuff going on. Overall it's really good stuff and I loved the 10 or so hours it took me to finish it and open the entire map up. PSA: the performance on my PC at least was pretty ropey. It was generally fast and smooth but had blatant issues streaming in new parts of the open world as the frame rate would briefly crash through the floor with irritating regularity so maybe wait for a patch or pick up the PS4 version if it's better.

37017227.review:
9/10
整体：解密成分，探索欣赏》战斗。十分休闲的游戏。适合放松。
战斗：手感非常流畅。建议使用手柄。
画风：清新，画面唯美整体性极强，根据剧情的推进，你会发现这款游戏的魅力。
音乐：复合氛围，原声碟感受宁静。
剧情：游戏内并无太多的文字解说，但如果静下来你能体会到它所表达的用意。
整款游戏算是开放世界。前期较为线性，游戏内含较多的解密成分【个人认为比较简单，但是恰到好处】，收集要素中等，为了成就的话要稍稍努力下。

紧随主线的话会显得游戏后期比较仓促，游戏整体框架十分完善。可以看出制作组这个小团队对于这款游戏的打磨十分细心，有一些细节能看出原本的计划要丰富很多。
制作组发生的事，我表示十分难过，个人感觉如果还有时间的话，这绝对又是一款满分游戏。
感慨一下今年的沙盒休闲类游戏有点多。

顺便提一下游戏内含防呆功能。悬崖边上如果【不】按住奔跑键摔下去会自己爬上来的。

36986392.review:
I'm sorry I'm giving this game a negative review because it's got a nice concept but there are a few things that made the experience not enjoyable for me.

First off: the graphics are nice and simple and I don't really care for visuals as long as the game is fun, but the frame rate is unstable at best, even on a GTX970.

The crashes: I played this game only a couple of hours before asking for a refund and I experienced 2 crashes (both in the middle of a cutscene).

Customization: this bothers me quite a bit but I cannot fathom how a PC game does not have a keybinding option. I understand it's supposed to be played with a controller but if a keyboard and mouse option is available at least let us choose the keys we feel more comfortable using.

If they're going to solve their graphic issues and crashes I'm sure I'll buy it again, for now it's a pass, though.

36985486.review:
在对这个游戏和这家游戏工作室一无所知的情况下，仅仅凭借一个宣传视频和一段简单的介绍文字就预定了这款游戏。

最开始出现了默认调用集显的尴尬错误，导致低帧数吓退了一些玩家。

但多次更新之后，效果非常赞，无论画面、动作、解谜难度，都很投我口味，在那段时间里，这款游戏也是我截图最多的。

但游戏本身也有不少缺点，游戏虽然有地图，但可收集物品不是随着地图区域解锁而随之显示的，必须看到之后才会在地图上显示，这样的设定能更加专注剧情以及更加主动的探索地图，但与之相伴的是一旦有遗漏没收集的，后期找起来真的很累，我现在还有一只蝴蝶不知道在哪，花了至少2小时跑图一点收获没有。。。真的没力气去找了。除了可收集物品，一些二级地点，比如山洞、地穴之类的，也没能在地图上表现出来，不方便后期的全收集全成就。

游戏的教学和指引也不够完善，因为没有语言设定，主人翁的机器人导师并没有什么详尽的教学，按键看设置，指派任务时更是随手一指，随口嘟囔两句，地图随之蹦出一个任务点，最坑的一次，地图上都没再有点，直接导致我不知道下一步干嘛，卡了好几个小时，半睡半醒的跑图找任务。。。

但总的说来，这款游戏还是我今年入手的最满意的一款游戏，也最愿意推荐给他人的游戏。

36890742.review:
There's just something about Hob. I'm a crotchety old goat at the best of times, frequently overly critical of games - but this one has that rare quality of delivering me directly to my childhood. A sense of wonder, or the beauty of simplicity? I don't know what it is, but Hob has it. Despite not sharing much in terms of gameplay, it reminds me of Bastion in some ways.

It isn't for everyone, however. The most commonly-cited criticisms are broadly correct; the basic combat, thin plot, and linearity are all valid complaints. If you don't like Zelda games, and aren't taken by the graphical style and general game environment, Hob probably isn't worth your time. Although I must've fallen to my doom dozens of times in completing it, the game could easily be described as being quite casual, if only due to how simple it is. Go here, unlock this piece of environment with your power glove, beat these enemies - rinse and repeat.

However, it's how the familiar formula is delivered that makes the game shine. Everything about the world of Hob conveys a lush beauty that is rarely seen in smaller games like this one. I found myself staying at the various 'vistas' in the game for no reason other than to savour the view. See above...your mileage may vary, but I found the game world to be compelling in all the right ways. Even the way the grass moved captivated me, as ridiculous as that sounds - the animation really is superb across the board, with no wonky physics to be seen. The minimal, poignant soundtrack also does a good job of bolstering the sense of discovery and purity (for lack of a better word), as well as helping you empathise with your avatar at key moments.

The world is sprawling, but cut into neat sections that you unlock as you progress. This is somewhat linear, but that isn't always a terrible thing. Hob is an example of linearity done well, dressed up in a tux and obscured by the shifting environment. It isn't as simple as 'go here, do this thing', despite what I said above - the environment sees to that. FFX did linearity (mostly) right, while FFXIII got it wrong. Hob falls into the former camp, I feel. The combat is going to feel pretty basic to most people in a post-SoulsBorne gaming landscape, but it's serviceable and offers a sense of progression via weapon upgrades that alter combos slightly, and so forth. Nothing goundbreaking, but I didn't find it grating.

Give Hob a shot. It's a sad state of affairs that Runic has now closed down, but this is a fine game to leave as their parting gift - it's clearly made with a lot of passion, despite the flaws. 2017 has been a bit of a rollercoaster for gaming so far, and shockingly Hob is one of the most enjoyable games I've played this year, despite the heavy competition. Far be it from me to dictate how people game, but I feel that approaching it in the right way will help a lot - leave cynicism (mostly!) at the door and step into the lush greenery with an open mind. Hob doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it sure looks and feels fantastic to experience.

作为一个探索类游戏，Hob已经合格了。
但是也只能算合格，就是全价买了不算太亏的级别。
细节上的缺点很多，包括从头到尾几乎没变过的难度，剧情单薄，掉帧等等。。。（就是那个高票差评里的那些问题
我主要加一些我自己的感受：
真正让hob让我觉得不怎么样的原因，是因为荒野之息。
较为相似的游戏方式（虽然hob是伪开放式）、画面风格、背景设定。。。
以及，两个游戏都把任务列表做得极其精简，hob甚至到了根本就只有路点的地步（其实这个设置挺不错的）。
荒野之息能让你解完谜题/打完boss战后让你感到“这个设置得真是巧妙”、“终于把这里通过了”
hob却是“我怎么就过了”、“这怪怎么就跪了”
甚至游戏结束时你都感觉到“怎么就完结了？？？”
给人感觉是生怕玩家通不了关。。。哪怕直接把四大知识神殿加入主线剧情都好，或者把清除感染物的地方加个boss也好。。。
不过这样对看风景玩家就不是很友好了hhh
=================分割线=================
总的来说，如果你这类游戏接触得不多，尤其是在没玩过荒野之息的情况下，这个游戏还是很不错的，全价入也不亏。
玩过的话。。。趁打折入一个拿来放松下心情也可以。
以前玩过火炬之光的话。。。那资磁一下不好吗hhh

-Puzzles, mainly involving environmental manipulation.
-Good hidden places/items for completionists.
-Interesting method of narrative (no dialogue).
-Beautiful art style and music.
-Immersive world (draws you into wanting to understand the quest).

Cons:

-Some language used to describe upgrades/powerups.  I would have preferred a commitment to no language.
-Quest objectives frequently unclear due to lack of description. Makes you wonder how far into development they decided on the "no dialogue/description" shtick.
-Platforming made annoyingly difficult by shitty camera placement (it's not locked to your character).
-Gameplay sub-par to similar titles (combat is a little janky, often difficult to orientate character due to weird camera).

36417872.review: I just completed Hob and thought I would leave a review. Right off the bat, I have to say I really enjoyed my little adventure, of about, 15 hours of gameplay. I'm giving this a 7.5/10. It dropped points for a few reasons. First, it is a tiny bit glitchy... I got stuck in the environment six or seven times where I had to respawn, which was a little annoying, but don't let that put you off. Also, even though the visual style is great, there was nothing really new in terms of gameplay, nothing you haven't already seen in games before, and it even 'literally' borrowed a few mechanics from other games; for example, if you're low on health, be sure to cut the grass and spawn some health (I'm sure you've done that in another popular game). It also drops in framerate on occasion and gets quite chuggy in places. I have a powerful PC too, so if you have a low spec PC, you might want to try it out first. The final thing is a little more feedback would have helped. I got stuck a few times and founf myself wandering, not sure what to do next, but these are minor things in the overall experience. All in all, it's a great little game, quite a large world in which to explore and play, great (dynamic) level design, lots of collectables and a nice character upgrade system. Thanks...

36259528.review: Hob is a fantastic game boasting highly detailed environments, imaginative creature designs, and story telling that is VISUAL. The creators at Runic Games understand "show don't tell," and Hob does it. Probably the strongest statement I can make about Hob is that it does not have any major flaws for me, at least in terms of art and story. The story is simple and it works, there are questions that are never answered, but nothing that feels forced, awkward, or that logically breaks the story. The designs are consistent, the world is vibrant, and the puzzles are familiar to the genre of puzzle-games yet always have the unique "Hob" perspective. Some of the most challenging puzzles for me involved getting up to a ledge I could see, but could not reach, or finding a safe path down to a lower level. A lot of games can't manage the basics, but for me Hob shows just how important the basics are. Hob also features a new world design that I have never seen in any other game. The world of Hob is the most developed character in the game and it hides suprises around every corner. I have played this game for over 20 hours and I think there still might be some corner hidden away that I have not managed to find. I hope the devs will not leave this gem alone. DLC, or even a sequel would be fantastic, especially since there are enough blank spaces in the world map to add new content in the future. For now I will give Hob an enthusiatic 10/10. Buy Hob.

36250764.review: This game had flown under my radar until it was released and I read a glowing review on Eurogamer.  They likened it to Zelda, which firmly caught my attention.  So without hesitation I downloaded and started playing.  I'm very glad I did!  The world is like one great big Zelda dungeon complete with labrynthine puzzles that intricately link together.  I felt "stuck" on occasion, but I really just had to sit back and think logically about where I can probably go next and look for hints built into the world.  Solving some of the puzzles was definitely rewarding and not overly frustrating.  The game isn't perfect though, as you get severe frame rate stuttering as you transition from area to area.  (It's presumably loading in the background.)  It gets even worse if you Alt-Tab to other apps and come back to the game.  It's like memory gets all fragmented making the stuttering even worse.  If that happens, just save and exit, and it should be much better when you start fresh.  I thought the game was the right length, but after finishing it I wanted to keep playing.  Aside from simply playing it again you have the option to keep looking for hidden secrets you missed.

36191394.review:
[i]This is the game I've been waiting for since I was a wee lad![/i]

With a world that you explore changes and transforms as you experience it, giving ample variations of the world you thought may be set in stone (often literally). You know those little mechanical details you used to see in games and films? Well they actually do something here.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
Great fun to explore and to play. Often games seem to be one [b]or[/b] the other, but in Hob there's plenty to explore and to interact with. From the strange and cute wildlife (which you may cuddle or dice as you please) to crab-like mechanical platforms that even send the baddies fleeing in terror.

This game also boasts some of the best level design I've ever seen, which ties in with the exploration and puzzles brilliantly. But it's also far more vertical than you might assume from looking at the screenshots, and you'll often get to look over cliff faces to find there's something ahead/below. You might get stumped or lost for a moment, but their little visual cues and overall planning prevents frustration. The game rewards backtracking, which is especially useful once the world shifts or a new ability is unlocked. And there is an immersive fast travel system which you can use too.

It's also visually unique, having the look of a comic come to life. I feel like I'm playing in and with the concept art for games I grew up playing as a child. And I love the mesmerising soundtrack too - which sneaks out of the ambience nicely and emphasises discoveries. I just wish it'd be playing a bit more often.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
Despite the simple style (which is not a bad thing), the game is quite demanding and can lag at times. To their credit, the developers are constantly improving the game; but the framerate often drops drastically - most commonly when the camera pans up for some cinematic views, or peers down to reveal the depths of the game; which I assume is from loading masses of content at once.

I hope the developers will find a way to improve pre-loading (perhaps by using more RAM) to prevent this. I'm sure that it will also ease the strain on the GPU, allowing less powerful devices to run the game (my Laptop for example, which only has integrated graphics, but a powerful CPU and plenty of RAM).

Other than that, nothing really bothers me about the game... apart from creatures/enemies occasionally [i][b]*poof*[/b][/i] out if existence for seemingly no reason (they're not self terminating due to getting stuck).

[h1]Overall[/h1]
It may be a little demanding, but Hob is the most fun I've had in a long time.

I hardly ever get to sit down and play for over an hour with all the projects I have going... and I just spent 3 in a row with my eyes wide and a smile on my face.

Need I say more?

[h1]9/10[/h1]
[i](I look forward to giving the last point, once performance has improved)

36184358.review:
I purchased Hob mostly based on the reasonable launch price-point of $20 and amazing experience with Torchlight 1 & 2.

I admit I went into this game confused as to what the game was about, not knowing much more than "The art looks neat, and apparently ther'es a mechanical arm you can upgrade."  Unfortunately after several very confusing hours of play, and trying to come back to this game several times, I still can't tell you what the game is about or much more than "it looks neat, and there's a mechanical arm you can upgrade."  Sadly, I've also lost all motivation to continue.

The underlying vision of this game appears to be centered around explorarion and adventure, where everything about the game is expressed in a non-verbal way.  The game deliberately avoids having any UI, button prompts, tutorials, direction, waypoints, or goals.  While that type of minimal-ui visual communication can be a fantastic tool for creating imersive gameplay, a significant portion of the time I was left quite confused, and I believe deliberately so.

Throughout my experience, if felt like everything in the game lacked purpose.  You hit buttons because there exists a button, so you should probably hit it, but it's never communicated why we're doing anything in the game, what our goal(s) are, or what we're supposed to do next.  Unfortunately most of my time with this game was spent wandering aimlessly, trying to figure out where to go next. 

I hope to see more great work from this studio, and their $20 launch prices is amazing for what they deliver, but I felt this game fell flat.  Perhaps they'll put my $20 towards making another game that I'll enjoy, but I won't be blindly purchasing their next game based on reputation alone.
