36181420.review:
[h1] Hob Souls: Prepare to Die Edition[/h1]

It is at times like these that not only did I wish there were more comprehensive recommendation option, neutrals, caveats and all, but also a more generous refund window - perhaps even an extra hour ought to be sufficient. I only hope that based off what I have written on this game - and not what I had to click in order to post the review - people will be able to understand just one person's experience with this game. 

Based off of early footage, it would have been fair to assume that Hob would be a zen puzzle game. The setting appeared to pay tribute to the likes of Miyazaki and Studio Ghibli, whilst the art assets and sound design all appeared to build upon the signature Runic style, which is to say, a team heavily influenced by their experience with Blizzard, but with a Promethean flair about them. To say that the Torchlight series was anything other than an indie candle which was lit from the inferno of Diablo and WoW would be optimistic. The game's prized [i]ember[/i] says all that needed to be said there. However, it wouldn't be fair to Runic, who did after all work to the best of their means to keep their vision alive, and it paid off for them, and all the loyal players who came to warm themselves by Runic's captured heat. 

It was a source of pain then, when I drew too close to Hob, chargrilled atop Runic's writhing flames. What I had hoped for was another quirksome puzzle game with a few twists, a unfolding narrative, and a creative game world with crisp mechanics and feedback that made progress intuitive and rewarding. In other words, I was hoping for a more spacious and open-ended S-xy Brutale. What I got instead, was a 3D platformer.

Et tu Runic

My desire to keep my experience as fresh and unspoiled actually left me ignorant as to the game's core operation. I could see why the store page brought with it such a strong suggestion to bring with it a controller. Imagine if one might, the agony of navigating down slippery platforms barely exceeding the width of the dainty protagonist with WASD. The scenery - whilst at first inviting due to it's alien and abstract geometry, becomes lethal and trecherous as only one might expect from decrepit abstract ledges in advanced states of ruin. How ironic. 

It is actually possible to fall off platforms within barely a hair's bredth of error when least expected. After a while of traversing the terrain with minimal difficulty, it may well be possible to blunder into certain death half a dozen ways. I've been oneshot by a troll's club down a narrow chokepoint where the camera is obscured by foliage, I've slipped off a low wall and instanty died after landing on a cactus, and falling into the abyss after holding the line straight with the D key (no wobbly adjustments with a joystick involved). Perhaps my least favourite are the frequent occasions where the feeble character will drop off a ledge and plummit only 30ft or less to result in a torrent of blood. A grizzly, if predictable outcome for us mortals, but quite the contrary to how generous every other platformer from Banjo Kazooie to Mario has always been. I loathe platformers, yet even I was astonished by just how greasy and unforgiving fairly innocent platforms appeared. The novelty wore off bloody fast. 

Clipping has also continued to be an issue in the game. The occasional moment of being lodged in place between two or more objects in the game has been an infrequent, if vexing experience. A cruel fate which even the QA testers of the game must have raised hell over, for avoiding a game ending bug such as comes from getting trapped in the scenery, is the only reason the respawn option in the main menu exists. After all the energy spent on crafting Hob's world - and the world is very pretty - I can sympathise with Runic's solution to the bug, even if as cynical patches go, it's a devilishly funny one. 

Combat plain sucks. Beneath appearances, the core combat functionality is no different to Torchlight's method of click to win. The difference is that at least with Torchlight, the player's avatar could take a hit, and had limited, if sparkly abilities to cast. Hob has a bit of brass, and sure doesn't look like the little slugger ought to be capable of hauling around that impressive robot arm of his. The little guy has limbs that make spaghetti look like seqouia, and he's just as squishy as would be expected. The truth is, I think everybody could have done without combat in Hob. Finding creative ways to evade and defeat the zerg creep would have been enough, without having chittering goblins and those wretched cowards who toss infinite exploding slugs into cramped arenas. They're just the worst. Unlike the obnoxious platforms however, the mobs can be spanked into submission with Hobs aforementioned brass cudgel. It takes a while, but being able to trick mobs into launching themselves into hazards brings the occasional mirth, and after wrestling with the controls, mirth is very much needed. 

Oh, and whilst I remember, the fact that the keys cannot be rebound is sinful. Runic overlooked one of the essentials of game design. That's a paddling right there, with a dinky brass bat. 

Well thank you very much for reading this far. Please don't make the same mistake that I did. Invest in a controller. As pleasing as the world it to the eye, it's still a trecherous one, and even with a stick, expect to die a hundred silly ways. When all is said and done, it's possible to hug a sugar glider-rabbit hybrid. That's a teeeen outta teeeen right there. Know what you're in for, be safe, and please don't let the world stress you out.

36177598.review:
This has the potential to be a fantastic game, but it's plagued by a couple major issues. 

---Negatives---

- There are puzzles in this game, but most of the time it felt like I was just running around looking for something that I missed or following environmental queues like a trail of bread crumbs. Very rarely does the game clearly show you what your objective should be, so you are left looking for something to hop onto or looking for a path that you missed. The puzzles that are done well feel fantastic and are very satisfying to complete. I would have liked to have the game zoom in on the objective when entering a new area, then I have a direction to work towards. That small change would already make the game a lot more engaging. 

- Camera angles are good, but not great. Too many times I was left wanting to move the camera manually in order to move my character around. The game does a good job 90% of the time, but the other 10% took me out of the game. 

- Combat is not engaging or challenging. Movement in this game is fast enough relative to the enemies that it's not necessary to fight anything unless required to move on. When I do have to fight enemies I find myself mashing X and occasionally dodging an attack or two. Enemy variety was extremely low and I was disappointed that they did not significantly change upon entering a new area. I would have liked to see quicker enemeis with more varied attacks to match the protagonist. 

- Upgrades are not substantial enough. I didn't feel compelled to get many of the upgrades because they just weren't that useful. The only upgrade I was excited to get was the green cloak which allowed me to move quicker. Combat upgrades saw very little use in my playthrough as I rolled my way through most enemies. 

- Performance is inconsistent. I was regularly dropping a large number of frames at medium settings with a GTX 1070 @1440p. It didn't prevent me from finishing the game, but it was annoying at times. 

---Positives---

+ The artwork is amazing, as you can probably tell from the previews. You can really sink into the charming world as it transforms, and boy does it transform. 

+ Hob does a great job of showing you the story and how to play instead of outright telling you. This might be annoying to some new players, but you quickly catch on. 

+ The controls in this game are well done. The character is easy to control and platforming is enjoyable, which I can't say about most 3D platforming games. New abilities are implemented well and gradually introduced in the way they should.

+ Save points are frequent and generally in a useful spot. I only ran into trouble with these when I was backtracking to previous areas. 

+ The map does a good job of letting you know what you missed, where you should be going, and even providing hints at how to access specific areas. 

---Closing Thoughts---

There is an amazing game hidden inside Hob that could be revealed if a couple major flaws are fixed, but as it currently stands I cannot recommend this game.

36130239.review:
If you enjoy games like Zelda, Journey, Tomb Raider, and Okami - there's a very good chance you'll love Hob.

Gameplay 4/5
- combat 4/5
- platforming 3/5
- puzzles 5/5
- exploration 5/5
Art 5/5
Music and Sound 4/5
Story 3/5

Overall: 4/5


I feel compelled to write a review for Hob because I really loved it and I hope a lot of other people will try it and love it too.  If you've played Journey and felt moved by it, or have played a Zelda game and enjoy exploration, environmental puzzles and fluid combat then you're going to really have fun with Hob.  I've read many online reviews and the Metacritic scores just don't do it justice.  It's not a perfect game, but it really is fun and worth your time and money.

Hob is the kind of game that doesn't bore you with tutorials or backstory.  It plops you into its world and lets you explore.  The best way to play is to simply let your intuition and curiosity guide you.  The game does a great job of giving you waypoints so that if you get lost or bored exploring, you have a general sense of where to go and what to do next.  This game can be a very relaxed, zen-like experience, but there's enough mystery, puzzles and combat to keep things entertaining.  I personally feel you should just go where curiosity leads you and enjoy how solving puzzles transforms the landscape and opens up or changes the world.

As far as gameplay goes, Hob shines brightest with its fun environmental puzzles that unlock, change or move portions of the world around.  It's like the world itself is composed of this giant, living puzzle, and to progress, you figure out how to unlock it.  For the most part, the puzzles are fairly straightforward.  There were a few times that I spent maybe 10 minutes wondering exactly how I could get to a certain location, or how a puzzle worked.  Only once or twice did I almost check the Internet for help; but I didn't, and I'm glad I didn't have to.  

The combat at first is a bit limited.  I kind of wish you could unlock some of the cooler elements earlier in the game so that everyone could enjoy teleporting through enemies and stunning them, or using the glove to knockback enemies.  When you combine the simplistic elements together you can actually create little combos and facing large groups becomes very enjoyable.  So my advice here is to upgrade your sword and your glove as soon as you can and don't forget to keep upgrading as you go.  Because it's not "necessary" it can be easy to forget, but it's well worth it.

Platforming is a little frustrating at times.  I feel like that's one area where the game could be improved.  The character sometimes feels "floaty" and not anchored to the world.  If they could get the physics of landing jumps and grabbing ledges the way the Tomb Raider games are able to, this game would be that much closer to perfect.  Even though you'll miss your share of jumps, it's by no means terrible and with all the well placed save points and lack of any real death penalty, it's no big deal anyway.

The world itself is incredibly beautiful and the art and level design group should be praised.  Animations are lovely.  Even ambient wildlife is beautifully animated and fun to watch and "pet".  I absolutely love that the developers allow you to pet animals.  I have wanted to do that in games since forever and it's a lovely touch.  Anyone who appreciates beautiful level design or who loves cell shaded style worlds should play this game just to appreciate how absolutely gorgeous it is.

The story in Hob is interesting and its mysteries are compelling enough to make you want to see how it all ends.  I enjoyed that there are multiple endings; although, it would've been nice to have a little more reason to choose between them.  In my opinion, there's not a compelling enough argument for one of them.  All that said, the story is somewhat light and I would've loved to have learned a bit more about some of this world's inhabitants and more of the backstory behind it; even if that was through pictograms or some other non-verbal method.

The game did feel a little short, but that said, I somehow managed to spend 30 hours playing it.  Yes, you can rush through it, but this is a game that you should just take your time and savor. I really hope that Runic adds some DLC to expand on those foggy gray areas on the upper left side of the map; and if not, I hope they consider making a sequel.  Games like Hob are some of my favorites and it feels like they only come along once in a while.  Thanks for your hard work team Runic!

36024659.review:
Développé par le studio Runic Games , Hob est un jeu d'action aventure dans la droite lignée des derniers zelda. Là où on attendait un Torchlight 3, Runic Games a donc fait fi des demandes de ses fans pour tenter une expérience ludique singulière et originale. Point de narration chiante dans Hob, son histoire se dévoilera sans paroles et sans GPS et autres points de contrôles obligatoire. On incarne donc une créature qui va devoir tenter de sauver son monde d'une drôle d'infection qui transforme tout ce qu'elle touche en créature malfaisante ou pire qui vous tue à petit feu. Après avoir été touché, notre personnage sera sauvé par un robot tout droit échappé de son usine et qui va sacrifier son bras pour nous sauver. Après une courte convalescence, on va vote comprendre que ce bras va nous permettre de nous défendre et d'explorer un monde en mouvement constant grâce à ses capacités.

Hob est un jeu spécial et qui fait une très forte impression dans ces 4-5 premières heures de jeu. On comprend qu'il va falloir se débrouiller seul pour avancer et que seul notre sens aiguisé de l'observation ainsi que notre curiosité naturelle nous permettra de découvrir des passages secrets et autres éléments nécessaire à l'avancée de l'histoire. En gros, il va falloir explorer les différents niveaux à la recherche de petites créatures nous permettant d'éradiquer d'une zone l'infection. Ce ne sera pas toujours possible de prime abord et il faudra parfois avancer ailleurs pour débloquer une nouvelle compétence comme le fouet afin d'accéder à des zones inaccessibles auparavant. Forcément, attendez vous à faire pas mal d'aller retours dans le jeu mais sachez qu'il est possible de faire la navette entre différents centre de téléportation dont celle de notre base principale où on pourra upgrader notre gant et acquérir de nouvelles améliorations diverses.

Fistiland, au fond du fun!
Si le jeu fait tout pour que l'on se sente seul dans un univers hostile et délabré, on y fera pas mal de rencontres plus ou moins amicales. Hob fait également la part belle aux combats avec un système simple mais au final très efficace. Notre gant nous permettra de frapper nos adversaires, de leur faire perdre leur garde ou alors d'enlever des bouts d'armures pour que l'on puisse espérer les toucher. Ajoutez également un bouclier et vous obtenez presque toute la panoplie d'un Zelda! Il faudra aussi utiliser une sorte d'épée upgradable en trouvant du métal rare et retournant à la forge de départ. Celle-ci est efficace mais elle nécessitera souvent d'être très mobile et d'attaquer avec un bon timing car elle dispose également d'animations lentes et qui vous laisserons à la merci d'un contre bien senti des ennemis. Si l'on tape sur un mur par exemple, notre personnage reculera pendant quelques secondes le temps de gérer l'impact ce qui nous obligera à se battre dans des endroits pas trop exigus. Il est également possible de faire tomber ses adversaires avec le poing en chargeant son attaque pendant quelques secondes ce qui aura comme désavantage de nous laisser immobile et donc vulnérable.

J'ai apprécié les combats dans Hob mais ils sont tout de même assez simplistes et redondant vers la fin du jeu. Le challenge n'est clairement pas dans les combats car on est rarement débordé par le nombre de nos ennemis et qu'il est assez simple de se focaliser sur les faibles avant de se retourner vers les forts. Autre point intéressant, les ennemis peuvent se toucher entre eux ce qui peut nous aider à gérer des situations cocasses en les faisant s'entretuer avec un achievement à la clé. En gros, on meurs bien plus souvent en chutant lamentablement dans les décors qu'au combat et c'est un peu dommage. On est très rarement mis en danger et seuls quelques combats spécifiques offrent un peu d'adrénaline et des sueurs froides; c'est d'ailleurs dommage d'avoir le meilleur combat dans une des 2 fins possibles... Frustrant.

Avec une carte, tout est plus simple.
Dans Hob, le monde évolue au fur et à mesure de vos actions. Les niveaux ont une géographie variable et activer des mécanismes fera monter et descendre des morceaux du monde pour vous libérer le passage vers de nouvelles zones à explorer. C'est grâce à la carte incluse dans le jeu que l'on va comprendre que tout est finalement assez linéaire et qu'il faudra souvent aller d'un point A vers un point B pour déverrouiller un nouveau mécanisme. On y trouvera également les secrets ainsi que les zones de téléportation et autres upgrades. A vous donc de vous faire votre propre chemin et de lire la carte pour y trouver votre prochain objectif, celui-ci peut être indiqué directement sur la carte mais il vous suffira simplement d'aller là où se trouve les robots géants pour y trouver les créatures pour permettant de 'fister' la créature responsable de l'infection de la zone. Au pire vous risquez de vous retrouver bloquer 1 heure en tout pendant les 12 heures nécessaires pour terminer le jeu en ayant débloquer les 2 fins.

Il y a énormément d'inventivité dans l'univers de Hob. Les monstres sont sympathiques et les décors de toute beauté. On prend un réel plaisir à explorer cet univers et à tenter de débloquer le plus de secrets possible et à aller chercher la petite bête nous permettant de terminer le jeu à 100%. La durée de vie du jeu est excellente à la vue du prix demandé, ajoutez à cela une bande son vraiment au top par le génial Matt Uelmen dont Gamekult a fait une brillante interview il y a peu. Tout n'est hélas pas parfait dans Hob, loin de là. Sur ma configuration, j'ai eu toutes les peines du monde à le faire tourner convenablement (Geforce 1070, i5 et 16Go de RAM) avec énormément de soucis de ralentissements inexplicables. Cela ne m'a pas empêché de passer du bon temps et de m'amuser mais il a fallu énormément de mises à jour pour venir à bout du problème et j'avais terminé le jeu depuis bien longtemps. Rajoutez à cela une maniabilité pas toujours évidente dans les combats et dans les sauts et vous obtenez des défauts gênants mais pas rédhibitoires pour autant. Comme expliqué plus haut, j'ai eu énormément de morts dues à ma profonde maladresse et c'est assez frustrant. Jamais assez pour vous faire ragequit le jeu mais assez pour nécessiter des temps de pause.


Some people just want to watch the world evolve.
Hob est une assez bonne surprise avec son côté très coloré et son ambiance au top. Si le gameplay est assez basique et que le challenge n'est pas forcément au rendez-vous, on se surprend à apprécier les moments calmes et contemplatifs que nous propose le jeu par le biais d'endroits spéciaux où l'on peut admirer le décor tranquillement. Les puzzles ne tritureront pas vos neurones et l'on avance à bon rythme dans le jeu sans mal. Hob est presque un jeu plus sympathique à regarder qu'à jouer en y réfléchissant un peu mais cela reste tout de même un beau coup de coeur me concernant. J'ai beaucoup apprécié l'univers proposé et les possibilités offertes par notre gant et notre arme. Le jeu fourmille également de petits détails et autres attentions aux éléments du décor qui forcent le respect. Pour peu que vous aimiez les jeux indépendants originaux qui s'éloignent du metroidvania-like et que aimiez l'exploration, Hob constitue un excellent passe temps et se trouve être une belle expérience à vivre même à plein tarif!

36021848.review:
Hob is the latest title from Runic Games, the developers of Torchlight 1 & 2. Set in a half organic, half machine world, it’s a wordless action/adventure game filled with exploration, light combat and mild puzzles. Drawing inspiration from titles such as Zelda, Ico and Shadow of Colossus (maybe even a bit of Metroid?), Hob takes things from each game and then adds its own spin on top of them while offering up a couple of new ideas in the process. After a friendly robot names Jeeves seemingly wakes you up to a partially deconstructed planet being taken over by an unknown life form, you start on a journey to get the world back to the way it was, all while finding out a bit more about what happened while you were slumbering.

After spending around 30 hours playing the game twice (average playtime seems to be around 10 hours) and spending almost another 35-40 (offline, so i wouldn't be forced to update) just running around exploring and taking screenshots, i can safely say Hob has become one of my favorite games of all time. Even after spending all those hours getting to know the game world pretty thoroughly, i still crave more. While playing, and even afterwards, the feeling of one more thing waiting to be discovered was always present. And i don’t just mean normal gameplay type things (like a new upgrade, story revelations or a brand new area), i also mean things like little spots on the map you haven’t made it to yet, or maybe new paths to objectives you never realized were right in front of you. And this, to me, is why Hob is such a special game. The world, and the characters that inhabit it, are so full of detail, mystery and charm, you can’t help but want to explore and experience every last thing the game has to offer, big or small. Runic Games has utterly succeeded in creating an unique, intriguing and atmospheric world that just begs to be discovered. I never got tired of trying to reach a new vantage point just to take in the beautiful views or scouring the different areas looking for the subtle environmental storytelling.  

I found Hob to be a great mix of exploring, puzzles, combat and platforming. The level design is amazing, always keeping things fresh and interesting. The way the world moves and shifts as you complete objectives is so satisfying. Even small things, like creating steps out of the side of a wall, are moments of joy. The puzzles aren’t difficult yet they offer a light challenge and a nice change of pace. The combat, while simple, is enjoyable and gets even better once you unlock some of your upgrades (the charge/ground punch that blows apart enemies is especially gratifying). A few of these upgrades also enhance your movement, making traveling around the planet easier, quicker and all around more fun. The platforming can also be quite engaging (and even intense at times), however the fixed camera angle (it’s mostly from a top down perspective) got me killed on a few occasions. This is one of the two things i would change about the game if i could. The ability to have a camera i could control would be priceless. Not only for gameplay reasons, but also so i could view this gorgeous game from different perspectives. I almost feel the fixed camera does the game a disservice by limiting what you can see of it, and i desperately want to see it all! Even a first person look around mode would be hugely appreciated. While i can understand one of the reasons for it (to make the player feel small and world feel big) it comes at the cost of a bit of mystery, since you know what’s around almost every corner before you get there. The other thing i would change is the fall damage. It’s a bit too restricting in my opinion, especially for a game that wants you to explore and has lots of potentially fun cliffs you could jump off of.

Visually, the game is a dazzler. I fell in love with the art style the very first time i saw it and love it even more now after completing the game. The attractive colors, the way the cloud shadows roll across the ground, the gently blowing grass that realistically moves as you walk through it. These all help pull you into the world of Hob. Throw in top notch animation, tons of passionately crafted details (like all the animals that help make the world feel alive, the tiny sprite creatures who watch you curiously, and the wavy wind gusts that streak across the screen) and add a moody and relaxing soundtrack and you get quite a magical experience.

I did run into a few glitches during my playthroughs (like falling through a few walls and disappearing water), but nothing too bad. The developers have been hard at work listening to feedback and constantly patching the game though, so i’m confident most/all of the bugs will be ironed out quickly, if they haven’t been fixed already.

At $20 Hob is a steal. The fun and quality you get for that price is crazy. I think they could have asked $30-35 easily and that would have been more than fair. But at the same time, i’m glad they set it at a lower price point if that means more people are able to experience this wonderful title. It definitely exceeded all my expectations and i hope and pray one day we’ll get another game set in the brilliant world of Hob. Highly highly recommend.  

Huge thanks to Runic Games for the review copy.

Amazing game, stunning visuals with gameplay that makes you want to finish the game in one sitting.

BUT.
It's hard to follow. The quest starts are like trying to find a needle in a haystack. In the sense that the needle actually has very thin thread tied to it but is prone to snapping when you tug too hard on it. Then the hunt begins. Over. And over.

Yes, I know, It's a puzzle game. It’s a mystery novella wrapped in a video game. But throw me a friggin bone! if I spend an hour running around with no direction or hint as to what I am supposed to do, it becomes very unrewarding. At the point of 2 hours of running around you sort of ‘forget’ what your goal was for the game. I’m now more likely to close the game and find something else to do. That’s not cool. :(

In short I just wish there was more cues to help along the flow of the story. Maybe have the sprites more involved more to give hints.

[b]TL;DR[/b] I'll recommend this game for its strong focus towards exploration, its puzzles and environment design.
[b]Slightly longer answer:[/b]
Its story is mainly told trough gestures and environment, which makes it easy to miss.
But if you explore the world a bit more there is a lot to discover and collect. And it will help you to understand the story a bit more.

What is the world of Hob filled with might you ask. Animals, a lot of them, and some enemies.
There isn’t a lot of variety in enemy types you will encounter and combat isn’t a strong suit either.
But it is functional and does its job well enough.
You can collect new ability’s and upgrade them as needed; this does not only help you in combat but also brings new ways to explore the world.
Also you will find a lot of puzzles thought the cause of the game nether of them are to complex, this adds to the overall relaxed atmosphere. Speaking of there are only a few instance of hurry, be sides combat.

You might like the game if:
[list]
[*]You someone how likes to explore.
[*]You like to collect stuff.
[*]You like environment base puzzles.
[*]You like piecing a story together and might never find out how close you are too the developer intended story. At least in game.
[/list]

You might not what to pick up this game if:
[list]
[*]You can’t live without bosses too defeat.
[*]You can’t live without a difficulty of Dark Souls.
[*]You are unsatisfied with the graphical appearance.
[/list]

35933334.review:
The Good: Great visuals and amazing music. Combat is challenging but fun - it's kind of like Zelda crossed with Dark Souls, because you have to time your attacks carefully and dodge the enemy attacks. Exploration is rewarding - tons of collectible upgrades to find. The puzzles in the dungeons are mostly clever and interesting, and the dungeons themselves are always well-designed and look cool. The design of the world is really impressive too, with different areas and obstacles and creatures to encounter.

The Bad: The movement can be a bit frustrating at times, as the game uses a fixed camera so you sometimes will jump expecting to land in one position and you'll end up falling or landing somewhere else. The story is difficult to follow at times because there's no dialogue - everything is conveyed by the characters pointing and gesturing - and sometimes I had no idea WHY I was going somewhere, I was just following the marker on the map. The map also doesn't show dungeon entrances, and since dungeons contain collectibles it's very difficult to find them later and collect 100% of the items.

Overall this is a very good game and I would highly recommend it for anyone who likes ARPGs with a focus on the Action, like Zelda, Dark Souls, or Torchlight.

35931399.review:
In my recent increase of interest and love for platformer games, I discovered Hob. Great visuals, amazing music and the joy of exploration makes this a great game!! As you keep exploring, you understand the world and its mechanics and that is what will help you solve the puzzles. This game absolutely tells you nothing except where to go and at times it gets frustrating because the paths are well hidden, but its all worth it at the end.

The first thing that caught my eye was the art style, absolutely stunning!! There are spots where you can sit and just enjoy the view, there were times when i just sat there for minutes.
For an indie game and at this price, it sure is a long game(which is great!!). Money well spent. :)

The one thing i hate about this game is how bad the optimization is. The frame rate drops are the biggest pain in the a**. I have a Gtx 970 and yet this game fails to give me a proper 60fps most of the times even at the lowest settings. I believe this is a issue with majority of the players. The good thing is that the developers are working on it, this game receives regular updates but none of them were able to solve the issue.

I love exploring and collecting stuffs in games and I would have done it if only the fps issue didn't exist. Maybe someday if it is fixed, i'll come back for more. Even with the fps issue, this is an amazing game. I would recommend this game to anyone who wants an exploration game with beautiful visuals and great music.

35916942.review:
Hob - oder auch der Rasenmähsimulator - 

Ich habe glaube ich in einem Spiel noch nie soviel Rasen gemäht wie in Hob. Und auch wenn das bisher komisch klingt, macht es spieltechnisch sogar was aus, weil man dann schneller vorwärts kommt und im Rasen Heilorbs finden kann.

Aber nun mal ernster.

Viele vergleichen Hob mit Zelda, den Vergleich kann ich nicht tätigen da ich nie Zelda gespielt habe.
Ich würde Hob eher als kindgerechtes Darksiders bezeichnen, mit weniger Fokus auf Kampf. Es gibt auch keine Bosskämpfe und bis auf ein oder zwei Feindbegegnungen, kann man jedem Kapf sein lassen. Der Fokus des Spieles liegt eher auf Erkundung.
Warum ich den Vergleich mit Darksiders ziehe? Zum ersten wäre da die unwiderlegbare Gleichheit der beiden Hauptdarsteller. Beide tragen einen roten Umhang, haben ein Schwert und eine"etwas" zu groß geratene Hand. 
Zudem ist selbst die Ausrüstung die man erlangt ziemlich identisch zu Kriegs Spielzeug.

2 Kritikpunkte gibt es dann auch noch

- Die Kamera ist starr, also nicht frei beweglich, was mich etliche Sprünge und auch Leben gekostet hat

- Es gibt ein Problem mit der Engine, soll wohl nur mit der 1xxxer Serie von NVidia passieren, vor welches zu teilweise heftigen Ruckeleinlagen führt. Da ist aber scheinbar auch nicht jeder Nutzer von betroffen.

35899126.review:
With the latest patch and the Windows 10 Creator's Fall Update, this game is running smooth as butter for me (NVidia 1080). All that is left  is the serene beauty that is this Hob. Yes, there are some similarities to Zelda here, but Hob stands on its own so well with a mysterious, beautiful world to explore, and clever, enjoyable puzzles. If you are looking for a game with amazing combat, this is not it. Serviceable, yes, but I don't feel like combat is meant to be the primary focus.

This is my favorite game of the last few years. Thank you, Runic Games, for this.

35894447.review:
很喜欢这种清新的画风，这就是所谓的塞尔达风格嘛？
本人12个小时左右通关，怎么说呢，游戏的主旋律就是探索和解密啊！！动作元素稍微有那么一点点的硬核感觉，类似魂系列摸一下就要死。不过基本可以无视战斗难度。
而且，游戏从一开始到后来，通过石头人的指引以及地图不断的“建造”出来，就能够感受到游戏剧情的发展。

1.画面
清新、耐看、讨人喜欢。虽然没有什么3A大作的各种粒子效果，但是这种讨人喜欢的卡通风格，也不失为一种解决办法。对于天天沉浸在各个3A大作中的我来说，算是眼前一亮吧。

2.音乐
嗯，背景音乐？那是啥？不过各个地图、动作等等的音效还是可以的，比较有代入感

3.游戏性
游戏以解谜为主，通过一道道谜底，潜移默化的告诉玩家这个世界发生了什么，不需要大段的过场动画、大篇幅的漫画叙事、或者大段的文字阅读内容以及开放世界的那种收集笔记之类的。感觉这一点做的很赞，制作方，通过环境、谜题一步一步的告诉你这个奇葩世界发生的故事。
战斗部分，虽然不难，但是也不是很鸡肋，每个怪物都是有特色的，战斗过程有一定的挑战性，而且那种喷血让人很爽，打击感还可以，用视觉效果来提高打击感。

4.创意
感觉这个游戏算是那种一次性的快餐游戏。如果后续不出额外DLC拓展游戏地图和剧情的话，相信我你打完一遍就不想玩第二遍了。就像《勇敢的心》、《黑暗血统》这类的，可玩性除了第一次给玩家带来的惊喜以外，没有重复欲望。

总结：
今年质量比较高的轻量级冒险解谜游戏，推荐入手。清新脱俗的画面，轻松惬意的游戏氛围，让玩家从各种战火纷飞、绝地求生、肾上腺素里面解放出来，算是在玩腻3A大作之余适当的甜品吧。

Da es aber ständig crasht und es immer noch nicht behoben wurde durch bugfixes kann ich nur davon abraten.

35889316.review:
So I'll get this out of the way first, I think Hob is deserving the title of Game of the Year, the outstanding ability to intertwine all aspects of design with the mechanics is nothing short of masterful and inspiring. Onto my review.

Hob is a masterpiece of design, with an intimate world. Each mechanic is introduced and explored at a pace that keeps the gameplay intruiging and exploration relevant. Near the end of the game I found myself amazed at how brilliantly the mechanics and world are made for eachother, even while looking at the game in a critical deconstructive manner it took me so long to realize I had been conditioned to associate materials and elements within the world with mechanics, testament to how potentially shy of the blue pads, every interactive element of the world feels like it belongs there.

If I had 1 criticism it'd be that the story was a little beyond my reach, but I have a feeling the vague nature of the story was intentional, in any case the beats were impactful and whatever the full bredth of the story was I at least adored the portion of it which the game takes place.

35880591.review:
Really interesting game! Hob looks great and some aspects of the gameplay were always wanting me to keep playing. The downside is that it wasn't overly challenging. Combat was very easy, you can just dodge every hit and then attack when the enemy is vulnerable. 

This game is more for the puzzles and the visuals than anything else and with near zero replayability. 

If you enjoy solving puzzles and amazing visuals I highly recommend this game.

35876573.review:
This is a fun game for certain.

The sense of discovery and joy as you explore this strange world and build it back up to it's true glory is a wonderful tale.

I whole heartedly recommend it to people who enjoy exploration and a largely self guided run through the game. But it is not without its caveats.

Crashing. It will crash for the most random reasons. However the devs seem to be actively working towards fixing these issues and in my final run through the game I suffered no crashes.

The requirement of a controller. They aren't kidding when it says a controller is recommended. the game is very difficult without one. You NEED a controller to have a comfortable experience.

But otherwise. the combat is punchy and feels good and the puzzles are not too difficult but aren't tedious which is a great thing.

Overall, I would totally lose an arm over this game.

35857919.review:
J’attendais Hob avec impatience et je n’ai vraiment pas été déçu.

Voir le monde se construire par blocs au fil de nos actions est un vrai régal et j’ai passé des heures à ma balader pour récolter tous les secrets une fois l’aventure finie, juste par plaisir.

Graphiquement le jeu est magnifique et je me suis souvent arrêté pour faire des captures d’écran de ses plus jolis panoramas.

Le mix aventure / puzzle / action est bien dosé et si on peut regretter qu’il n’y ait pas de boss, les différents « donjons » vous demanderont un peu de réflexion pour trouver quoi activer et dans quel ordre pour tout remettre en état.

Comptez environ 10h pour boucler l’aventure, mais suivant le temps passé à récolter les différents objets cachés vous pouvez quasiment doubler cette durée.

Ca faisait longtemps que je n’avais pas pris autant plaisir à m’immerger dans un univers et c’est donc sans hésitation que je vous recommande Hob chaudement.

[url=http://www.gamesidestory.com/2017/10/19/hob/]Lire le test complet sur Game Side Story[/url]

I'm in love with this game. There are not many games that I can say that about lately but here are my reasons why:

1) The World feels so alive with all the different animals and plants. 
2) The graphics style of the game is very pretty.
3) The puzzles to unlock new areas are all different and interesting.

35850128.review:
Video Review at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rr2xvo4M4Ys
Hob is a 3D top down action game that plays sort of like Hyper Light Drifter and Legend of Zelda, sounds pretty awesome right? Well not really because the core mechanics of what make those two games great are a filed down mess.

The majority of this game is walking around the map pushing buttons, and when I say majority I mean 98% of the game is spent doing this. There are no actual challenging puzzles in the game, any puzzle you come across is solved by walking around an area till you find a button you didn’t push, a ladder you haven’t climbed, or a cube you haven’t pushed into the right area. Most of these puzzles became incredibly frustrating because you would hit a button, then an area across the map would have changed slightly and you’d have to figure out what changed. 
 
You don’t really have to think at all while going through the game, most of the puzzle go as follows. If you hit a dead end, there’s probably a button nearby, and you better push that button so that it lights up another button five rooms back. You spend around an hour in each area pushing buttons, so you can go to another section across the map to push more buttons. It gets incredibly tedious, and really starts wearing on you after you catch onto the fact that there is no more substance to the game.

Throughout the entirety of Hob there were zero bosses, which was a serious problem with the game. It would set you up perfectly for a boss fight, you’d push a button and a huge shutter would happen causing the platform you were on to shoot underground, straight into a massive robot manufacturing facility, were you’d ultimately have to battle a colossal robot scorpion. However, the scorpion never came, there was never going to be a boss fight. You never get to fight that grand robot scorpion, you enter this beautiful looking robot facility, push more buttons, and leave. There is never a boss to challenge your mechanics, and what you’ve learned through the monsters in the area.  Some would say this isn’t really a downside because the game was meant to focus on its story, which is understandable, but it doesn’t help the game from becoming stale.

There’s minimal combat and whenever you actually do get into a fight, the combat feels stiff and thrown in just as a distraction from the dull task of clicking buttons. You have a roll ability which is comparable to the dash from Hyper Light Drifter, or the Roll in Dark Souls, it grants you a few Invincibility frames and darts you in whichever direction you point the stick. There is no cool down or Stamina bar forcing you to use these rolls strategically. Every fight turns into rolling around until the enemy uses one of his two attacks, then you strike him until you see his attack animation start again. Rinse and Repeat.

The fighting became so boring and frustrating that I found myself just running past the enemies, because it was better than hitting them in the face with a sword thirty times till they exploded into bits. The only time I wouldn’t run past them was if the game deemed it necessary to kill them to open a door, or lift a platform. There wouldn’t be any indication that you needed to kill them either, you would just have to figure that out through elimination.

There are two weapons in this game, you have the classic sword, and a robotic fist which you can charge up and hit for damage slightly higher than a basic sword attack, which basically means you’ll never use the Fist unless you need to destroy an enemies Rock Armor. The charge up on this weapon is actually incredibly long for the low damage return, it’s a high-risk weapon with low reward.

There's also some upgrades to your character which grant you new abilities, the only ones I purchased was the Shield upgrade, which you’ll never use because it costs energy to deflect hits, and slows down the game to an unbearable crawl, and the Teleport behind enemies' ability, which you’ll never use because it costs energy, and you can just roll around practically making you invincible. There are also abilities to change some of your sword combos, like a stab while sprinting combo. This was the only one you would really use, but it never felt ground breaking. You wouldn't unlock the upgrade and say to yourself. “Wow, this ability is going to change everything!” It's just more of the same, you hardly even notice using it.

Now onto the worst thing in this entire game, the Grappling Hook. This was the worst thing by far in the whole game. The grappling hook uses energy for you to hold on to the “Hook” which in longer platforming sections will seriously frustrate you, it’s already hard enough just using the thing. To jump from hook to hook, you have to make sure your camera, slowly moves itself into position so the next hook is in view, while holding yourself up with the hook running your energy low. You then have to look at it with the left stick till it glows, then I think you press A to latch to it. I say I think because it’s so terrible that sometimes it will just jump you off the hook and you’ll fall to your death. Sometimes you'll jump to the next hook effortlessly, then you'll fly straight back to the previous hook. It’s awful in all regards. There’s a section where you have to do six grapple jumps in a row and after all that work, what do you get? A cloak that you don’t even get to use because it costs eight butterflies which is a ton!

Across the map there are hidden sections where you can find different Cloaks, each one of these has to be unlocked with a ridiculous number of butterflies. It took me till about three quarters through the game to unlock one of these cloaks. They offer a boost stat effect, for a downside of another stat you have, generally health. The one I bought was the Green cloak which increased your speed. It didn’t really change too much but it is there if you want to collect something to try and spice up your game.

While exploring this world you'll come across these Chests you can open, giving you ten green orbs, or a new schematic for an ability or cloak. Early on these chests are a life saver when trying to afford your initial upgrades, and I always felt relieved when I found one.  However, the problem that happens in Hob is the fact that enemies drop these green orbs as well, and they drop way more than the chests. This makes the chests feel like a waste of time trying to collect once you're further into the game, especially when majority of them only have ten green orbs in them. 
 
The biggest enemy in the entire game is the perspective. The camera is constantly out to get you, making platforms seem in reach when in reality they’re incredibly far away. The cameras are in fixed locations that you cannot rotate, while walking it will snap to a new location sometimes changing the direction you’re moving in causing you to fall off a platform. Slight inclined platforms are some of the most annoying things in this game, you can’t tell where the edge is properly, you don’t know if rounded objects like the pipes you walk on will be collided properly. There is a section where you're climbing a colossus which is fairly broken, once you get to one of its joints it starts pushing your character off. You basically have to fight the game to advance past this section.

Ladders are also horrifying, they’re so frustrating it’s difficult to describe. When walking up to a ladder and pushing towards the left once attaching to the ladder it will force you all the way to the left on the actual ladder, forcing you to change the angle of the stick. It seems like a stupid complaint but through the seven-hour play time it really adds up becoming incredibly irritating.

One thing that gets incredibly annoying is the fact that when every you approach an object your character climbs on it, so you have to get in a very precise location to pull a lever, or you’ll just start climbing on it. Let's talk about bugs, in Part Two.

Awesome game!

I dig the art style and music / sound. The controls are a little loose, but the combat is a lot of fun once you figure it out (I felt the same way about Hyper Light Drifter, although Hob's enemies are not as challenging [not a bad thing]).

35829988.review:
Hob is well designed and fun to play. It is a 3D platformer, living puzzle-box of a world, that evolves and changes the further you progress. As soon as I started playing Hob I wanted to know what happened to this place and what was going to happen next.

Visually, it is a work of art.

Exploration and discovery are key roles and none of the inhabitants of this world really tell you where to go or what to do. You get to figure that out for yourself. That's part of the fun and once you get it, the flow of the game really draws you in.

As a game, it is one of few I have played in several years (PC & Consoles) where my excitement to play consistently wasn't driven by some need to do "daily quests" or involve myself in some new weekly "multiplayer modes" just to climb tiers as a progression scheme.

I just enjoyed the game and wanted to see how it ended.

I recently finished the game and was more than happy with my time spent playing it and the price. Torchlight I/II were awesome, Hob was amazing, and I am already looking forward to whatever Runic Games has to offer next.

My only recommendations are:

(1) If you get frustrated, go back to areas you may have overlooked with a fresh eye. Don't rush - and resist the urge to "Google it". You're only cheating yourself from having that "Aha! I got it!" moment that comes from figuring it out for yourself.

(2) A game controller (PS4, using DS4Windows in my case) is really much more fun and natural than a keyboard + mouse. This is my own personal preference, although a game controller is also recommended by the developers. You may enjoy the game just fine without a controller.

35817358.review:
Hob is a fantastic game that combines a number of genres into one.  Puzzles, exploration, item collection, it's all there.  What I liked is the emphasis on the exploration, no matter what direction you took, you always seemed to end up where you where supposed to go, so I never felt lost while moving towards the next objective.  Finding secrets/collectibles was very well implemented.  Some are obvious to find, others a little more obscure and more difficult.  And what I loved was stumbling on a room that a lot of detail went into made specifically just for a health, energy upgrade, etc.  Sound, music, and ambience are all very good.  The art style, aesthetics, character design are top notch.  And of course, the manner of opening new areas/shorcuts is very creative and imaginative, and I was always pleased to watch it unfold.

What I didn't like was the camera.  For the most part, it did it's job, but other times I would find my view stuck behind some object, or the angle itself would make me miss jumps.  The camera is just troublesome.  I've had some performance issues with framerate and vsync.  I ran 60 fps for the majority of the time, with skips in framerate during gameplay, and some areas that suffered framerate drops.  You'll also run into quite a few graphical glitches, bugs that broke immersion for me.  There wasn't a whole lot of variety in enemy types, as you'll see the exact enemies in every part of the game.

Overall, aside from the flaws and glitches/bugs, I had a blast with Hob and enjoyed every minute with it.  I highly recommend it.

35816901.review:
TLDR: I went in with stupidly high expectations, and was ultimately disappointed.

Let me start off by saying that the game is not bad. The world is unique and interesting. The artstyle is enough to sell the game on its own. The mechanics are solid, if a bit lackluster. It also runs very well (at least on my machine anyway) with the framerate dipping below 60 only a couple of times. I ran into a few minor bugs, sure, but only one that forced me to restart the game in order to progress. All in all, it wasn't technically bad.

Now with all the nice things I have to say out of the way, I'm about to rip this game apart.

I was looking for a zelda like experience. 6 hours in, I was wondering where the dungeons where at, where where the boss fights? I've picked up a couple upgrades, but I'm still running with just a sword and a robo fist.

There are no dungeons in Hob. There's a couple (maybe 3) underground areas that might be large enough to count as dungeons, but they're all so straightforward that they're just a seriese of obsticals.

Once I got over the initial wow factor of the new areras springing into place, the exploration of the world just swung back and forth between follow the blip on the map, and hunt for the one square centimeter that you haven't stood on yet. Often, the route you're supposed to take is easy to miss, which left me frequently thinking "what do I do? where do I go?". That's bad conveyance.

Combat in this game felt like it was trying to be dark souls, and did not succeed. I feel one of the biggest detriments was the lack of variety of ways to kill enemies. You can slash enemies, and you can punch them, and that's pretty much it. Hob would  benefit greatly from some kind of ranged attack, even if it was extremely limited in use.

Enemies could be classified into two groups: Trivial enemies that where basicly no threat so I'd just ignore them, and Absurd enemies that would kill you in one or two hits (three hits if you have almost all the health upgrades) no matter what you do so I'd avoid them as much as possible. While it certainly didn't help that I'm bad at the combat of this game, I didn't feel encouraged to get better. The best solution was the avoid combat, unless of course an enemy sensor eye stalk was in the room. This is a shame, because I like good combat systems. I like killing monsters. I didn't like killing monsters in Hob.

I thought maybe it was because I was using a controller, maybe that's why the combat felt off. So I switched to mouse and keyboard and discovered CARDINAL SIN NUMBER ONE: you cannot rebind the controlls. There are two presets for mouse and keyboard, and one preset for controller. That's it. This right here is enough for me to condemn even the best game. It's 2017, ALL games should have completely rebindable controlls.

There is only one boss fight in the entire game, and it's at the very end. At this point, I just turned the difficulty down to easy because since I never really practiced the combat during the entirety of the game, I had no hope of actually beating that fight. Also, I just wanted to get to the end already.

On game length, I beat it in about 13 hours, although someone who doesn't suck could probably do it in half that time. While I'm totally fine with short playtimes  in games if I really had fun with it, I can't say that I really had fun with Hob. I finished it wanting more than it could offer. The last 5 hours of play felt like a slog, I was going through the motions without caring anymore why I was doing them. Knowing all the while that I wouldn't find any worthwhile challenge along the way (and then they spring the game's only boss fight on me, but I already went over that).

I would have loved to see what this game would have been if Runic gave it another year before release. I applaud them for doing something different from what they've done in the past, and I'm sad that I didn't like it as I thought I would.

35767646.review:
Hob is set on a beautiful and dangerous unknown world, with buzzing life above and the whirr of mysterious machinery below. The more players delve into the world’s design, the more they uncover a planet in peril. Players must learn to survive, understand their true purpose through acquiring skills, and ultimately transform the nature of the world itself. Hob is presented without text or dialogue. Narrative is revealed as players explore and interact with their mysterious planet, and the strange life forms that inhabit it. Hob features smooth controller gameplay, multi-layered puzzles, and striking visuals.


Hob is the newest and most ambitious project of Runic Games, a developer made famous by the popular Torchlight franchise.

Moving away from the previous style of Diablo clone games Runic Games delivers Hob. Hob is the name given to a tool used to cut/manipulate gears. This word perfectly defines the main character as you roam through this beautiful world. Hob's world is a machine, and throughout the game, you must master puzzles and dungeons to rearrange the world to what you need it to be. This is a fantastic concept that makes the world seem like a living character on its own. Hob is not a game that will please everyone although I'm sure Hob will please the fans of a good Indie game filled with puzzles and some very subjective story telling.

Unlike the overwhelming majority of games, Hob's plot is transmitted subjectively and artistically. The path is pointed (literally) by the faithful squire of the protagonist and there is also a map to assist the player if he gets lost. Other than this you are on your own. There is no tutorial, which I find refreshing. Runic must feel the player is smart enough not to have their hand held during the opening areas of the game. I respect that. The overall story can be as deep or as light as you want it to be. There are optional rooms to unlock in game that give you a visual clue as to how the world became what it was, but doesn’t tell it to you like other games do. Now I quite enjoyed this as I explored the world more freely than I would have if there was a linear story or even waypoints put in front of me (give me a dot on a map and I will follow it). However, I can see this having the opposite effect on some players. They could become confused by the slow and very subjective storytelling, and find it difficult to progress through the game.  The game features well thought out puzzles that will require a bit of thinking. Despite the degree of complexity, the gameplay and the puzzles are intuitive and should not cause a headache for most players. Hob also has some satisfying RPG elements. There are a lot of collectibles scattered throughout the world. From sword fragments to improve the character's attack to Heart pieces to upgrade your overall health (Link to the Past anyone???) I must say, I fell in love with this game as soon as I saw the art work and E3 trailers earlier this year. The game world is beautiful and the use of colour is executed perfectly. The main world areas above ground are colorful, vibrant and seem full of life, but when you delve into the dungeons there is a distinct change in tone making each area feel ancient and abandoned. The music in the game is perfect with each area/dungeon having its own unique soundtrack.  Hob is a game that is fun and full of life (even if it is a little Zelda-esqe). I highly recommend this game to everyone. It looks and sounds beautiful; the puzzles and combat are satisfying and the dungeons are challenging and different enough not to come across as boring or repetitive.

I played Hob through Steam on launch day and I have held off on my review as there were initially some ‘bugs’ I encountered. There was an issue with GTX graphics cards that would make the game crash at launch and I also encountered a lot of dropped frames but after a few very quick updates the game now runs smooth as butter.

Hob is available now on Playstation 4, Steam, GOG and Humble Bundle

www.honestgamingreviews.com

35763642.review:
If you like a chill puzzle adventure with a little bit of fighting then this game is for you. The puzzles are not difficult, in fact the majority of your path will be linear with a few paths that lead off to treasure. The graphics are beautiful and remind me of Borderlands with their comic like look. You can upgrade your sword, health, energy, and even your cloak throughout your travels. There is no dialogue and the inhabitants speak in sim-like babble which gives the game some charm as you get to use your imagination. Their are two endings which you can experience right after each other and their interpretation is up to you.
The only problems I had were a few wonky camera angles that did result in death; your character will sometimes bump into a ledge and fall to their death instead of grabbing it, and I found several spots where my character became stuck and I had to respawn. In one of the titans my character also fell through the floor and sustained damage. Aside from that I found the game very relaxing and if you decide to "purge" as your ending you get to see more Hob like people.

35763476.review:
С каждым часом прохождения Hob, на сколько стремительно у меня пропадал интерес к самой игре, на столько же стремительно он возростал к ее авторам. Ведь каждый разработчик видеоигр в первую очередь хочет сделать игру, которая будет и сама по себе финансово успешным проектом, и расширит аудиторию потребителей будущих релизов студии (забудем про издателей на время). Так вот Hob наврядли хорошо окупится (и окупится ли) и врядли подогреет интерес и внимание игроков к последующим их проектам. Но что самое интересное, мне кажется, разработчики об этом и сами заранее знают (ну или предполагают). Чтобы немного больше укрепить это предположение, и без того имеющее под собой мало оснований, мне бы стоило поиграть в Torchlight, но чую это гиблое дело, так как главная ее особенность автогенерация - болезненная язва на теле игровой индустрии.

Так в чем же дело с Hob? Когда вы последний раз играли в платформер с видом сверху при наличии вертикального геймплея, с потенциально очень многообещающей боевкой, с элементами головоломки и метроидвании и без... СЮЖЕТА!!!? Hob - это эксперимент. Причем очень смелый. Вы скажете - что в этом такого, это же инди, а инди должны цеплять именнно уникальностью, свежим игровым опытом, новыми идеями, жанорвыми хитросплетениями и т.д. Все верно. Но почему не наложить хоть какой-то сценарий, самим придумать, не нанимая сценаристов отдельно? Limbo, Inside, Little Nightmares тоже были немыми, но там все понятно и без слов. Здесь же ничерта, а в конце еще и выбор просят сделать). Так то судя по всему история прослеживается драматичная. Почему ее явно не рассказать?

При этом у игры есть же очень сильные стороны. В принципе все составляющие игрового процесса умело вписаны в общую картину. А из определенно сильных элементов выступают вертикальный геймплей и боевка.
Вертикальный геймплей при изометрической камере на меня произвел просто "вау" эффект. Когда взбираешься куда-нибудь повыше и перепрыгиваешь с одной узкой платформы на другую в спринте - просто дух захватывает. При этом хоть окружение и однообразное, картика приятная, выдержан собственный стиль. 
Касательно боевки можно поспорить конечно. Может она и скудновата, но здесь ты не выживешь тупо закликивая противника и чередуя умения, как в умирающем жанре экшн-рпг (Diablo, Titan Quest, Sacred, Grim Dawn). Честно говоря я до сих пор не пойму, почему классические экшн-рпг не переведут на такой тип боевки как в Hob и Furi например. 
А касательно скудности боевых элементов и умений, для Hob того, что есть, достаточно, главное, что потенциал выбран верный. А развить этот потенциал можно и в следующих проектах, были бы деньги.
В принципе все остальное сделано слабее. Головоломки (если их можно так назвать) простые, слегка нудные. Порой очень долго приходится отыскивать способ добраться до цели во всех этих хитросплетениях путей. Звук хорош, но эмбиент на фоне играет такой себе. 

В общем будь здесь явный сюжет, и подтянули бы все элементы до одного уровня - была бы очень достойная уникальная игра. А так это пока выглядит как проба пера перед нечто большим.
Советовать никому не буду. Если желаете исключительного игрового опыта, возможно не ошибетесь, взяв ее даже за полную стоимость.
6/10

35754037.review:
Liked:
-Good puzzles that open the world in a linear fashion.
-Out-of-the-box compatibility with X-box controller.
-Combat is simple, which keeps the focus on adventuring.
-The game looks nice, but I think every purple claw is modeled as an individual monster, which wrecks my FPS in thickly infested areas. After you get killed by one the first time and realize they actually attack, the claws are nothing more than a frame-rate dropping nuisance.
-A ton of extra exploring to do. I thought I was doing pretty good until I finished the game and had barely found half the available hearts and only 3 sword pieces.

Disliked:
-The height at which a jump will kill doesn't seem to be standard throughout the game. Sometimes it looks like you've found a shortcut, but you just splat and respawn.
-Fixed camera is usually OK, but there are a number of points in the game where it makes things harder than they should be because you either can't judge where you're jumping or it's a bad angle/zoom for combat.
-Low variety of enemies.
-Hob will grab most ledges if you fall off, but there is no way to drop down from the hang. You just crawl back up. Super annoying when you're trying to drop down to another ledge.
-Respawn animations are nice touches at the start, but soon turn into nothing more than game delays.
-Endings are anti-climatic and sudden.

35749417.review:
What if you'd mix bioshock's aesthetics, zelda's adventuring/fighting and metroid's exploration together in a final synthesis of the 3 genres ? You get HOB!

The world itself is very abstract and teaches you how to go through your own inquisite nature and icons on the worldmap. 

There's almost no hand holding. It's a bit confusing at first but after encountering world events corresponding to the itels you find, you get the grasp. Go to your work bench and see what "this full meter" does to your sword,  and how about these mysterious butterflies ? are these for crafting abilities ? 

In the scenes you'll encounter power up stations, mysterious traps and corruption that you have to do away with in various ways. What's that ridable tripod that gives stuff power ? 

In this game, you find out things by doing and it's sometimes frustrating but just when you're about to get stuck, you discover a new drop or ladder, path or action you have to take that will make you discover the world further. The game doesn't feel linear though, becuase you're mostly poking holes in the corners where you explored and go ever further on the scenario. This is a wonderous adveture to figure out.

Sometimes you'll access a passage and a dungeon which will make sense of the progress when you come out of its tail or top end. 

So because there's almost no hand holding I call it "pragmatism simulator, the game." 

When you are in dungeons you'll unexpectedly find new things you never thought you'd need before, and this is it's very mch like a metroid game, that with every ability found/upgrade, world layer raised or corruption removed, there's an other layer of exploration you can do in the same place. Hob's cuteness mystery and danger comes together into one of the most enjoyable games of this year, 

Hob is the pragmatic "sherlock holmes" of action adventure games, while it adds a little hint of "pocket tomb raider/metroid" into the gameplay mix. You find out about the story pure by playing and deduction, nothing else!

35748172.review: This game is gorgeous, the world is absorbing, the puzzles are fun, and it's a genuine joy to fix the world and change the geography. Highly recommended.

35745836.review:
Wonderful game, generally recommended. It can be completed in a couple of hours, but I had major fun throughout it all.

At the point of writing this review, there were some frame-drops at times, but luckily it didn't affect the combat too much.

The puzzles are on the easier side I think, and much of the game is fairly linear in that it always pulls you to the next objective you have to solve. There were no place in the game where I got "stuck" and had to think about what to do next. This is both good and bad. Good, because progress is always being made. Bad because puzzles are then fairly easy. If you like hard puzzles, this is not a game for you. If, on the other hand, you want to chill on a couch, this is an excellent game.

There are some combat in the game. But it is built on learning what the opponent is doing and adapting to this, more than it requires fast reaction skills. I found the combat fair, and not too punishing. You will soon have a health bar which can cope and opponents drop extra health as you defeat them in order to help you going further.

35743589.review:
这是一个看似开放世界的线性游戏

35737171.review:
[h1]徒有其表的西洋钟
——评《Hob》[/h1]

还是先上简评：
+ 独具一格的画面风格
+ 拾人牙慧但令人眼前一亮的观景台
+ 无文字的自然表现形式
+ 流畅而打击感强的战斗体验
o 美观但缺乏引导的开放世界场景
o 不明所以但不明觉厉的剧情
- 反馈感极低的线性谜题设计
- 存在感稀薄的背景音乐
- 大量的贴图与卡位Bug
- 鸡肋的收集要素
 
总评：5.5/10，外表光鲜亮丽，内在机械枯燥，玩家想要的是足够有趣的开放世界解谜游戏，但Runic Games呈上来的只是一个线性观光游戏，令人失望。
 
先感谢一下STCN鉴赏家提供的评测机会，终于加上小粉枪的好友了。
 
在《Hob》上架之前，我和不少玩家一样心怀期待，大家都多多少少沉迷过火炬之光这个刷刷刷游戏，都希望Runic Games能在《Hob》中能够脱离暴雪与《暗黑破坏神》的影响，做出一个属于他们自己的独立游戏。
 
从我一贯的傲慢视角来看，就像是皇帝已经厌倦了旧有邦国献上的珍珠玉石，听说外邦来了传教士，希望他能带来一些令人眼前一亮的贡品。
传教士来了，献上了大洋彼岸的宝物：一座西洋钟。
皇帝一看，的确是让人眼前一亮：
自然、机械与腐化的元素在游戏中毫不突兀地结合在一起，构造了一幅由Fariy Land与Steam punk混成的世界图景。身披红色披风的主人公，与它的守护者机器人在开场剧情中的惊人表现暗示了故事的主线与游戏的基调。
 
游戏选择了无教程、无文字、无引导的方式来保证画面与剧情的原生态，你可以在游戏中寻找观景台，一览这颗小小星球上不同区域的错落景致，也可以一点点探索地图，渐渐代入到“披风小人”中，更为深入地沉浸到开发者为我们准备的世界之中，去发掘迷雾中的未知。

你可能会问，这不挺好的吗？
——西洋钟的外观总是华美精致的，但等到皇帝打开了西洋钟的后盖，看到里面复杂的机械结构，便会问传教士这些是什么。
传教士一言不发，丢给皇帝一张结构图——还是草图——然后吹嘘道：蒙主之恩，西洋钟里面的零件只要能拆下来，就一定能按照这图装上去。
皇帝尝试弄下来个齿轮，发现都是固定死的，根本无法拆卸。
皇帝：？？？
可那传教士仍在吹嘘西洋钟的妙处，仿佛他不知道这座西洋钟的真面目一样——外壳装饰是教会的大匠精心制作，机芯却被换成主教的工匠侄子偷工减料做出的经常会停摆的次品，连报时的功能都时灵时不灵。
 
如果只看宣传片与截图，每个人都会对《Hob》心存期待，可在进一步体验后，你的游戏体验就会被各种贴图与卡位bug一点点破坏掉。玩家经常会被各种bug卡进地面、草丛、山坡，甚至有一次我被卡在存档点里出不来，成了坏档，只能从头再来。
 
而且当我关闭游戏后再度打开《Hob》，脑中总会浮现出经典的三个问题：我是谁？我在哪儿？我要干什么？只凭着地图上模糊的指示，无形的任务链条很容易断掉，令玩家失其间，在地图上漫无目的地跑着。
强调空灵又缺乏节奏感的背景音乐在这个时候的存在感极其稀薄，只有玩家在观景台驻足时才会想起“咦，这游戏还有音乐呢”。
 
《Hob》在宣传时着重强调了“开放世界”的元素，号称可以在地图上各个区域间自由地探索，原则上你可以通过技能与地面上的几种装置交互，自由地探索，不过在你打过三四迷宫后，会发现你只能按一定的次序探索迷宫并获得技能，并按智能机器人指引的既定顺序一个一个探索下去，不然就会卡地图、无处可去。等我踌躇满志地开始自由探索时，却猛然发现我已经探齐地图、戴了绿帽换上了绿披风、面对女王、即将结束游戏了...
Runic Games最初是可能是想做一个真正的开放世界的，但我玩到的却只是一个假装成开放世界的线性结构，有一种《全境封锁》街区缩水闹剧再演的既视感。
 
在《Hob》中，线性的不仅仅是地图与场景，还有解谜与战斗。
 
《Hob》的解谜部分本应该是最吸引人的部分，大多数玩家想看到的是机巧运转、关窍暗藏、曲径通幽的谜题设计，通过自己的冥思苦想、反复尝试，得到解密成功的正面情绪反馈，但《Hob》令我们失望了：玩家想要“七巧板”，但《Hob》却是“一根筋”。
可能是为了弥补探索过程中引导的缺失，游戏中出现的谜题难度异常“人性化”，玩家一路前行，看到无法通过的路径，只要环顾四周，一定能找到直接移除障碍、开启路径的机关，如果找不到，那就再环顾一次...这样无脑推过去，令人感觉就像钟表中的一块小齿轮，无需思考，只要不停地绕轴转动就能完成自己的任务，感受不到丝毫乐趣。
另外，开发组“贴心”地为所有悬空部分设置了跌落保护，所以在《Hob》中解谜的唯一难点就是小心不要在跳台间跳跃时被跌落保护拦住...
 
至于战斗，有着两部《火炬之光》的经验与底蕴，钢拳+铜剑的技能组合打击感很棒，怪物的设计也颇为经典，唯一的问题是难度曲线——一个正常冒险游戏的战斗难度应该是梯度上升的，但《Hob》的战斗难度是一条躺平的直线，游戏中的战斗场景本就不多，不超过双手之数的怪物类型也难以构成令人感到棘手的配合，就算是我这种相对手残的老年玩家，也可以基买齐初始技能后一路平砍过去。
 
战斗难度的平稳导致游戏中用于加强角色战斗力的收集要素都成了鸡肋，在《Hob》中，玩家看到一条没走过的岔路，第一反应不是探路，而是“诶？又是收集品吗？拿了也没用，继续赶路吧”，然后略过开发组精心布置的五种收集品继续疯狂迷路...
 
顺带一提，请尽量收集齐古剑碎片，可以通过遗迹来查看背景故事，也会影响结局——这是游戏中唯二能影响剧情的玩家行为。
 
由于没有文字表述，《Hob》的剧情方面可以说是见仁见智，未收集古剑碎片的玩家就算通关了也是一头雾水，通过五个遗迹了解了历史的玩家也是一脸迷茫，对于细节的理解却不尽相同，但大家都有同样的感受：这剧情就是为了让开发组方便吃书才做得这么模糊不清的，玩家稀里糊涂玩下去也不影响游戏体验，颇有暴雪风味。
以下是我对剧情的理解，剧透涂黑。
[spoiler]
主角一族是来自星海的移民，有着极高的科技水平，乘坐星舟（世界之塔）降落在在这颗环境相对原始的星球上，在三个首领的带领下建立了一系列星球地下改造设施，并建造了大量辅助用的智能机器人。
可是好景不长，某种紫色的生物自星空而来，它们的领袖就是我们在游戏的最后面对的女王，紫色的血肉侵蚀了星海移民的大多数城市，甚至杀掉了一位首领。女王似乎这时才发现了与移民共存的办法，但此时星海移民们都躲入避难所休眠，只剩下智能机器人不知疲倦地抗击混沌。
其中一个机器人在濒死时，被树海的小精灵的歌声所拯救，开始不断释放沉睡中的星海移民，试图改变这一切。
它失败了无数次，败者皆腐朽枯槁；成功了一次半，其中半次是游戏中出现的先为同伴后成Boss的神秘人，他试图与紫色混沌共存，他有着成功的机会，但不幸的是，最终他失败了。
而主角，一路探索，被女王所救，得到了改变一切的机会：伸出友谊的手，成为新的傀儡，“温暖”这个世界；或是拔出决裂的剑，净化星球，唤醒同族？
[/spoiler]
 
总体而言，《Hob》是一个完成度不低但可玩性不高的解谜冒险类游戏，如果你喜欢在游戏里看风景、截图，《Hob》也许是个不错的选择，但如果你想玩谜题有趣、可以自由探索的开放世界游戏，Runic Games的这部新作可能不会令你感到满意，就像一个徒有其表的西洋钟，外表高贵美观，内在机械粗糙，与成功的独立游戏相比，还有很差距。

35735553.review:
First and foremost, be warned: If you're using a GTX 10-Series GPU, and/or are on Windows 10 (the issue hasn't been fully narrowed down as of writing) there is a pretty high likelyhood that you'll encounter severe dips and stuttering throughout Hob. The only solution so far is to get on the Windows Insider program and update to the Fall Creators Update. This fixed a lot of stuttering for me, but there were still times where my framerate was halved on a GTX 1080.

Hob is a good game, but I was having a hard time deciding and started out this review with the intention of not recommending it for the combination of performance issues, and gameplay issues I have. Visual design is great in Hob, I love the Borderlands esque art style, and the world and characters are fully realized. I do have a minor gripe that they have some missteps particularly at the end of the game with the lack of voice acting, but my main criticism lies in the gameplay.

The core of my issues with Hob's gameplay is due to the camera. You have no camera controls, as it's always locked and determined based on your position in the world. This works very well when you're rebuilding the world and have long shots of entire land chunks coming into scene which is really cool, but in gameplay it feels clunky. It's hard to judge where you're going to jump, so whenever you're doing precision platforming you're at risk of falling to your death. Not to mention for some reason you're stuck with Castlevania jump dedication, meaning as soon as you hit the jump button you're locked in. You get no manueverability whatsoever, which really clashes with the decision to have a locked camera. And considering you'll be doing a lot of jumping, this becomes a major issue. I died multiple times or had to restart puzzles more than once because I wasn't able to judge which direction I needed to point the left stick upon jumping. The camera also obscures your view in multiple areas, but this wasn't nearly as much of an issue.

I really want to recommend Hob and I do if you aren't at risk of performance issues, and know that you won't be frustrated by dying due to camera confusion. I was able to really get into the Hob for the last 3 or so hours of gameplay, but before that it was more of a grind to figure out performance issues and fight against the camera, which was really unfortunate. The game definitely had a lot more potential than was realized. I definitely think the unique ‘world building’ concepts they have in Hob are worth experiencing, but maybe wait for a price drop and make sure it’ll run well for you.

35732443.review:
I would recommend this game without much thought if it was 12-15€.
For 20€, the game feels too linear, buggy, and non-challenging.

Personally I also found myself getting increasingly annoyed with the control-scheme used to climb ladders (walking up to a ladder on your left, you'd be holding the stick to the left. As soon as you touch the ladder, you have to press up. The character in most modern games will simply continue to climb the ladder as long as you hold whatever direction formerly counted as forward. In Hob, this is not the case) and the camera also leaves much to be desired at times.

Combine annoyances like this with very linear maps/puzzles and largely uninspired upgrades which barely improve upon the simplistic combat, you're left with a poorly optimised, mute yet beautiful Zelda-clone.

If that's what you're looking for, this game is gonna be just your thing, and I'm sure I'd enjoy it a lot if I hadn't just refunded it for its pricetag.

35713595.review:
[b] In short [/b]
Hob is a beautiful game that instantly drew me in. It's polished and feels like a finished game (which cannot be said of all games these days).
I would recommend it to anyone who likes beautiful puzzle platformers with a bit of action and set in a unique world (so, most people?)

[b] Slightly longer [/b]
It reminded me of Journey, mixed with The Neverhood (or Armikrog), mixed with some of the charm and je ne sais quoi of old-school games such as Rayman, Jak and Daxter, or Crash Bandicoot; but with updated graphics and modern game design principles applied. That is of course coming from someone with a PS / PC background - someone coming from a Nintendo background would no doubt compare it to Zelda games or Super Mario 64.
I got from it a feeling I haven't felt from a game in a long time, it's a feeling I can't quite describe, but something akin to nostalgia mixed with innocent curiosity and fun - like I had the opportunity to be a child playing a favourite PS2 game during school break for the first time again.

[b] Longer and more technical [/b]

[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
    [*][i] Setting: [/i] Beautiful and creatively thought out world
    [*][i] Pace: [/i] Puzzles are light but interesting; you're never stuck on one thing for long
    [*][i] Not frustrating: [/i] Save points are regular and the only penalty for dying is going back to the save point, any progress between deaths is automatically kept
    [*][i] Clear is clear: [/i] Monsters typically don't respawn (with very few exceptions), this means when you're running back to a previous part of the world you're not constantly killing. Once you've cleared an area, it's pretty much clear.
    [*][i] Tone: [/i] Nice mix of tones that flow well between cuteness, fun, creepy weirdness, sadness, and mystery
    [*][i] Progression: [/i] Progression is quite clear - you do something and the world changes, opening up new areas and enabling you to go back to old areas to do things you couldn't do earlier that puzzled you (you get "ah ha, that's what that was for" moments). You also get more stats and abilities as you go.
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
    [*][i] Combat: [/i] The combat in Hob is... not perfect. It successfully increases the pace of the game and helps you define new areas from old, and is a bit of an interesting break in tone, plus it informs the plot a little as you go. But it's almost too simple - you get a lot of moves but 80% of them you'll never really use because certain combinations just work more effectively and are less risky. There are also some options to customise combat style (wearing different cloaks which affect your stats), but these take a long time to get, even longer to get more than one, and hard to change between. Plus I didn't tend to find the options that appealing.
    [*][i] Camera Angles: [/i] You have no control over the camera. Surprisingly this actually works in the game's favor 85% of the time, it simplifies a lot of the gameplay and is used to hint at things you might otherwise miss. However, at times you can get stuck with a weird camera angle that doesn't quite work, and the controls are oriented based on the camera angle... so if it shifts halfway through you running along a ledge all of the sudden you may be running in the wrong direction and fall. Also, running along ledges is hard in general with the angles given.
    [*][i] Controls: [/i] Some of the controls aren't great, and they're not explained. You have two dodge moves but I didn't even realise this until 1/2 way through the game (and that was by accident). There's also some inconsistency - when climbing up a ladder, 'up' is always 'up', even if the ladder is 90 degrees from the camera angle on the right. Conversely, when using an ability to climb up a ledge, 'up' is the direction the ledge is from you in 2.5D (so usually to the left or right), it isn't necessarily 'up'. Not a game breaker though, it still plays smoothly and you learn to compensate for these inconsistencies after 1 or 2 deaths, just a little annoying.
    [*][i] Unclear Ending: [/i] If you don't pay close attention to the mural movies found using your sword, and go through both endings, you will likely need to look up an essay dissecting what went down to understand it all. If you do pay attention and go through both, you may still need to look up said essay. For the most part the non-verbal aspect is quite endearing and works, but here the lack of clarity in communication right at the end as the plot is fully revealed can leave you feeling a little confused. I don't think verbalisation was needed, but the visual communication needed to be stepped up one notch - show us a telepathic cutscene of the past, give us slightly easier to understand murals, and/or a longer and more comprehensive pantomime sequence at the end. Something along those lines would have made for less confusion and a better feeling of resolution at the end of the game.
[/list]

[b] Neutral [/b]
[list]
    [*]The majority of puzzles in Hob are jumping puzzles - you have to work out how to physically get somewhere you can see, and often have to get creative. I like this type of puzzle, but I can understand if people do not.
    [*]The ending is quite bittersweet. Mild spoiler (as to tone and vague idea behind ending rather than specific plot): [spoiler] It involves a grey choice to make, which some may consider cool and others may consider unsatisfying. To have something heavy placed on your shoulders with no real 'right' answer and both positive and negative outcomes to either option is certainly interesting and different to the norm... But it also leaves you feeling bittersweet either way and unsatisfied that after affecting so much positive change throughout this beautiful world you're now uncertain whether you did the right thing. [/spoiler]
[/list]

[b] Overall [/b]
This game will never be my favourite game. It doesn't quite stand up to the design and polish of Ori and The Blind Forest, the uniqueness of Journey, the puzzles and plot of The Talos Principle, or the combat of... well, most games with combat. But I loved it, so much. And I am so very glad I bought it and spent the time playing, which was about 13 hours for me, but it felt like 20 (in a good way). It was relaxing and interesting and beautiful and fun. It is, simply put, a good game.

战斗。显然没打算把它做成核心，怪物种类少，会滚就行。
